XML.Hansard-Body:
Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts)
(9.34 am): Last week when the inspiring Dimity Dornan was named Suncorp Queenslander of the Year she responded with a comment that would move even the hardest of hearts. Ms Dornan, a renowned speech pathologist and founder of the Hear and Say Centre which has given the gift of sound to hundreds of children, said, ‘If you’ve ever seen a child’s face when they hear for the first time, it is impossible to deprive them or their family of that.’

Our government is listening and that is reflected in our funding of this very special sector in yesterday’s state budget. Every Queensland child who needs dual cochlear implants will now receive them under our new initiative and the remarkable Hear and Say Centre will also receive a significant financial boost. Our government will contribute an extra $5.5 million this financial year, amounting to $16.5 million over the next four years, to double the number of paediatric cochlear implants available for Queensland kids and to expand children’s hearing services. We will do this by allocating $2.46 million of that funding to the Hear and Say Centre to continue its groundbreaking work with hearing impaired children.

The Hear and Say Centre is one of the world’s leading cochlear implant centres, giving vital assistance to infants and children whose hearing problems affect their fundamental ability to communicate. Around 300 children are identified with hearing problems in Queensland every year and around 60 to 100 children will go on to need hearing aids or cochlear implants. We know that early detection and intervention of hearing loss is critical to giving our kids the best start in life and the work that this centre does gives Queensland children every opportunity to get the best out of their education and support as they get older.

Of the children with a cochlear implant who use the centre’s services, 97 per cent to 99 per cent are able to participate in mainstream schooling by the age of five. This new funding means 66 Queensland kids will be able to access a full package of auditory-verbal support through the Hear and Say Centre. Now that we have universal screening for children and cochlear technology is so good, we have more and more parents wanting to give their kids the best start. We know that dual cochlear implants work even better than a single one where appropriate. This funding guarantees that every child who needs single or dual implants will get them as well as enable us to provide them with the ongoing support and therapy that is needed. Additionally, $2 million in funding will go to the centre for capital investment.

This package means that Queensland now has the nation’s most comprehensive cochlear program. Our government’s groundbreaking universal newborn screening program is a major investment in our children’s future. Since its inception in 2004 the program has screened more than 279,000 newborn babies, some as young as six hours old. More than 98 per cent of Queensland children are now screened within 30 days of birth. This allows us to provide cochlear implants or hearing services for those children who need them from the earliest age.

Just seven years ago only one child under the age of three months was fitted with hearing aids. Thanks to our Healthy Hearing program, by 2008 there were 34 children under three months who had been identified and fitted with hearing aids and a further 34 were fitted by 12 months of age. This funding will double the number of publicly funded cochlear implants in 2010-11 and provide for additional implants every year after that. What it means is that in the forecasting no child will be put on a paediatric waiting list for cochlear implant surgery.

I was very pleased to be joined by the Deputy Premier and the Treasurer this morning on a visit to the Hear and Say Centre and to meet with mums and dads whose children are experiencing the benefits of this technology and who are actively being supported with speech and auditory therapy from the Hear and Say Centre. I look forward to seeing that centre go from strength to strength with the services it is providing to children.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.38 am): At the height of the global financial crisis our government established a jobs squad made up of industry, business, academia, social services, unions and public sector leaders. The task of the members of the jobs squad was to provide inside information on their own sectors of the economy and provide expert advice on how to protect jobs in the most difficult of circumstances. As the worst economic crisis the world had seen in nearly a century bore down on Queensland, our focus first and foremost was on protecting and creating jobs. We are not out of the woods yet, but we are seeing major signs of recovery and strong employment growth.

In many ways it is a sign of how far we have come in the past 12 months that we are now seeing a rapidly growing demand for skills in key industries such as the fledgling liquefied natural gas industry. Our government is committed to ensuring that Queenslanders have the skills they need to harness our state’s bright future for themselves and their families. That is why today I am pleased to provide further details of our announcement yesterday to create a new industry-led statutory authority to drive training, investment and skills reform in Queensland.

Skills Queensland will bring together industry leaders to direct government investment in skills and workforce development, and to advise of reform in the vocational educational and training system. This new body will develop vocational training and labour market programs and plan priorities for skilled migration into Queensland. It will provide training plans for emerging industries and effective responses to critical events such as the closure or downsizing of major employers. Skills Queensland will include industry leaders, plus the relevant directors-general from both the education and training and employment departments. An interim steering committee will be established to ensure that the new body can hit the decks running when it commences operations at the end of the year.

Our government believes that during periods of growth we should give Queenslanders every chance possible to take advantage of that opportunity. That means our vocational and training systems need to respond quickly to deliver skilled workers into the jobs that are needed. We also need to ensure Queensland is able to keep pace with the demands of a growing and changing economy. To do that we need a genuine partnership with industry. The creation of a new statutory authority, the Queensland Skills Commission, sends a clear signal to industry that they will have a greater say in the direction of skills development in Queensland. We are already seeing the benefits of that type of partnership. In March we announced a $10 million coal seam gas/liquefied natural gas industry training program, where industry will match the government’s contribution dollar-for-dollar to train workers in this new industry. By August this year, under this program, we will employ the first of approximately 2,500 trainees, who will begin a new career in our emerging LNG industry.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.40 am): Our government is committed to protecting and creating jobs. We have maintained our record capital building program, pledging $17.1 billion this year and supporting 106,000 jobs. However, our government recognises that we must also support industry to create the conditions needed to support continued job growth across our state. For that reason our budget delivers a raft of measures to help Queensland businesses, big and small, grow into the future. We have extended the 125 per cent payroll tax rebate for apprentices and trainees for another 12 months, at a cost of $8 million. That means Queensland still has the lowest payroll tax rate in the country. New South Wales, which made one of the centrepieces of its budget the reduction in payroll tax rates from 5.75 per cent to 5.45 per cent, still is nowhere near Queensland’s rate of 4.75 per cent.

In the next financial year, the government will continue to support Queensland businesses with programs that promote innovation, competitiveness and productivity. As I have just outlined, the new industry-led Queensland Skills Commission will drive training and skills reform. Skills Queensland will support industry investment and align training programs with real jobs, where the jobs are and where they are likely to grow. We recognised that improved productivity is a key driver of business success. That is why a new $2.5 million Innovation Vouchers Award program will help Queensland-based small to medium businesses improve their productivity. This pilot program will provide up to $50,000 for every eligible business for the use of new and innovative practices, such as the development of mandatory new machinery or the development of more sustainable workplaces. The pilot will provide businesses with redeemable vouchers that they can use to access research and expert advice to grow innovation in their companies.

In this financial year ongoing funding of $5.5 million to the Jobs Assist program will continue to provide an integrated package of support for businesses still feeling the impacts of the global financial crisis. This budget also delivers red tape reduction for our vital resources industry, with the provision of an additional $12.5 million over four years to deliver streamlined mineral and petroleum tenure approvals, and an extra $18 million over four years for a new mining exploration program to maximise Queensland’s exploration and resource potential, and continue to stimulate and attract investment. As well as all these measures, there is $7.5 million over four years to support economic development projects through the Queensland regional development initiative. This is used to assist regional development organisations focus on skills development and regional investment opportunities for businesses.

The budget sends a very clear message that Queensland is open for business and these initiatives are good examples of a government working with businesses to realise their full potential. I am very pleased that business groups have welcomed the state government’s allocation to some of these programs, particularly the infrastructure spending. Steve Greenwood from the Property Council of Australia says that the industry is positive about the budget. He says the sector will benefit from major infrastructure spending and stable property taxes. He states, ‘And that’s a very good thing for property investors and property owners.’ Paul Bidwell from the Master Builders Association says the spending will help struggling commercial builders. He states, ‘Every little bit helps.’ Chris Rodwell from the Australian Industry Group says the budget provides a strong platform for economic growth. He states, ‘It’s very significant indeed that we continue to have strong spending in infrastructure.’ The Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland has said it welcomes the government’s commitment to more responsible spending.
Government members: Hear, hear!
Ms BLIGH: Some days you just get lucky!

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.44 am): Finally, it gives me great pleasure to conclude my remarks today with some mention of the Arts budget this year. From the South Bank cultural precinct to our regional centres and beyond, Queensland has a vibrant and thriving arts scene. The Millennium Arts Project includes the Gallery of Modern Art, the new Queensland State Library, the Centre of Contemporary Art in Cairns, the Brolga Theatre in Maryborough and The Edge at the State Library, which are now built and going strong. Those infrastructure developments were put in place as part of our Millennium program, which started more than 10 years ago. The National Carriage Factory in Toowoomba is also near completion and will open towards the end of year.

Arts investment has increased by 68 per cent since this government came into office in 1998. This year the total investment in the sector is $232 million. We have come a long way in the past decade and now it is time to launch the next chapter of arts and cultural development in Queensland. Yesterday the Cairns cultural precinct took a giant step forward with the Queensland state government’s commitment of $40 million in state owned land for the project and our one-third share of the planning money requested by the Cairns City Council--
Honourable members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: The state government has provided $2.5 million towards detailed project planning.
Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: We know they are philistines on that side of the House. They never want to listen about the arts.
Mr SPEAKER: Just wait, Premier. We will wait for the chitchat to stop.

Ms BLIGH: I can advise the House that the people of Cairns are very enthusiastic about this project. The project was proposed by the Cairns business community and supported by the Cairns City Council, and a submission was put forward to the state and federal governments seeking one-third shares in what will be the most substantial cultural precinct anywhere in regional Australia. And where better than Cairns? It will breathe new life into the Cairns economy when it is needed most, it will add a major new attraction to the Cairns visitor experience, and it will be a showcase for Indigenous art and performance.

Over the next four years we will also see more than $12 million in new funding to ensure that the Queensland Art Gallery can keep delivering major exhibitions into the future. A further $1 million over the next two years will enable planning and design work on the major redevelopment of the Queensland Museum, which is the one state cultural institution that did not see a significant redevelopment as part of the Millennium project. The special role of Indigenous art is also recognised with a further $1.2 million over the next two years towards the Cairns Indigenous Art Fair, which promotes Indigenous art from all over Queensland. Regional arts infrastructure will also get a new $4 million boost over the next four years. This program will provide funds to regional art and cultural facilities for upgrades and to enable councils and others to plan, with the state government, for new infrastructure.

We all know that a thriving arts and cultural sector is an important part of liveability, whether you live in Cairns, Charleville or Brisbane. A dynamic Queensland arts sector also means jobs and a boost for local economies. It deserves to be supported and that is what we are doing in this year’s budget.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.49 am): The Bligh government is sticking to our strong economic plan of delivering more jobs, building infrastructure and investing in Queensland’s economic recovery. There is no portfolio that more starkly illustrates the benefits of the Bligh government’s strong economic plan than Health. Our infrastructure and jobs strategy means that we are building or rebuilding hospitals across Queensland, hiring 1,200 new clinical staff this coming year and increasing overall Health expenditure in the coming year to $9.99 billion. The reason we can afford this record investment in health services and infrastructure assets is that we have chosen an economic path that invests in a capital building program delivering in the areas government investment is needed most: hospitals, roads and schools--key government services and key public social infrastructure assets.

In the Health portfolio, the government’s strong economic strategy is delivering in spades. The Health budget will grow by 10.5 per cent on last year’s Health budget--well above the state’s 2.6 per cent population growth. Our massive $7.33 billion health infrastructure program--the largest ever undertaken in the nation’s history--is building and expanding hospitals and health services from the Torres to the Tweed and securing Queensland jobs. Queenslanders will not benefit from that vital social infrastructure unless we stick to our strong economic plan, and that is exactly what we are doing.

We are upgrading and expanding emergency departments at Logan, Redlands, QEII, Caboolture, Ipswich and Toowoomba, as well as a dedicated paediatric emergency department at Prince Charles. Major hospital infrastructure projects are already underway in Cairns, Townsville, Mackay, Mount Isa and Rockhampton, delivering more beds and expanded services for local communities. Nearly 200 projects across the state will secure close to 40,000 construction jobs over the life of the projects--half a billion dollars this year alone on the Gold Coast University Hospital. Each and every one of these jobs is a dividend of the government’s economic strategy that puts jobs first, and that would be put at risk by the cost-cutting, job-destroying policies of those opposite.
Interestingly, in the Sunshine Coast Daily today, AMA President Mason Stevenson said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It will be at least 18 months before we have one extra bed on the Sunshine Coast.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table that article. It is worth a good read.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of article, dated 9 June 2010, from Sunshine Coast Daily titled ‘No Tonic for Health’ [ 2379 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: In fact, the 96-bed, new ward at Nambour Hospital will open by the end of the year--which, last time I checked, was six months, not 18 months. That is another typically politically motivated comment from the AMA, that is in fact less critical of the LNP than Tony Abbott is.
Dr Douglas interjected.

Mr LUCAS: I welcome in the budget the funding to ramp up services on the Sunshine Coast--and that was due to the work of the clinicians, working with Queensland Health and me, not the politically motivated AMA. I take the interjection of the member for Noosa, who of course we would note has organised no extra commitment from the Leader of the Opposition for funding the Sunshine Coast University Hospital.
Mr ELMES: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I made no comment at all. I do not know who the Deputy Premier was referring to, but it was not me.
Mr SPEAKER: That is not a point of order.

Mr LUCAS: Of course he is embarrassed about it, because his leader made no further commitments. We went to the last election with a commitment to employ 3,500 extra doctors, nurses and allied health staff over three years. After only 18 months we are well ahead of target, with an additional 2,827 clinical staff employed since the last election. We are 80 per cent of the way towards our health jobs target less than halfway through the term. That is what our strong economic plan is delivering into our hospitals.

For the first time, the government will invest $8.5 million over four years for a mental health social marketing campaign to raise awareness and reduce the stigma associated with mental health issues. Remember those opposite? They had volunteers. Medical research has received a massive funding boost out of this budget. That is how much the Deputy Leader of the Opposition cares about people with mental illness. He stood by the member for Caloundra, and the member for Burnett said that the turning point in his relationship with the LNP in the last election campaign was when his mental health policy was volunteers delivering services.

There will be $31.2 million initial funding over four years to support the Queensland Institute of Medical Research and $1 million over four years to the Wesley Research Institute. For Queensland’s most vulnerable children, we will invest $16.5 million for children’s hearing services to increase the number of cochlear implants, boost early intervention and expand therapy services. Queensland will have the most comprehensive children’s hearing program in the nation. Mr Speaker, when you see those children’s faces light up and when you see what can be achieved, it makes even the greatest capital expenditure seem nothing in comparison.

The state budget will boost funding for cancer services in regional Queensland by $194.5 million operational and $179.3 million capital funding over four years, providing new and upgraded cancer centres throughout Queensland. That means 26 extra chemotherapy chairs, two additional linear accelerators and a positron emission tomography scanner at Townsville and enhanced tele-oncology and chemotherapy treatment services at Mount Isa. These are all the benefits of a strong economic plan delivering health services for Queensland.

Mr Speaker, you cannot invest record amounts in health services to benefit Queenslanders unless you stick to an economic plan. That is what the Bligh government is doing. The AMA nationally called for 3,700 beds to be built in Australia. We are delivering 1,700 in Queensland and $7 billion worth of infrastructure build. New South Wales is the closest, spending about $2 billion.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.55 am): Yesterday this government delivered a strong, sensible budget--one that will stand the test of time and one that puts us on a course to return to our AAA credit rating. It builds the recovery and it forecasts lower debt, lower deficits, stronger growth and more jobs. This is a budget that shows that our plans for reform and the plans we put in place last budget are delivering. We have charted a course to deliver our AAA credit rating and we have the discipline and the determination to stick to it.

Standard & Poor’s, the rating agency, acknowledged yesterday that our ‘steady-as-she goes budget will strengthen the state’s structural budgetary position’. S&P went on to say that ‘the rating remains on a stable outlook, an upgrade may be possible’ and said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In particular, if the proposed assets sales go ahead and the proceeds are used to retire debt--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: which is exactly our plan that we are putting in place--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: then Queensland’s net financial ratio could decline to around 110% of revenue--a level consistent with the 100-110% Standard & Poor’s identified as a possible trigger to reassess the rating.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: What does that mean? They say that our plan is working and that we need to stick to it, which is what we will do.
XML.Hansard-Body: An integral part of the plan for rebuilding the recovery will be the delivery of our huge $17.1 billion building program to support growth today and provide the infrastructure critical for our future productive capacity and future growth. What does business have to say about this? The Australian Industry Group gave it the tick. The Property Council gave the infrastructure spend the tick. The Transport and Tourism Forum of Australia gave the infrastructure spend the tick, with our commitment to improve public transport. Even the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Queensland said, ‘On balance, it’s a fair budget.’ They said that we were pursuing the right plan with our plan to put these commercial businesses to the market.

Isn’t the silence from the other side of the chamber all of a sudden entirely instructive? It is a silence, of course, that we know has been going on for about a year now. But we all wait because the countdown is on. Put the rocket ship on the launch pad--26 hours to go until all will be revealed. The Queensland Resources Council said that we were on the right track and endorsed the programs we put in place for the resources sector.

While this year’s budget will see the balance sheet strengthened, it will also lend a helping hand to Queenslanders who need it most. This budget delivers increases in electricity rebates for pensioners and seniors, to help our most vulnerable with the financial pressures through a $216 a year electricity rebate--something which the Queensland Council of Social Service has welcomed. The early childhood sector--C&K and Independent Schools Queensland--has welcomed our commitment to spend $60 million to bring forward the construction of 40 additional kindies by 2012.

The Wilderness Society and the World Wide Fund for Nature have both praised the introduction of our reforms to waste and the new commercial waste levy, as have business groups such as the Waste Contractors and Recyclers Association. The Local Government Association has also endorsed it and business groups like the Australian Industry Group say that we have got the settings right and have praised our determination to work with industry over the next 12 months.

This is a budget which focuses on what Queensland needs for the future. It is a budget that reflects the strategy we put in place. It reports on the recovery we are building and shows that we are on track, with a plan, to return to surplus, to regain the AAA credit rating, to deliver a net new 100,000 jobs--just as we said we would.

Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (9.58 am): Yesterday I was pleased to detail jobs in many infrastructure projects in which Public Works is involved. Yesterday’s budget reinforced that message and committed funding to continue the Capital Works Program. This government’s massive building program is delivering infrastructure and jobs. We can do this because we have an economic plan and we are sticking to it. We said we would protect our capital works budget and we have.

Public Works continues to manage huge projects, such as hospitals, schools, courts and correctional centres, on behalf of other government agencies. On top of that, Public Works also manages a host of its own major projects. These include the $47.6 million six-star green-star rated Joint Contact Centre at Zillmere. The centre will be shared by Smart Service Queensland and Queensland police. In total, nearly 360 jobs are being provided on that project. In Cairns, work continues on the $79.5 William McCormack Place stage 2 government office building, supporting approximately 600 jobs over the duration of the project. Nearby in Mareeba, $6.5 million has been allocated for a government office building and learning centre, providing an estimated 34 full-time equivalent positions. Further north, the $13.5 million government office building being constructed on Thursday Island is creating approximately 90 jobs.

On the Sunshine Coast, the $79.9 million Maroochydore office building is taking shape. The project will generate an estimated 600 jobs in total. If yesterday’s budget did not commit to those projects, what would we see happen? Those cranes would come down and those workers would lose their jobs, and that would have happened if those opposite had won the last election.

In Brisbane, the site infrastructure works to create a platform for the Boggo Road Urban Village are due to be completed in late 2010. This $45.5 million project will support 350 full-time equivalent jobs during construction. As an integral part of the new Boggo Road Urban Village, the $378 million Ecosciences Precinct, which includes an $88 million contribution from CSIRO, will be completed ahead of program in late 2010 and will create over 2,900 jobs. Yesterday the Treasurer also signalled a commencement of the $450 million Queensland Police Service training academy by providing $50 million to allow for the planning to start to get this project to the market so that it is completed by 2014-15, which will also create 3,500 jobs.

Finally, I want to congratulate the mighty Goprint for again producing an accurate, timely and secure set of budget papers for this year’s budget. Goprint staff worked well beyond the call of duty to deliver on time and with the usual high quality--as they have done for over a century. I congratulate all those workers at Goprint who worked through the night to make sure that these documents were on our desks yesterday in a timely and accurate fashion.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (10.02 am): Our government has a plan to turn Queensland into the solar state. It is a plan that will build a new green industry to create green jobs for Queenslanders. It is a plan that will allow us to reduce our carbon footprint and lessen our impact on the environment. It is a plan to move toward a renewable energy future for our state.

We have a plan for a solar future, and yesterday’s budget means we can make that plan a reality by delivering $115 million worth of solar initiatives over the next five years. This is the largest single funding commitment for solar deployment in Queensland’s history, demonstrating our government’s determination to move towards a renewable energy future. We are moving towards that future with initiatives like CS Energy’s carbon reduction program. We have provided $35.4 million towards the program to help support the development of major renewable energy projects like the solar boost project at Kogan Creek. Our commitment of more than $35 million for CS Energy, together with $31 million from the federal government for this project, means Queensland will be home to the largest solar project in the Southern Hemisphere. It is projects like those being developed by CS Energy that will see Queensland’s reputation as a solar hub continue to grow. As the projects grow, so too will the industry and the green jobs that come with it.

Our plan is not just about the solar industry; it is a plan that involves every Queensland household. Indeed, this year’s budget ensures all Queenslanders can do the bright thing and switch to solar, with initiatives like the $60 million solar rebate scheme which is providing residents with rebates of $600 and $1,000 for the installation of solar hot-water systems and solar heat pumps. It is not only Queensland homes that we are targeting. The budget also includes $5.8 million for a new Solar Kindergartens Program. This funding will go towards the installation of solar PV panels on the roofs of new and existing kindergarten buildings built or upgraded over the next four years. This means our kindies will be able to be more energy efficient and the next generation of Queenslanders will have the chance to learn about the benefits of renewable energy and take those messages home.

Our government has a plan to double our state’s solar energy capacity over the next five years. This year’s budget will see us continue to deliver on that plan, and the people of Queensland will reap the benefits.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.04 am): Queensland children state-wide will be able to access extra kindergarten services under a plan by the Bligh government to fast-track 40 new state-wide services. The 40 extra services come on top of the locations of 68 extra kindy services that are already planned to open by the end of 2012. The bring-forward cost of the 40 new services will be $60 million. This is in stark contrast to the last state election, when the LNP policy was to completely cut the spending on new Queensland kindergartens. We are investing $321 million to make this happen and we are building state-of-the-art facilities for Queensland children to enjoy a flying start to learning and life. This comes on top of $10 million being spent on new school infrastructure every day in Queensland by the state and the federal governments.

We know where those on the other side of the chamber stand on new infrastructure in Queensland schools. They stand divided. On the one hand, they make a public call for the freezing of new infrastructure in Queensland schools, yet when it comes to their own backyards they want more spending on schools and they do not care whether it is state or federally funded. The divide does not stop there.

The South-East Queensland corner Liberals say we need to stop spending in regional Queensland because it costs more, while the regional National Party members want more spending in their schools. The member for Moggill, for example, claims that just because you live in a remote part of Queensland you do not deserve new infrastructure because it costs more. The member for Currumbin claims we should pre-empt the outcomes of consultations with regional communities and just cancel any new buildings. Meanwhile, the member for Hinchinbrook is committed to keeping one of his local schools open and supporting BER buildings in his electorate.

The Bligh government wants to keep all small schools sustainable. We want all students to have a flying start in education. That is exactly what we are going to do with the record education expenditure in this budget.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.07 am): The Bligh government is tackling congestion on busy roads with sensible, workable solutions. We have just doubled the number of roadside traffic cameras in South-East Queensland. It is a win for motorists, with 50 new web cameras rolled out across the region. The cameras stream live vision to the traffic website, alerting motorists to potential hazards, traffic snarls and delays. Our new web cams will save time for people who lead busy lives. People will be able to click onto the website, work out where the trouble spots are and plan their journey. We are installing the new cameras in more than 50 busy roadside locations on the Sunshine Coast, in Brisbane and on the Gold Coast. The sites have been carefully chosen. They are places prone to congestion and traffic build-up. Next month, we will have 100 web cams up and running.

The Bligh government is serious about tackling congestion and making life better for motorists. We have made tough choices as a government and they were the right choices. That is why we are able to deliver a first-class road network for Queenslanders. The $315 million duplication of the Houghton Highway will go a long way towards slashing travel times on both bridges. I look forward to joining my colleague, the member for Sandgate, in some fishing on that bridge as we inspect that new fishing platform. The new Sir Leo Hielscher Bridge, part of the $2.5 billion Gateway corridor, means motorists will have six lanes all the way from Nudgee to Nerang--and six months ahead of schedule. The $1.95 billion Ipswich Motorway upgrade from Dinmore to Goodna includes six lanes, with room to expand to eight in the future. That is what I call planning for growth. We have almost $1 billion to upgrade the Pacific Motorway between the Gateway and Tugun to give motorists a smoother, swifter and more seamless run.
The Bligh government is tackling congestion and slashing travel times by building bigger and better roads right across our great state. We are at action stations, unlike the opposition.
Mr Johnson: Not in the west you haven’t.

Mr WALLACE: I take the honourable member’s interjection. I thank him for his support in the newspapers today for the funding for local roads in his area. I thank the member for Gregory for that. Unlike the opposition, while we work they whinge. They are over there whingeing. Whilst we are getting on with the job of laying tar and bitumen across Queensland they are too busy laying tar and feathers on each other.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport) (10.09 am): Yesterday’s record Transport budget of $7 billion--the third highest portfolio spend in the Bligh government--secures jobs, ensures sustainable growth and helps lay the foundations for an economic recovery. The budget provides: an extra $179 million for trains, buses and ferries; the fast-tracking of the Springfield railway line at a cost of $646 million; $35 million for the duplication of the railway line from Keperra to Ferny Grove, including a major railway station redevelopment at Ferny Grove; $61 million for cycling infrastructure; $197 million to continue constructing the Northern Busway from Enoggera Creek to Kedron; and $150 million to extend the Eastern Busway from Buranda to Main Avenue at Coorparoo.

The Bligh government is also about to undertake the biggest upgrade of train stations in South-East Queensland since services began in the 1860s. As announced in yesterday’s budget, $200 million will be spent in the coming financial year to spruce up around 50 railway stations. Renovations at stations will range from major works such as new lifts, escalators and expanded car parks to basic revamps like new toilets, fresh paint and new seating. Another great feature of this program will be the installation of LCD screens at a number of stations. The screens will provide commuters with real-time service information, including countdowns to arrivals and departures, details about special events and other important information for train travellers.

From this year Queensland Rail will be a designated passenger carrier and Queensland commuters will see better customer service as a result. The rail station renovation will be the biggest clean-up blitz ever seen on the Citytrain network. It will take us from the steam age to gleam age. The renovated stations are used by 90 per cent of daily passengers, meaning that most commuters will benefit from the upgraded facilities as part of their daily rail commute. Almost a third of stations will receive some form of upgrade, with work to be prioritised over the coming weeks.
When TransLink was established in 2004 its budget was $600 million. Today that budget has doubled--
Mr Johnson: Are you going to keep the cattle trains going so you can keep people employed?
Ms NOLAN: I note that what the LNP are interested in is not better public transport for hundreds of thousands of commuters; it is cattle trains in Western Queensland.

When TransLink was established in 2004 its budget was $600 million. Today, that budget for TransLink has more than doubled, to $1.38 billion, to continue to expand public transport on the South-East Queensland network. This record level of funding demonstrates that the government is committed to public transport by providing enhanced services and infrastructure. I think the LNP demonstrate for themselves what they are interested in.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.13 am): The Bligh government has a plan for a safe and secure Queensland, and the 2010-11 state budget handed down by the Treasurer yesterday demonstrates that we are sticking to that plan. In my portfolio that means a massive $1.8 billion allocation for the Queensland Police Service. This record budget allocation--an increase of $110 million on last year--is made possible because the government has taken the tough decisions to ensure front-line service delivery is not compromised.

We said that we would deliver an additional 600 police during this term. This year’s police budget is another step in that commitment with funding for an extra 203 police positions this year, joining the more than 10,000 sworn officers already on the beat. These officers are doing a great job, with the overall rate of crime down 26 per cent between 2000-01 and 2008-09.

The Bligh government is determined to keep that trend going. That is why we are getting more officers on the beat proactively working to reduce crime and investigate crimes when they do occur. The government is also planning for the future. We have allocated $50 million towards the ongoing development of the new Queensland Police Academy at Wacol. This funding will assist the Police Service in having this facility operational by 2015, providing a modern facility from which the next generation of police officers will be trained.

This budget also delivers funding for the new Badu Island Police Station, Oxley district forensic facility and district support facility in Townsville, as well as the Murgon Police Station and watchhouse, Camp Hill Police Station--being built at Carina--Lockhart River Police Station and the Sunshine Coast district water police facility. More than $50 million will be invested in the latest information and communication technology to support front-line police officers. This includes investing in a new weapons licensing system, a new computer aided dispatch system, a digital integrated traffic camera system and a permanent telecommunications interception capability.

Contrary to media reports today, the budget also includes funding for the continuation of the One Punch Can Kill campaign. The government previously announced a $700,000 commitment, to be spent over two years, for this campaign. This budget demonstrates that the Bligh government is sticking to its plan of having a well-funded and well-resourced police service for Queensland.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.15 am): This week new acoustic alarms or pingers, which alert whales to the location of shark nets, will be trialled on the Gold Coast. With 13,000 whales expected to pass along the Queensland coast this whale migration season, the Bligh government is committed to minimising the impacts of its Shark Control Program on non-target species such as whales.

The new pingers have a longer and louder noise specially aimed at alerting whales to the location of shark nets. The new pingers will complement existing dolphin pingers, which have been installed on shark nets since 1996. Last whale migration season, six whales were entangled in Queensland shark nets. All were successfully released by the state government’s Marine Animal Release Team. That is a relatively small number, considering there are up to 13,000 whales migrating back to southern waters, but it is still six too many.

A number of pinger prototypes have been designed and will be fitted to Gold Coast shark nets this week to test their durability in the ocean environment. The alarms have been developed by a Queensland based specialist acoustic device manufacturer and give off a louder noise for a longer listening period, making it easier for whales to hear. It is important to recognise that these alarms are designed to alert whales to the presence of nets; they are not designed to scare them away from the equipment.

In total, we will have 90 pingers in the water at any one time. That is three on each Queensland shark net from Mackay to the Gold Coast. The aim is to have pingers on all nets by August. This will be in time for the second half of the whale season, when young whales are more likely to come closer to shore and become entangled. After that, pingers will be fitted to the nets from 1 May to 30 November each year. The public are strongly encouraged to report any whale entanglements by calling the shark control hotline on 1800806891.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.18 am): The Bligh government believes in the delivery of infrastructure and jobs for Queensland. That is why we made a plan and stuck to it. This year’s budget funds a $17.1 billion Capital Works Program that supports 106,000 jobs--the highest infrastructure spend in Australia for the 10th year running. In the last 10 years this funding has provided busways for Brisbane, the return--I repeat, the return--of rail to the Gold Coast, the upgrade of air and sea ports in Gladstone, Townsville, Cairns and the Mackay region as well as numerous health and hospital upgrades.

For my portfolio this budget means more than $486 million in capital spending over the next 12 months to continue an ambitious infrastructure and planning program to provide jobs. I am pleased to report that funding for the remaining South-East Queensland water grid projects will top $315 million in 2010-11. That is $202 million for the Northern Pipeline Interconnector stage 2 and $105 million for the Wyaralong Dam, among other projects, to provide water security for South-East Queensland’s two million residents.

These projects will also continue to provide jobs, wherever possible sourcing local workers and businesses. The Northern Pipeline Interconnector stage 2, the second stage of the reverse cycle pipeline to link the Sunshine Coast to the South-East Queensland water grid, has already generated a total of 416 jobs and a local spend of more than $13 million. A total workforce of 650, with up to 60 per cent to be hired locally, is forecast to be reached in August 2010 on the $440.4 million project between Landers Point and Noosa. The $348 million Wyaralong Dam, which in conjunction with the Cedar Grove Weir will deliver enough water for 300,000 people each year, will generate a total of 420 jobs in the delivery of that project. The project is currently employing an estimated 370 direct workers and subcontractors, with more than 50 per cent from the local area.

The Wyaralong Dam project has also sourced goods and services from more than 400 businesses, with about 45 per cent from the local area. Wyaralong Dam is also helping break the unemployment cycle and aiding the environment, with a total of 61 Green Army recruits involved in the project. So far, 36 of those involved in the green traineeships have gained local employment following graduation. The next work placement, which starts on 21 June, will see 10 participants at work on the construction of recreation trails around the dam. These important projects are further evidence of the Bligh government’s plan to provide infrastructure and generate jobs. We will continue to deliver water security and infrastructure through the nation’s biggest building program at $17.1 billion, protecting 106,000 Queensland jobs.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Acting Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.21 am): The Lord Mayor has reportedly expressed concerns about a medical waste disposal facility operating at Willawong in Brisbane’s west. Specifically, he has raised concerns about the facility known as Ace Waste being located in proximity to some residences. I wish to respond to media reports today to address the Lord Mayor’s comments and provide a clearer picture of the issue being dealt with at a state and local level. Ace Waste has been operating at Willawong since 1993. It is the only facility in South-East Queensland capable of disposing of certain types of medical waste that are required by law to be incinerated. Brisbane City Council has been examining planning options for expanded residential development to cater for population growth in the wider Oxley Wedge area for a number of years. However, it was only recently that the Department of Environment and Resource Management became aware that council had proposed a large residential development for a parcel of land adjacent to the Ace Waste facility. Council sought advice from DERM on its proposed Paradise Wetlands neighbourhood plan.

Let me be very clear: council had wanted higher density development in close proximity to a medical waste facility--indeed, within 300 metres of the facility. This is a lot closer than the nearest households, which are about 800 metres away. The state government has said no way. This year DERM informed council that it believed the proximity of 300 metres was insufficient. DERM encouraged council to consider a Draft State Planning Policy for Air, Noise and Hazardous Materials which recommended a distance of 1,000 metres away from areas that contain facilities such as Ace Waste for future developments. This facility is located away from higher density residential areas with established buffer distances and suitable conditions on its operations.

Let me be absolutely clear that the facility is operating within its development approval conditions and Queensland Health has advised it does not consider there to be any current health risks to the nearest residents. However, sensible planning dictates that residences should not be encroaching on the facility’s surrounding areas. In response to DERM’s advice, the council commissioned SIMTARS, an arm of the Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation, to undertake an air study to evaluate health risks and advise on separation distances. SIMTARS acts as an independent consultant with a world-class reputation of assessing, researching and testing health and safety risks of industry.

The council commissioned study has three stages. The first stage involving theoretical modelling of emissions has now been completed. The model, using average emissions for Ace Waste and the landfill flare, revealed that levels of modelled contaminants were within national guidelines at existing residences. It also indicated that nearby workplaces were not at risk of harm. But to establish more than adequate separation distances for future residential planning, an additional worst-case scenario model was run, and this was the subject of media reports today. This model was purposely very conservative, assuming the facility operated 100 per cent of the time at peak operational levels. It was intended to overestimate the impacts of Ace Waste’s emissions and exaggerate the potential effects to identify the features of such a worst-case scenario. It is important to note that this modelling has never and will never be based on the facility’s actual operations.

Council and the state government both agree that the investigations are incomplete and further study is required to determine the actual risks. Stages 2 and 3 will provide this information. DERM is committed to continuing to assist the council commissioned investigations and will work with council to keep the community fully informed of progress. This case, above all else, is an effective demonstration of DERM acting as an environmental regulator. DERM stepped in to prevent what it saw as inappropriate planning. This case highlights the very real reasons why a State Planning Policy for Air, Noise and Hazardous Materials is so important--to guide councils on appropriate buffers between industry and households. DERM takes its responsibilities as an environmental regulator very seriously and takes action against all breaches of environmental conditions and legislation. DERM will continue to work with both Ace Waste to ensure its continued compliance with its environmental conditions and the Brisbane City Council to ensure that residential development maintains suitable separation from this facility.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.25 am): Tomorrow I will be introducing legislation into the House to make changes to the Child Protection Act which will facilitate the Helping Out Families initiative, announced yesterday by the Minister for Community Services and myself. Personally, I cannot think of anything more precious than a newborn baby. At such a wonderful yet vulnerable stage, there is no more important bond than between mother and child. That is why the Bligh government has made the tough decisions and stuck to its economic plan to ensure that this year’s operating budget of $695.9 million for child protection focuses squarely on keeping our children safe. I am proud to announce $55 million in funding to be allocated over the next four years to the new Helping Out Families initiative, an early intervention and prevention pilot to be run in Logan and Beenleigh from October this year and the Gold Coast from early next year.

I spoke of the important and vital bond between mother and child, and that is why the Helping Out Families pilot will ensure every mother with a newborn child will receive up to six visits from a registered nurse within the first three years of the child’s life. This will ensure that mums and dads are getting the sort of help they need during such a life-changing time. The initiative also includes further assistance, with a provision for families requiring more intensive help to be offered an additional 15 visits over a 12-month period. The focus of the visits will be to enhance the confidence and capacity of parents and carers in their parenting role. They will help with information about immunisation, preventing injuries, promoting reading for future literacy skills, safe sleeping and encouraging breastfeeding and optimum infant nutrition.

Also included in the Helping Out Families initiative is the formation of the Family Support Alliance, an early intervention and prevention support network which will receive referrals from Child Safety and then assess and support families with children of any age with the relevant services they might require. Also incorporated in the Helping Out Families initiative are the 11 new Indigenous family support services being established for Indigenous families across the state. These will receive funding of $8.5 million per year on top of the $55 million four-year pilot. This government has stuck to its economic plan and made the tough economic decisions to ensure the safety and future of our children.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (10.29 am): The opposition is provided by this parliament with a budget to conduct its operations. That budget is expended in accordance with the guidelines contained in the opposition handbook and supervised by the Ministerial Services Branch of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. MSB was established as a recommendation of the Fitzgerald inquiry to provide independent oversight and control of expenditure incurred by ministerial officers and, by extension, the opposition. Ministerial officers and the opposition operate under guidelines based on similar principles, with all expenditures, of course, being audited by the independent Auditor-General.

The opposition handbook contains detailed guidelines relating to expenditures by the opposition on advertising. Those guidelines had traditionally been applied by the officers of MSB, who independently certify in advance, without informing the government of the day, that the advertisement complies with the guidelines. This system has worked successfully for many years, with the opposition office being prepared to change proposed advertisements in order to comply with the guidelines.

A couple of months ago this system was subject to change when the Director-General of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet, Mr Ken Smith--a person with whom the Premier has a personal contract of employment--unilaterally asserted the right to personally approve all opposition advertisements in lieu of the role of the supposedly independent public servants of MSB. Following vigorous discussions between Mr Smith and the opposition office, Mr Smith, who did not personally agree with the decisions of his officers, chose to refer to the Integrity Commissioner. Dr Solomon, the Integrity Commissioner, has indicated that he proposes to consult extensively in relation to his review, which will take several months. I am in the process of writing to Dr Solomon to suggest that any such review should also address advertising by governments as well as oppositions.
Yesterday, as part of the opposition’s strategy of response to the government’s budget, my office sought to place an advertisement in the Courier-Mail .
Mr Lucas: At taxpayers’ expense.

Mr LANGBROEK: Just as the government places advertising at their expense. A draft of the advertisement was forwarded to MSB at 7.42 am. Notwithstanding reminders of approaching deadlines, it was not until 12.13 pm that Mr Ken Smith responded, raising a number of concerns. Those concerns were addressed in a response at 2.05 pm. Because of failure to identify what changes to the proposed advertisement would be needed to satisfy the director-general’s concerns, a decision was made to place a different advertisement that was previously placed two years ago. This is an advertisement that has previously been approved by the department, paid for from the opposition budget, not the subject of an adverse comment by the Auditor-General and praised by the Premier in parliament on 4 June 2008. The only change was updating the relevant figures to accord with the current position and the removal of a reference to a defunct website. The director-general was advised of this at 5.46 pm. At 6.21 pm the director-general advised--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I have clearly stated that no advertising should proceed pending the outcome of the review by the Integrity Commissioner.
XML.Hansard-Body: This raises a fundamental principle of democracy in this state. This is an issue of not only a government censoring an opposition’s budget reply but also the ethics of an opposition having to seek prior approval from the Premier’s directly appointed department head. It is reminiscent of the most corrupt of administrations. Here we have the personal political appointment of the Premier of Queensland telling the opposition that it cannot utilise funds provided by the parliament to engage in advertising pending the conclusion of a review lasting several months by the Integrity Commissioner. There is no suggestion, of course, that the government will be subject to any similar ban by the director-general.

This is partisan political behaviour by the director-general that arguably amounts to official misconduct within the terms of the Crime and Misconduct Act. Accordingly, I advise the House that I will be writing to the chairman of the CMC requesting the launching of an urgent inquiry into this political abuse. In addition, Mr Speaker, I will be providing you with copies of all relevant material in order that you might consider what action should be taken to ensure that the privileges of an essential element of our democratic government--namely, the opposition and its capacity to effectively challenge and oppose government actions--are not inhibited by the partisan behaviour of the government’s public servants.
Mr SPEAKER: I would ask the honourable gentleman to place that in writing to me.

2. any prior warnings of potential failures of the new computerised payroll system;

4. the anticipated timeframe upon which it is expected a fully operational payroll system will be operational.

Mr LANGBROEK: The minister cannot sort it out so we might as well get someone else to do it.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.35 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to reports that the first likely major industry decision following yesterday’s state budget is the cancellation by Chalco of its refinery project in Bowen, which the government said would generate 3,600 jobs, and I ask: when will the Premier tell the Prime Minister, Kevin Rudd, that she will not be his party president but instead will do her job as Premier of Queensland and stand up for the thousands of jobs that are being put on the scrap heap because of Labor’s new super tax on mining?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. Let me say a couple things. Firstly, there is nothing in the state budget yesterday that relates in any way to deliberations by Chalco about the viability of its project. Secondly, when we took this project to international tender we had a number of stipulations, but the most important was that the winning bidder would have to not only be able to exploit the resource productively but also have a refinery that would see value adding and more jobs in Queensland as a result of us opening up that project. So what Chalco has to get over the line is not only a bauxite mine but also a refinery on the eastern coast of Queensland. It is a tough project to get up--it always was--and I look forward to it getting up. But I will say this clearly: Chalco was awarded this project on the basis of secondary manufacturing of this product in Queensland and it will be subject to the firmest possible view by this government that it will only get access to the bauxite mine if it can deliver what it said it would deliver, as any other international tenderer would have been required to do.

Let us just remember, shall we, where this bauxite deposit comes from. This was put to the international market. Why? Because the National Party and those opposite were part of a government that gave it away, said they could only hold the lease if it was developed within a certain period of time and then never, ever held the French company to account on that. So it held up that resource, which belongs to Queenslanders, and the company held it for 35 years without a single job, without any resource activity on the lease. What did this government do? We said to the company, ‘Too bad, you have not met your requirements. This belongs to Queenslanders and we are going to make sure there is an international company that wants to actually create jobs here.’

We want to see this project developed and we are working hard with the company to do just that. In fact, we have put on the table, as we have made public in the past, funds for common user infrastructure to assist. But what we will not do is walk away from the requirement that whoever exploits that bauxite will be required to do secondary processing at another facility. We will not simply see it put on ships and taken elsewhere for those manufacturing jobs to be gained in other countries.

If that is the policy of the Leader of the Opposition then he needs to tell the people of Bowen, who probably stand the best chance of getting that refinery. He needs to stand up and say that under his government, should he ever be lucky enough to get here, they will take the bauxite and send it offshore and there will be no secondary processing jobs.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Treasurer. Over the next year the interest on government debt will more than exceed the $1.2 billion in extra royalty revenue coming from what commentators are calling ‘mining boom mark 2’, and I ask: why is this reckless government spending the proceeds of the boom before the boom arrives?

Mr FRASER: I thank the Leader of the Opposition for the question. He clearly participated in a different budget speech yesterday and has read a whole set of newspapers this morning from a different planet and a different state. What we put in place yesterday was a budget that observed a strict fiscal discipline. In the charter of fiscal rules that is contained in the budget papers yesterday, what did the budget papers show? They showed that that fiscal discipline was in place, that the expenditure constraint was below the level of population growth and inflation last year. We met the zero net real per capita growth on expenditure constraint. What is the evidence of that? Well, the deficit not only for the coming year but across the forward estimates is more than halved as we allow the revenue that is coming back from the recovery that we are authoring, the recovery that we are building, the recovery that we are putting in place, to go through to the bottom line.

What are we doing with the proceeds from the economy picking up? We are sticking by the rules we put in place. We are flowing that through to the bottom line of the budget, halving the deficits across the forward estimates as we build a sustainable recovery. What the budget yesterday shows is that the plan that we put in place, the discipline that we put in place, is flowing through to the bottom line. It stands in stark contrast to the contribution from the Liberal and National parties in this state during the term of this parliament.

We are now within 25 hours of the time at which the Leader of the Opposition is proposing to finally give us an inclination about what his policy is, what policy he will pursue, what choices he will make, what programs he will cut, what efficiency dividend he will put in place that will slaughter 12,000 jobs out of the public sector and attack the front-line services that a growing population and a growing state needs.

One year on from the original promise, we are now inside the last day for seeing what the Leader of the Opposition is going to propose. What the people of Queensland deserve tomorrow is not a budget whinge in reply; what they deserve is a budget in reply that proposes an alternative, that puts forward a plan. We have a plan. It is put in place. It is working. It is delivering lower deficits. It is delivering lower debt. It is delivering higher growth. It is delivering more jobs. There has been nine months in a row of job generation because we put that first and foremost in what we said we would do. The budget handed down yesterday puts that plan in place, shows that it is delivering and delivering for Queenslanders.

What are we intent on doing here? We are intent on sticking to a plan that will build a stronger future for Queensland, that will return the budget to surplus, that the ratings agency says will put us on track to getting our AAA credit rating back, a plan that we said we would carry out, a budget in place that is delivering. That is what this side of the parliament has offered. What will the other side of the parliament offer tomorrow?
Ms DARLING: My question is for the Premier. Can the Premier advise the House of any issues arising from the use of public funds by the opposition for advertising?

Ms BLIGH: The Queensland opposition is provided with a budget and it is entitled to use some of those funds for public advertising. I am having this checked, but I am not aware of that being a right or an entitlement in any other state in Australia. Frankly, I think that, when they see those full-page ads in the paper, members of the public would be very surprised to know that in fact they are paying for that political advertising by the opposition.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: As I said, I think that members of the Queensland public would be very surprised to know that those full-page ads are actually being paid for by the public of Queensland. The guidelines on this are very clear. What those guidelines make clear, firstly, is that such ads, in order to be eligible for public financing, should not be or should not be perceived to be party political in nature and they should not have excessive reference to photographs of the leader. I think the Leader of the Opposition learnt that lesson last year. Importantly, they are available to promote the policy of the alternative government.

There have been a number of ads in the last six months, and many of the people in this House would have seen them, which have been funded at public expense which do not meet those guidelines. They are, by any reasonable assessment, party political in nature. More concerning, none of them promote the alternative policies of the Leader of the Opposition or his party.

I have heard some outrageous claims by those opposite this morning about my director-general. Let me make this very clear: under the Financial Accountability Act of this parliament the director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet is the accountable officer--no ifs, no buts. The public expenditure being made by the Ministerial Services Branch on behalf of the LNP is subject to scrutiny by the accountable officer, the director-general of the Department of the Premier and Cabinet. Given growing concern about the increasingly party political nature of these ads--and I think they are getting increasingly hard to justify to the public--the director-general, after discussions--
Mr Springborg: Oh, you think!

Ms BLIGH: I am entitled to a view on this, as every other Queenslander is, and I challenge the Leader of the Opposition to walk down the street with his ads and ask members of the Queensland public whether they ought to be paying for them. This is the subject of assessment by the Integrity Commissioner because I think the guidelines do need to be clear in fairness to the opposition, in fairness to the public purse. I think ongoing arguments about it from staff from the Leader of the Opposition’s office are not helpful. The Leader of the Opposition’s office was advised in writing yesterday that, given that the Integrity Commissioner is now reviewing this matter, further ads will not be approved. He chose to put the ad in anyway. I think it is important that this is clarified.
As I said, this is the best resourced opposition in the country. No other opposition gets publicly funded political ads. The Integrity Commissioner will provide some assistance with this.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Treasurer. This morning the Treasurer referred to the Moody’s report on the budget. The Treasurer failed to say--and I quote from the report from Moody’s in relation to the reinstatement of the AAA credit rating--that Moody’s will monitor the introduction of a new resource rents tax as part of the national reform proposal and new healthcare funding arrangements which will be considered as a part of its deliberations on the reinstatement of the state’s AAA credit rating. Does the Treasurer agree that the mining super tax will affect Queensland’s ability to recover the AAA credit rating that he and Labor lost?

Mr FRASER: I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition for the question. Here we go! We have the first insight into what tomorrow’s opposition budget reply will be about. Because they are so devoid of any capacity to talk about policies at a state level, tomorrow they will spend about 25 minutes talking about a federal tax proposal, constructed in front of them, to avoid the fact that they will not be able to go the distance talking about state policies. It will be a short episode. It will be a short little interlude on matters relating to the state, because it will be all about the federal resource super profits tax.

The reality is that at three separate places in Budget Paper No. 2, the strategy and outlook document--at pages 42, 88 and 142 from memory--it talks about the resource super profits tax. The point that is being constructed by those opposite is that somehow the budget documents are deficient for not factoring in a resource super profits tax that has not been legislated, that is not in place and that is still under determination.

I wonder what they would think of an excerpt from the WA budget papers. Last time I checked, a Liberal government was in office in WA. What does it say? I would like to quote from the Western Australian budget papers, because on this front we have matched that government’s achievement. What has it said? The WA budget papers state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Given the timing of the release and the current uncertainty around the final form of the proposed RSPT-based package (and its possible impact on Western Australia), the economic forecasts presented in this budget exclude any potential impacts from an RSPT.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those opposite should get on the phone to Colin Barnett and their Liberal mates in Western Australia and tell them that they are a bunch of duds. If they do not do that, the reality of the situation is revealed.

We will make sure that we do the hard yards to get this policy right, and that is what we have said from day one. We believe that the regime that has been put in place can work for investment in jobs, but does it work at this point? No, it does not. What will we do? We will continue to do what this side of the House does, which is to roll up our sleeves, do the policy hard yards, make sure that we work with the federal government and industry to get the taxation right so that Australians and Queenslanders get their fair share. That is what we have been determined to do from day one.

What have members opposite been determined to do? They have been determined to lie in the hammock, to play solitaire, to not talk about any alternative proposals, to preside over a party that is falling apart. That party was only ever a sham marriage. It was only ever a cobbling together of disparate and arguing forces and it is being revealed for what it has always been: a total and utter fraud.

Ms O’NEILL: My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier outline what the government’s $15 million solar package will mean for Queensland and the government’s aim to double our use of solar energy over the next five years?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for her question. I know that she has a keen interest in renewable energy, as does the entire Labor government. We are committed to growing our use of renewable energy, including in the solar area. I am very pleased to advise the House that the Minister for Mines and Energy has given an outline of the extra money that we will be putting into this year’s budget to grow the solar industry in Queensland. One of the centrepieces of that allocation is $35 million to CS Energy, in conjunction with a $31 million allocation from the federal government, to build a thermal solar booster plant at CS Energy’s Kogan Creek Power Station, which is a large coal fired power station. That solar thermal boost will increase the station’s capacity by 44 megawatts and significantly reduce its carbon emissions. It is important to understand that this will be the largest solar thermal power station in Australia. Indeed, it will be the largest solar thermal power station in the Southern Hemisphere and one of the largest in the world. Queensland’s claim to be the solar state of Australia is well and truly on track.

I congratulate CS Energy for working with the company Areva. Areva has some of the most advanced solar thermal energy technology in the world. This will be the largest deployment of it anywhere in the world. At Kogan Creek in the south-west of our state, in an area that is emerging as a significant energy corridor for Queensland, we will not only see significant new energy supplies from gas fired power and from clean coal fired power, such as the very high-tech Kogan Creek plant, but we will also see a very significant addition to our solar power efforts. We are committed to doubling our use of solar power within five years, and having this as part of our program will certainly help meet that. This is equivalent to over 38,000 solar hot-water systems and the project will create 120 jobs in its construction phase.

This program will join our budget commitment for this year of $5.8 million for solar kindies and our other programs such as the solar schools and hot water rebate programs. This all adds up to mean that whether it is in the home, in community organisations, in businesses or in large institutions, we are seeing solar power drive Queensland. Kogan Creek is the next development in that commitment. It will be the biggest solar thermal power station in the Southern Hemisphere and where is it? Here in Queensland!
Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer, who sent Queensland broke in a boom.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I would ask the honourable member to come to his question.

Mr NICHOLLS: Treasurer, despite receiving increased royalties, increased Commonwealth grants, increased GST and increased taxes, the best this government can do to help Queenslanders is a miserly 6c a day cut to CTP insurance that does not cost it a cent. Isn’t the CTP cut simply a cruel hoax, given that the cut is entirely consumed by the CPI increase in vehicle registration for most family cars?

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for his question--the shadow Treasurer who has occupied that space for two years and has not produced a single economic policy. Let us recentre this debate for a moment. Imagine if this government yesterday announced a $24 increase to the compulsory third party insurance regime. Imagine the crocodile tears from the toff from Clayfield if we had increased it by $24. Yesterday afternoon he was on radio, redolent of one of his political heroes, Senator Amanda Vanstone, saying it was not worth a milkshake and a hamburger. I do not know what goes on in Clayfield, but it would be a pretty expensive milkshake and hamburger that cost $24. It would be a Wagyu beef hamburger and a Barambah Organics milk milkshake, with a double soy latte on top, that cost $24.

I make the point that if we had increased the CTP by $24 yesterday they would have been standing up, crying out about the burden being put on households. They would have been standing up for people they have never cared for and have never put a single policy in place to assist. They would have been decrying us, saying that the $24 would be the straw that breaks the camel’s back. However, because we have cut it by $24, they have to try to invent some opposition to it. This government makes no apology for going after the trailing commissions that exist in the compulsory third party insurance regime to cut compulsory third party insurance by $24 and deliver a saving to people on their registration bill. Why have we determined to do that? Because of the strict fiscal rules that we put in place.

Yes, times are tough and the revenue position does not allow us to undertake across-the-board taxation cuts. We continue to maintain a taxation level that is $400 below the national average. What did we do? Last year we started work on the policy hard yards to make sure we could put in place a cut to deliver some relief to Queensland households. Far from being a cruel hoax, it is a real cut of $24 to the ceiling, which we will legislate for during the next sittings of parliament to be in place by 1 October. In that debate the test for those opposite will be whether they will stand up and vote for a cut in the CTP insurance regime ceiling for Queensland motorists. We know what they will do. They will stand up and vote for it, because they know--or they should pretend to know--that $24 does matter. We have put in the policy hard yards to deliver on this. Any sort of opposition to it by those opposite merely reveals that they have absolutely no idea what the vast majority of Queenslanders think.

Mr WETTENHALL: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Could the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health please update the House on initiatives to train dentists in North Queensland?
Ms Nolan interjected.

Mr LUCAS: Yes, that is a good point from the Minister for Transport. The opposition leader once believed in fluoride; he does not now and maybe he will do something differently on Thursday when he delivers his speech. I am pleased to confirm that the Queensland government is investing $24.9 million in 2010-11 to boost dental services in North Queensland, part of $45 million over four years. The honourable member has fought tooth and nail, so to speak, for that allocation. It will establish dental clinic training facilities on the James Cook University campus to train third- and fourth-year students and on the Townsville campus to train fifth-year students. We will now have three new universities in Queensland training dentists, and that is good news for the people of Queensland.

More than 1.9 million Queenslanders are eligible for dental services--45 per cent of our population. That is more than any other state. Indeed, in this budget we are investing big dollars in dental services, with an estimated 2 million occasions of service for 2011. In fact, our budget is the biggest in Australia for dental services by a country mile in per capita terms and is about the same size as New South Wales.

We have seen in his comments the Leader of the Opposition talking about what he thinks in terms of spending cuts. He has expressed his view. Of course that sits totally against two other things that the opposition have done in relation to dental services.
