First of all, time and time again they are calling for more investment in dental services. So clearly they do not want to invest money in that or they want to cut something else to do it. Time after time they have refused to put the pressure federally on Tony Abbott, who is holding up federal funding in the Senate for more services. That would have delivered $52.8 million in dental funding to Queensland over four years and provided for 187,000 visits--an initiative that would have greatly assisted Queenslanders. Not only are they dishonest in terms of calling for more services; they do not even support putting pressure on Tony Abbott.

It is very interesting. Tony Abbott is in town and he has expressed his view about the wonderful creation of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition--his opus maximus, the LNP. What did Tony Abbott say about the LNP? He said he was happy with a few candidates. How many is he happy with in Queensland? Three--Warren Entsch, Ken O’Dowd in Flynn and George Christensen. And he is not happy with anyone else. How could someone like Andrew Laming, who has an obstetrics diploma, is an ophthalmologist and has an MPA from Harvard, ever get off the back bench? Let alone this crowd over here. The simple fact of the matter is that the Liberal Party is a weak link and the LNP is the weakest link in the Liberal Party. Those opposite have no policy when it comes to dental services. We will roll dental services out in rural and regional Queensland.

Mr HORAN: My question is to the Minister for Health. I refer to the unauthorised deduction of hundreds of dollars from the fortnightly pay packets of Queensland Health employees by the Queensland government for non-existent loans. I table copies of two pay advices received by a Toowoomba nurse.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copies of Queensland Health pay advices, dated 19 May and 2 June 2010 [ 2380 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Inquiries show these bogus deductions are widespread practice. I ask the minister: how much has this government stolen from its employees in this outrageous scandal?
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Question Out of Order
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: I want to seek advice on that question. It appears to me that that may come close to the anticipation rule of tonight’s notice of motion. I rule the question out of order. I will give the honourable gentleman an explanation. As I see it, part 3 of the notice of motion tonight deals specifically with issues in and around the working payroll system. Accordingly, I rule the question out of order.
Mr MOORHEAD: My question without notice is to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer update the House on the government’s economic reform strategy and whether he is aware of any alternatives?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Waterford for his question and for his commitment to ensuring that the people in his community get the policies and the support that they need from a state government. I am drawn however, given the events of the last 30 seconds, to look at the prescience of Tony Abbott’s reported remarks in the Australian this morning. Mr Abbott is reported as saying, ‘Lift your game, Abbott orders fractious LNP’. The old tactics committee of the LNP should have tabled this up the top. What is he reported as saying? ‘It certainly needs to sharpen up a bit.’ There is probably no real argument about that. He said, ‘It’s not terminal but we’re starting to see the return of people who were involved in factional fighting in the Liberal Party. If they manage to get back in, it will sink the whole show.’

What is happening inside the LNP? Mr Abbott is reported as saying, ‘Unfortunately the LNP has been totally overtaken by turncoat Liberals’--of them there are a few--‘and hardcore Bjelke-Petersen style National Party types, and this has meant precious campaign capability and experience is not being used.’ Was it on display in the last two minutes? Remember the ringing endorsement that the Leader of the Opposition gave the opposition whip, for all his experience and tactics and the great way he could contribute to the parliament--with a massive own goal over the top of the head in the last 30 seconds. Of course that silence and that total incapacity to even do something as simple as run a question in question time is reflected in their total policy incapacity.

What has this government done? We have delivered a budget that charts a course for recovery. We have delivered a budget that forecasts lower debt, lower deficits, higher growth and more jobs sooner. It puts us on course to achieve a AAA credit rating, as Standard & Poor’s said this morning. What do they say? They say that our plan puts us in the zone. What will they say about the Leader of the Opposition on Thursday? Will they have anything to say at all? Will the Leader of the Opposition have anything to say at all?

Now we are inside 24 hours until the Leader of the Opposition, in all his impotent rage, stands up here and--just like the powder puff, glamour shot obsessive he is--produces nought, nothing, no policies, no alternative, nothing to go forward for the people of Queensland because he has been far more interested in the glamour shot. He has been promising us the money shot, but what has happened? Absolutely nothing. In all his impotent rage he stands there with a whinge and a whine, wrings his hands, talks about the future and produces nothing. Instead, all he does is stand atop as a figurehead of this brown’s cows collection of old timers and good timers, playing solitaire, doing nothing, sitting in the hammock, bludging off the taxpayer, ripping the taxpayer off for their advertising. What a bunch of lazy frauds!

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. This morning I was contacted by a nurse who works within my electorate who was due to be paid last Wednesday, 2 June 2010, and had been promised every day since then that she would be paid ‘tomorrow’. This morning she finally received a pay advice from Queensland Health and that pay advice has a net pay of zero. I table for the information of the House the pay advice from Queensland Health which shows a due date of 2 June 2010 and a net pay of zero.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of Queensland Health pay advice, dated 2 June 2010 [ 2381 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: I ask the minister: what do Queensland nurses have to do to be properly paid the wages that they have earned?
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Question Out of Order
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Just before you go on I want to check that. I am going to follow on from my previous ruling and rule it out of order.

Mr SEENEY: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I want to make the point that the notice of motion that was given by the Leader of the Opposition does not deal with the issue that I raised specifically. I asked a specific question about a specific nurse. I dispute your ruling and I question your ruling that the question I asked was pre-empting the discussion on the motion tonight. The question that I asked was about a specific case and it is not mentioned in the motion in any way, shape or form.

Mr SPEAKER: The grave difficulty I have been placed in is that I have a notice of motion that deals with payrolls. As I explained to the honourable member for Toowoomba South, his question went to the heart of that. The position I am placed in with the notice of motion is that I have to be consistent in my rulings. I would therefore invite the honourable gentleman, if he disagrees with my ruling, to move dissent from it. The position I have been placed in is that I have a notice of motion before the House. I have ruled one way for the member for Toowoomba South and I do not feel I can duck in and out of that. That is the position the chair finds itself in and, accordingly, that is my ruling.

Mrs SMITH: May I, firstly, acknowledge the student leaders from the Caningeraba State School in the electorate of Burleigh who are in the public gallery this morning. My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. It is heartening to see so many cranes on the Gold Coast skyline, at least five of which are on the site of the Gold Coast University Hospital. Can the minister detail some of the regions where jobs are being created and protected by the Bligh government?
Mr SCHWARTEN: What an extraordinary set of events we have seen here this morning by people who have been in this parliament long enough to understand the standing orders.
Mr Seeney: You’ve been in government long enough to make sure that nurses get paid. I’ll bet you didn’t get zero.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Callide! It will help the chair, Minister, if you answer the question.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Thanks, Mr Speaker. Did I hear him use the word ‘zero’? That is his level of intelligence. No wonder those opposite want to blind out the answer on this, because they know that tomorrow they will be asked to vote down jobs in Queensland by their own party. That is the reality.

The honourable member for Burleigh talked about the Gold Coast. May I suggest that honourable members who sit opposite get somebody to read to them this document I am holding, because the reality is that members of parliament on this side of the House will support all of those jobs throughout Queensland that are outlined here. Those opposite seem to think that if you do not borrow money--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: I ask the honourable minister to resume his seat. It is getting very hard to hear up here.

Mr SCHWARTEN: This document, which is available to all Queenslanders--and the Rockhampton Morning Bulletin actually picked it up--is part of our absolute clarity to the people of Queensland. It points out--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I know that you are not interested in what is happening in your own region, but there are plenty of people in the building industry who are.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.

Mr SCHWARTEN: The people who are interested include those whose jobs depend on, for example, the $117.8 million that will be spent this year on construction jobs at the hospital in the honourable member for Burleigh’s area. If we do not agree to do that through this budget, that project stops. It is pretty simple. It is all very well for you to misuse taxpayers’ money--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I ask the honourable gentleman to address his comments through the chair.

Mr SCHWARTEN: It is all very well for honourable members opposite to misuse taxpayers’ money to tell people that you should not borrow money, but the net effect of it is this: every one of those construction workers who depends on a job like that would have to walk off the job. They would not have a job, whether it be at Lotus Glen, out at Gatton or on any of our projects throughout regional Queensland. What that ad which they attempted to put this morning, with the disgraceful use of taxpayers’ money, should really have said at the bottom was: ‘By the way, get rid of all the building workers in this state and get rid of all the projects.’

Mr McARDLE: My question is to the Minister for Health. I refer the minister to the capital works program for the health department this financial year of which $365 million for critical health infrastructure was not spent, causing projects to be delayed, including emergency department improvements and the Townsville Hospital and Bundaberg Hospital expansions. Minister, with the access block running at an average of 34 per cent across the state and critical projects being delayed, how much longer will people continue to lie on a trolley rather than on a real hospital bed?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for his question. Our capital works budget dwarfs that of other states when it comes to health. Our capital works budget this year in Health over the forward estimates is in excess of $7 billion in the Health Action Plan. This year it is about $1.6 billion, off the top of my head. In fact, the Gold Coast University Hospital is half a billion dollars. Of course, in a state like Queensland where we have significant rain problems--and I think we had significant ones in Townsville--that will cause delays in some projects from time to time.

Let us be very clear about the choice that you have in this place, and we will see this choice tomorrow when the Leader of the Opposition delivers his budget reply. When he is given the choice between Forestry Plantations Queensland, with a return on capital of half a per cent, and delivering a Health capital budget of $7 billion, we will see where he stands. The opposition leader has thus far stood criticising the government for our Health capital projects rollout, yet at the same time he has said that he does not want to privatise anything. That is of course unless you are quoting the member for ‘Santoro’ Clayfield--
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.

Mr LUCAS: He has said on the record time and time again that he wants to sell the electricity assets. The simple fact of the matter is that the opposition leader does not want to sell government assets and put that money into health facilities. The simple fact of the matter is that the opposition is not committed to a Health capital building project. This government is putting its money where its mouth is, with $9.999 billion in recurrent expenditure. We will continue to build a record capital works program in Health and that will result in more and more services.

We had the AMA president in the media on the Sunshine Coast saying that we would not see beds delivered there for 18 months. Well, we will see the Nambour 96-bed wing completed at the end of this year. One would think the AMA--that is, the industrial wing of the Liberal Party--with people such as the Rockhampton president as a Senate candidate, would have something to say about the state budget. Yet it does not, and it never criticises at a state level Tony Abbott or indeed the LNP. Tony Abbott is a bigger critic of the LNP than the AMA is.

We will continue to build our record capital works building program. The AMA wanted 3,700 beds nationally; we are delivering 1,700. In the course of about five years, we have doubled our expenditure in Queensland Health. We have 1,200 more clinical workers this year, and the best the intellect in the member for Caloundra could do was deliver volunteers working in mental health. No wonder he is not even considered as deputy leader for the LNP.

Mrs KIERNAN: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. Can the minister outline how this year’s budget is helping to ease the pressure on Queensland families?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the honourable member for the question because we know the pressure that Queenslanders are under. Many families are doing it tough, and that is why this year’s budget provides increased support for vulnerable members of our community. As announced by the Treasurer, we are introducing a Medical Cooling and Heating Electricity Concession Scheme, worth some $216 per annum. Pensioners and seniors will also benefit from a boost to the electricity rebate, taking the rebate they can apply for to $216. The Electricity Life Support Concession Scheme will also go up to $440.30 per year for consumers using oxygen concentrators and $294.85 per annum for consumers using home kidney dialysis machines. They are some of the rebates that are providing relief for Queenslanders who need it most.

There has also been someone else talking about electricity recently, and that is the Leader of the Opposition. An extraordinary exchange took place just this morning between Madonna King and the Leader of the Opposition. It went like this--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Madonna King: You just raised electricity. Can you guarantee that electricity would be cheaper for Queenslanders if you were Premier?
Mr Langbroek: I could guarantee that tomorrow--in now less than 24 hours--I can guarantee when I do my budget reply we are going to deal with some of those costs.
Madonna King: No, that is not what I asked you, though. The question was, ‘You raised electricity, do you believe electricity prices, you could bring them down if you were made Premier?’
Mr Langbroek: I can guarantee that we’ll make sure our increases are not the increases we are seeing under Labor.
Madonna King: Yes, but you’re already flagging there would be increases saying that.
Mr Langbroek: Oh, I think.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He recovered shortly thereafter. He stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queenslanders everywhere I go are feeling the pain from electricity and rego and we’re not going to say that we’re actually going to say we’re going to have decreases two years from now.
XML.Hansard-Body: When the pressure was put on, he squibbed it. When the simple question was asked, ‘What will you do about electricity prices,’ he had nowhere to go. Can I suggest to the Leader of the Opposition that the first thing he needs to do if he is going to have an impact on electricity prices is move away from the commitment made at the last two elections to underground powerlines--an initiative that would cost $35 billion. That is $8,750 each and every year for the average Queensland household. He has to move away from that commitment that he made at the last two election campaigns before he can do anything about electricity prices.

We know what they are really going to do. As we heard from the member for Clayfield only a couple of years ago, those opposite not only support privatisation of the retail arm of electricity but also support selling the generators and selling the poles and wires. What I want to hear from the Leader of the Opposition tomorrow is a repudiation of what the member for Clayfield, his shadow Treasury spokesmen, said a couple of years ago in this place that they would sell the lot.

Mr MESSENGER: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. I refer the Deputy Premier to recent correspondence that I have had with him regarding Australian of the Year award winner and nurse Toni Hoffman who says that since the Bundaberg health crisis she has not had a decent holiday or a break because she has had to use all her official Queensland Health leave entitlements preparing for royal commissions, giving evidence to royal commission and preparing for criminal trials or giving evidence to criminal trials. Can the Deputy Premier please explain whether it is fair, moral or ethical that this government has treated a valued employee and inspirational Queenslander in this shabby manner?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I acknowledge that Toni Hoffman is a great person and that she has played a wonderful role in public issues in Queensland. I will find out what the rules are in relation to public servants giving evidence and the extent of leave that is available for them to do that. Generally when people give evidence they are entitled to witness fees and the like. If they are giving expert evidence there are different levels of fees available as well. I will have that investigated.

It is admirable the way the court system operates when people do their public duty and give evidence, either voluntarily or under subpoena. I am not suggesting that Ms Hoffman would have done it under subpoena; I am sure she would have done it voluntarily. I will make some inquiries in relation to that.

I am sure the honourable member would expect, though, that the treatment that would be provided would be equitable in all the circumstances, vis-a-vis the number of other Queensland Health employees who are giving evidence in matters. I do not want to canvass any specific issues. I know there are specific matters that are currently before the court. I will find that out and let the honourable member know.

Mrs MILLER: My question without notice is to the Minister for Education and Training. Could the minister please update the House on planned increases to teachers and teacher aide numbers in Queensland schools?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. The Premier and Treasurer have said it right. Education is the cornerstone for the growth of the Queensland economy and the Queensland community. That is why there is record expenditure in this year’s budget of $9.53 billion. That is up significantly--$257 million or 3.29 per cent--on the previous year. Nearly a quarter of the Queensland budget is dedicated to building this cornerstone for the future.

That includes 316 extra teachers and teacher aides. It also includes paying the highest comparable wage rates for beginning teachers in our education system. It also pays for putting our outstanding senior teachers on a new performance pay rate that is equal to other states.

I will tell members one thing: as I have been travelling around Queensland in recent months and from the feedback I have heard from the 60 or 70 forums conducted on the flying start discussion paper not one person has approached me and said, ‘Stop spending money on education in Queensland schools and spend that money on building railway lines for coal companies.’ Not one person has done that. They know where we should be investing public money.

The opposition has a policy--and it has recently reiterated its policy--on freezing capital works, freezing the building program in education, freezing the rollout of kindergartens and 36,000 staff to go. There has been no new policy since the reiteration of that policy. There have been no new policies, no new vision and no new ideas.

Why have those opposite got no policy, you might ask? The shadow spokesman for education has just been benched. Yesterday, the member for Currumbin got the education question. The member for Moggill needs to watch out for the member for Currumbin. Watch out shadow spokesperson.
Mrs STUCKEY: I rise to a point of order, Mr Speaker. I find the minister’s comments--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I will wait for the House to come to order.
Mrs STUCKEY: I find the minister’s comments offensive and I would seek an apology as Dr Flegg returned from an operation on his eye yesterday morning and could not see clearly.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The difficulty is this: I will say to the honourable member that you are taking a point of order on behalf of another member.
Mrs STUCKEY: I find the words offensive and untrue and I ask for them to be withdrawn.
A government member : Nothing was said about you.
Mrs STUCKEY: They were untrue.
Mr SPEAKER: I would ask the minister to get on with it. If he could withdraw the statement we can get on with it.

Mr WILSON: I am happy to withdraw, Mr Speaker. Parents and students in this state deserve better from the most highly funded opposition in the country, the laziest opposition in the country--an opposition that has no plans, no vision and no policies on education and training. They expect policy for world-class education, for excellence in teaching, for exemplary leadership of schools and the best curriculum in our schools. That is what the education portfolio is providing. That is what parents and students expect. We are delivering on that. The opposition is simply the threadbare remains of a shotgun marriage.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the honourable member for Nicklin.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Woolooga-Eerwah Vale High-Voltage Electricity Transmission Line
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WELLINGTON: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to my statement in parliament yesterday on the proposed Woolooga-Eerwah Vale high-voltage electricity transmission line. Will the minister instruct or request Powerlink, a state owned corporation, to accept the offer from the community action group PAGE to inspect their proposed alternative corridor for the powerline and grant a 14-day extension for submissions to be made regarding the proposed powerline corridor?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for the question. I did note his speech in the chamber yesterday and his request on behalf of his constituents for an extension of, I believe, two weeks for the receipt of submissions into the proposed Woolooga-Eerwah Vale transmission line project. Just a bit of history first. My understanding is that Powerlink has written to stakeholders, including landholders directly affected by the project, advising of its intention to seek ministerial designation as community infrastructure under the Sustainable Planning Act.

Public notice was also placed in local newspapers, and during this time all interested parties have had the opportunity to make submissions on Powerlink’s proposal. As I understand it, submissions close today and hence the relevance of the member’s question. The PAGE group has raised some issues regarding Powerlink allegedly not adhering to process, including a claim that Powerlink did not write to all affected stakeholders. This is an issue that must be raised with Powerlink and I understand that that issue has in fact been raised. I have also been further advised that Powerlink responded to this claim and granted an extension to specific landholders who had not received a letter informing of the community infrastructure designation. Again, this is a matter for Powerlink and PAGE in the first instance. My role will be the assessment of the final responses to all of the issues raised. Any concerned landholders and community groups have until today to lodge their final submissions with Powerlink.

I am advised the 9 June deadline was set according to the guidelines about the environmental assessment and public consultation procedures for designating land for community infrastructure which was put in place in 2006, and those guidelines are established by the Sustainable Planning Act. Powerlink’s processes are set out under schedule 5 of that document. Therefore, to grant a further extension, I am advised, would require an amendment to the Sustainable Planning Act, which I am sure the member who asked the question will agree is not practical or warranted in the circumstances. Under normal circumstances I would receive such requests and view them favourably, but given the constraints on me by the act--as I said, it is not something that I have discretion on--I certainly understand the approach that the member for Nicklin is making on behalf of his constituents. I can only encourage those constituents to make sure that they get whatever information they have to Powerlink by the close of business today.

Ms GRACE: My question is to the Minister for Transport. Can the minister outline what the budget delivers for public transport services in Brisbane and what funding is provided by other levels of government?

Ms NOLAN: I can, and I thank the member for Brisbane Central for her question. There is a stark contrast between the three levels of government in their commitment to public transport. At a federal level, while the Howard government did nothing for Queensland public transport, the Rudd government has stepped ably into the field, putting $365 million into the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project and $20 million into the development of the Cross River Rail project. At a state level, over the last five years this Labor government has more than doubled its TransLink funding from $600 million in 2004 to $1.38 billion today, and this Labor government is paying fully for the operation of each and every one of the 125 new buses that the Brisbane City Council will build this year. So when the people of Brisbane drive around and find themselves sitting behind a big new blue and yellow bus with the words ‘500 new buses for Brisbane’ on the back of it, the people of Brisbane should think that that is thanks to the state government, because this government is paying fully for the operation of those 125 new buses.

There is one level of government that stands in stark contrast to the other two in terms of its contribution to public transport, and that is the one level of government which is administered by the LNP. In 2004 when Campbell Newman was elected as the Liberal Lord Mayor of Brisbane, the Brisbane City Council paid for 50 per cent of the operations of Brisbane transport, particularly Brisbane City Council buses, and that fifty-fifty split with the state was a longstanding historical arrangement. In 2010 the Brisbane City Council under the LNP administration pays just 40 per cent of the cost of Brisbane City Council buses because Campbell Newman has done to public transport what John Howard did to health: they have progressively withdrawn from their share of a funding contribution such that in 2004 the council paid 50 per cent and today it pays 40 per cent. With the Brisbane City Council’s budget being handed down today, I call on the LNP administration to match our funding contribution. If it does there would be $27 million more for better buses, which we pay for. We pay for those buses in total and in full.

Ms SIMPSON: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. Queenslanders will pay more in vehicle registration--an increase of $239 million--and a fuel tax--an increase of $500 million each year--together nearly three quarters of a billion dollars coming out of road users in Queensland. Thus, will the minister explain to the road users of Queensland why road funding has in fact decreased in this budget by a quarter of a billion dollars?
Mr SPEAKER: Minister for Main Roads, you have one minute.

Mr WALLACE: Thank you, Mr Speaker. We are spending three times what those opposite spent on roads--three times. We are spending over three times more on road projects right across our state. I heard some whingeing from those opposite that there was nothing in their electorates. Let us talk about their electorates: Callide, 56 projects; Caloundra, 33 projects; Condamine, 22 projects; Dalrymple, 32 projects; Gregory, my good friend from out west, 59 Main Roads projects; Hinchinbrook, 30 projects; Lockyer, 31 projects; Mirani, 50 projects; Mudgeeraba on the Gold Coast, 13 projects; Southern Downs, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition’s electorate, 35 Main Roads projects; and Warrego, right out west, 60 Main Roads projects. We are out there delivering road projects right across this state. They will sit there and whinge. We will roll out the bitumen. We are very proud of our record.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The time for question time has ended.

Mr SEENEY: I rise to a point of order. Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order concerning the rulings of the House this morning with regard to anticipating debate on motions of which notice has been given. Due to the circumstances in this House, there are an increasing number of motions accumulating on the Notice Paper . I would suggest that some of those motions at least have the potential, if the ruling that was given this morning is extended to all of those motions, to seriously curtail debate on the budget bills.

In particular, I would draw your attention to one such notice of motion which deals with the royalties to regions question. If the interpretation of the anticipation rule is applied to that motion in the same way that it was applied to the questions that were asked this morning, I would suggest that debate on the budget bills is going to be seriously curtailed. Mr Speaker, I think there are other motions on the Notice Paper which present similar problems.

I would ask you, Mr Speaker, to either reconsider the rulings that were given this morning by a formal notice to this House or to refer this issue as a matter of urgency to the Standing Orders Committee so that debate on the budget bills can proceed in the traditional way without being curtailed by the precedent that has been set this morning by this ruling.

Mr SPEAKER: I will undertake to get back to the honourable member. There are issues that you have raised there that are on the Notice Paper that I want to have a look at. I would say in general that a lot of the notices of motion that have been given do come off the Notice Paper after 30 days. Nevertheless, it is always my intention to allow both sides maximum discussion. I will get back to you in a fully considered way, and that is what I intend to do. I would remind the honourable gentleman that there is a meeting of the Standing Orders Committee later this week, so I will get back to you well and truly before then.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.39 am): After seeing the performance by the member for Thuringowa and the member for Mount Coot-tha, I think there must have been something in the water in 2004 when they came into this place. What we have learned from the budget, which we are discussing now, is that you cannot believe a word this government says. On the cusp of a federal election, it will do and say anything and, as we make a detailed analysis of the budget, we will see that it will hide everything.

We have now had different reasons from the Treasurer about privatisation. Over the past couple of years privatisation has been about delivering better services for Queenslanders, repaying debt and replacing the lost income. But of course, the government has its income back and now it is all about restoring the AAA credit rating. I note that today the Treasurer says that the $603 million from the sale of Forestry Plantations will provide services to disadvantaged families in Logan and Beenleigh. So privatisation is not about repaying debt.

This morning on ABC Radio the Treasurer came out with the statement that householders in Queensland are probably spending less because they incurred too much debt, which they put on themselves during the boom years. That is exactly what this state has done. But of course, the Treasurer does not acknowledge anything like that. All he comes out with is statements such as ‘brick by brick’, ‘tough road to hoe’ and ‘it is not a blockbuster fairytale but one that turns the page’. He also says, ‘The task is not done.’ This morning the Treasurer also said, ‘It is a theoretical proposition that has not been undertaken so that makes it of no real utility’, ‘The bigger they come the harder they fall,’ and ‘climb down out of their trees’. This morning he also said that the budget was ‘a helping hand to those who need it most, as is our calling’. He thinks he is Churchill. Then we heard him say, ‘The budget will stand the test of the time’--of course, until the midyear economic fiscal review. The Treasurer also says, ‘It will require our resolve--something we have in spades’, ‘roll up the sleeves’ and ‘do the hard yards’. That is all we get from the Treasurer: words, not action.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (11.41 am): To paraphrase Oscar Wilde, to lose one candidate may be regarded as misfortune but to lose two members of the Queensland parliament, a member of the federal parliament, two candidates and a councillor looks like the rabble of the Liberal National Party. This morning I rise to welcome the member for Gregory, Vaughan Johnson, back to this place for another sitting week. I must say to the member for Gregory that, after the last sitting week, I did not think he would make it back.

During the last sitting week Queensland watched in amazement as the LNP started leaking all of its dirty laundry about Michael Johnson, the then LNP member for Ryan. There were allegations of secret commissions, fundraising for flowers and, of course, the ever-suspicious purchase of a scooter. Everything that Bruce McIver and the bovver boys of the LNP could leak on Johnson they did. But by Thursday it was all over and Johnson had been expelled.

But then the LNP started on Johnston. The LNP started tipping the bucket on her, too--Nicole Johnston, LNP member on the Brisbane City Council team. Allegations that she pushed over a chair were wielded and then Johnston was gone from the LNP. Councillor Johnston quit before being pushed.

With the LNP Councillor Johnston gone and the federal LNP member Michael Johnson being expelled, I was worried that poor state MP Vaughan Johnson would not be back or would be sitting up the back of this chamber this week. I thought that the Johnson faction of the LNP was not doing too well after the last week’s sitting. But maybe, coming from the National Party, Vaughan Johnson has Bruce McIver on his side, leaving him the last Johnson standing.

With the opposition leader hiding from the cameras during the last sitting week, who would have thought it could have got worse? On Monday night the LNP lost another one. Good old Bruce McIver was at it again. Federal LNP candidate Hajnal Ban was disendorsed after a tribunal finding that she had used a power of attorney and mixed her own moneys with moneys of a resident of the Talbarra nursing home at Waterford.

These people try to say that they could govern this state. They cannot organise a preselection and probably not a chook raffle. If you cannot govern your party, how can you govern this state? In 2006 they could not tell Queenslanders who would be Premier. They cannot even tell who will be candidates now.

Ms SIMPSON (Maroochydore--LNP) (11.43 am): During the last election campaign the Bligh government promised Queenslanders a jobs plan but, 12 months on, no plan has been announced for the Sunshine Coast. With regard to jobs, this region has been ignored by this government. I ask the Premier: where are our jobs? Or has the Premier forgotten that it is small business that provides the majority of these jobs? Those small businesses now have record business costs imposed on them by her government: water, power, vehicle costs, registration, petrol, increasing council levies and other charges. In fact, most regions of Queensland have seen no economic strategy and jobs plan from this government.

The SEQ Regional Plan and accompanying investment time frames in SEQIPP do not cater for growth. But this is a doubly cruel hoax when we realise that there is no economic strategy accompanying the land use strategy. The same is true for the Sunshine Coast Regional Council’s current draft Maroochydore structure plan, which is anti investment and jobs. I table separately a number of documents relating to the commercial uptake of property, the transport department’s own projections as to where jobs will be generated versus where the population has grown, the business confidence survey and UDIA’s commercial analysis.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Graph titled ‘Growth: SEQ by TransLink Sub Region: Growth 2006-2031’ [ 2382 ].
Tabled paper: Chart from ABS Labour Force Survey titled ‘Queensland: Unemployment Rates by Labour Force Region, April 2010 (%)’ [ 2383 ].
Tabled paper: Media release by Boardroom Business, dated 17 May 2010, titled ‘Business Confidence on Sunshine Coast drops’ [ 2384 ].
Tabled paper: Sunshine Coast Business Confidence Survey, April 2010, by Boardroom Business [ 2385 ].
Tabled paper: Office Market Report: Statistical Summary, January 2010, and Office Market Summary, January 2009 [ 2386 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: We see now that the Sunshine Coast has double the population growth compared to the jobs growth. That means that, without a genuine, coordinated and focused jobs plan for the region, people will be commuting to Brisbane and elsewhere for a job. That is happening now. I am fighting for a sustainable Sunshine Coast--sustainable for the environment and the lifestyle and the businesses that supply the jobs in the local economy. Without this plan from the government we will continue to see people losing their jobs, leaving the region and facing increased costs.

These documents show that the current plans of this government and also, unfortunately, the draft structure plan of the council are anti jobs and anti investment. We do not want to see small businesses bled anymore. We see from the documents that I have tabled that, clearly, there is a major issue with small businesses and jobs, particularly in the Sunshine Coast region.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP)
(11.45 am): Six months ago, upon my request, the Minister for Sport, Phil Reeves, visited the Centenary Rowing Club during their early morning training on the river at Jindalee. Members of the club have been meeting at this spot, affectionately called the ‘mudhole’, for many years to undertake training and competitions. This area is on land that is leased from the council by the scouts and is directly behind the scout hut. The scouts have been generous in allowing the rowing club to share this area for the benefit of the young people who are involved in the sport until they establish their own facility at the end of Sumners Road.

The minister announced on his visit that his department would be providing a major facilities grant of $390,000 to construct this new clubhouse. This funding is in addition to a previous Sport and Recreation grant to construct a state-of-the-art pontoon at the Sumners Road site in 2009. At their trophy presentation a number of weeks ago members advised me that there were extra unexpected expenses that appeared to have been overlooked by the council during the development application process, which took several years. They recently discovered building waste material on the western part of the site, which had been an illegal tip. The waste had to be removed and replaced with fill. There also have been extra expenses for the extension and expansion of water, sewerage and power facilities to the property boundary, requiring them to redesign and reprogram these works.

These costs are unavoidable and are needed to complete stage 1 of the project. As a supporter of the hundreds of young people from both public and private schools who are passionate about rowing, I have spoken to the minister about the need for extra funds and I have formally written to him to detail the club’s current dilemma. It would be a tragedy if, after the years of work and achievements of the club, the facility could not be completed because of these unexpected costs. The club has built its reputation through its enthusiastic volunteers, its achievements, its fierce competition and successes in rowing and through providing opportunities for young people from public schools to partake in the sport. I again call on the Minister for Sport to give consideration to the club’s unexpected costs and to provide the extra funds to ensure that these young rowers continue to flourish.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (11.47 am): I rise to speak in relation to an important determination that will be made shortly by the Sunshine Coast Regional Council--that is, whether the airport at Caloundra, which includes surrounding businesses, will be sold. The airport and the surrounding businesses are located on land that is owned by the state government, of which the council is the trustee. This government has placed upon the council the obligation to decide whether this land is to go to the private market and the moneys used elsewhere.

I point out to the House that three entities operate on that site. There is the airport itself and those businesses, there is the Queensland Air Museum and, adjacent to the Air Museum, the air cadets. The air cadets organisation is run by the RAAF. It mentors young people between the ages of 13 and 18 on leadership, being part of a team, understanding right from wrong, and developing into strong citizens. If this airport and its precinct are sold, these young men and women, who come from right across the Sunshine Coast to attend air cadet meetings every Monday night at this training facility, will be left without any home base whatsoever. If we believe in providing young people with strong initiative, strong direction and a strong understanding of their role in society, we should be ensuring that this organisation of young men and women stays exactly where it is.

The air cadets site is located adjacent to the Queensland Air Museum, which is an organisation that holds one of the most important collections of aircraft and memorabilia from across this nation--going from the early flying days of the 1900s right through to the present. It would be an absolute crime for these two facilities to be sold in any way, shape or form. They must stay exactly where they are. I am told that the airport supports 225 people and their families. Every single day they pour school fees et cetera into our economy.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP)
(11.49 am): Queensland Rail’s new rail welding facility at Yeerongpilly is at the cutting edge of rail technology and producing a world-class product that services public and private sector customers across the country. Construction of this new facility commenced in January 2008 with completion in March this year. Currently, finetuning of the operation is underway, with commissioning of this $35 million facility set for this month.

Last week I inspected the plant, met with staff and observed the production process. What I saw was a rail welding workshop that is the most advanced of its kind in Queensland and with a capacity to supply all rail requirements of Queensland projects over the next 25 years. With dual gauge access rail can be transported in and out of the facility for customers across the country, with all types of rail product able to be welded at the factory. Whilst I was there I observed production of 110-metre lengths of rail which involves four pieces of rail unloaded, cleaned, welded, ground and reloaded for shipment. This complete production line of 110-metre lengths, with three welds and a weld standard within a half millimetre tolerance, takes 20 minutes in the current facility with future capacity to enable welded rail links of 330 metres.

But the most impressive aspect of the facility is the welding technology which enables separation of staff and plant by incorporating computerised systems and world-leading plant and machinery. This provides a safe workplace, with workers able to monitor and control production from a work station separated from the welding activities. With a focus on zero harm, Queensland Rail has developed a facility and implemented procedures that deliver on this government’s commitment to zero harm at work. I commend Queensland Rail for its focus on safety in the facility. This contributes significantly to workers’ health and job satisfaction as well as production of a high standard product which is in demand across Australia.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP)
(11.50 am): The government’s green paper Flying Start proposes that grade 7 be moved into high school. Nowhere in that green paper does it ask people their opinion on middle schooling as a way of dealing with that dramatic change for young Queenslanders. The LNP is committed to quality education in Queensland. We note that if this change goes ahead children entering high school here will be much younger than they are in the other states.

Middle schooling should be considered as an option. The private sector has extensively used middle schooling and students have been able to obtain that benefit. It is one of the reasons why we see a drift away to the private sector. This government is so disinterested that in its budget brought down yesterday it deleted all information about the middle years of schooling. There was not even the number of students in the middle years of schooling. No wonder it was not prepared to give Queenslanders the opportunity to discuss middle schooling in the context of moving grade 7. It has lost touch with the issues that are important in education.

Middle schooling must be an option made available to the school communities in Queensland to consider. It should be included. The LNP will today release its discussion paper on middle schooling. The government did not ask Queensland parents and teachers to comment on middle schooling, but the LNP wants to know what parents, teachers and education stakeholders think about middle schooling as a way of dealing with the transition to high school.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: LNP discussion paper on middle schooling [ 2387 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms O’NEILL (Kallangur--ALP) (11.52 am): World Environment Day has just passed with the theme of Many Species, One Planet, One Future. The theme echoes the urgent call to conserve the diversity of life on our planet. Moreton Bay Marine Park is one of Queensland’s most important natural, recreational, cultural and economic resources, and the bay’s popularity for boating and fishing is rapidly increasing. While we all enjoy the bay, our enjoyment is having an impact on one of our at-risk species, the dugong. Years of research and observation of dugong in Moreton Bay has found that it is an important feeding area and the only place in the world where dugong still live on the doorstep of a major city. There are 600 to 800 dugong that live here.

Dugong are prone to boat strike and Moreton Bay is a hot spot for boat strikes. Half of the incidents recorded along the Queensland coast occur in Moreton Bay. Our Department of Environment and Resource Management has the Nature Conservation (Dugong) Conservation Plan, which includes speed limits in designated areas. Unfortunately, as dugong are rarely seen from boats not everyone obeys the rules, resulting in boat strike. The member for Redcliffe invited me to the launch of the Hays Inlet Festival where I was fortunate to see a presentation by a regional manager of Parks and Wildlife which showed aerial vision of boats on the bay and clear vision of a herd of dugong underneath. It was easy to see why boat strike happens.

Dugong are slow but move out of the way if the boat is going slow; they have no chance if the boat is going fast. The footage made it so clear that I am sure that if it were possible to include this vision or pictures in the accredited boat licence training we would see more boaties adhere to the speed limits. We are fortunate to have a fabulous recreation area on our doorstep and we can all do our bit. I urge all those lucky people who use Moreton Bay to think of the turtles and dugong underneath and obey the rules and slow down where requested.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Task Force on Short-Term Holiday Accommodation in Residential Areas
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP)
(11.54 am): I rise to bring to the attention of the House the increasing problem and recent developments concerning the issue of short-term holiday rentals in residential areas. As this problem is quite clearly the operation of a tourism business in a normal residential zoned local authority area, I have focused my attention on the Gold Coast City Council. With constituent support we were able to influence the local council to create a task force in an attempt to tackle this worsening issue. The Task Force on Short-Term Holiday Accommodation in Residential Areas is comprised of representatives from the community and various stakeholders in a bid to tackle this major community issue. I thank the mayor of the Gold Coast, Ron Clarke, for his efforts in establishing this task force.

People who have bought property in what was thought to be a quiet suburban community have been shocked to find their suburb riddled with holiday homes that see their neighbours changing every week and sometimes three times a week. These types of short-term rentals are often let to party groups hosting events such as rowdy bachelor parties, birthday celebrations and out-of-control parties that may go on all week. One couple, who have complained several times to police, have to now keep their grandchildren inside when they visit for fear of them viewing crude acts, such as nudity and foul language that continues night and day.

I am happy to say that these problems will hopefully become an issue of the past once the task force has had time to liaise with stakeholders and make recommendations on rectifying this problem. The task force aims to present a solution to the permanent residents of these problem areas and get a return to the quiet residential communities that they bought into. Mayor Clarke has invoked a sunset clause of four meetings only for this task force to meet to arrive at a remedy for the problem. I congratulate the Gold Coast City Council for taking the initiative to start tackling this issue and I look forward to complete support from the state government in implementing any legislative requirements necessary to eradicate this inappropriate and illegal business activity in otherwise normal residential suburban areas.

Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP) (11.56 am): The people of Chatsworth are strong supporters of public transport. Since the introduction of the go card many people throughout my electorate have purchased go cards to benefit from the lower costs of travel as well as the convenience of using the go card. From the time that I was elected I have lobbied hard to increase public transport throughout the electorate. I am pleased that this government has been listening. We have increased services to Camp Hill, Carina and Carindale and I have seen the development of the park-and-ride service at the Sleeman Centre which has improved access to bus services for people living in the Gumdale, Belmont and Wakerley areas.

This government is also delivering on the South East Busway, a commitment of over $456 million. This busway is moving towards my electorate and will provide significant improvements in comfort and reliability to the many Chatsworth residents who travel to the city each day. Not only that, I am sure that it will be welcomed by the drivers who work in the Carina area. It is time that the federal government matched this government’s commitment to the busway. I have joined with the members for Bulimba, Greenslopes and Capalaba in lobbying our federal counterparts to commit to provide funding for this important job. The south-east suburbs of Brisbane are growing rapidly and we need to ensure that the public transport infrastructure matches this growth.

I have mentioned that the number of go card users is increasing and growing and we need to ensure that we make it easy for them to purchase and top up go cards. I understand that any new system will take time to fully implement. However, it is important that go card top-up facilities are available in areas that suit the user. In my electorate, Carina News at Carina and Burstall News in Belmont have been waiting for a number of months for TransLink to provide the equipment to allow them to top up go cards. I have recently written to the minister to ask her department to develop options for delivering the equipment needed to provide go card top-up facilities more quickly. Due to the significant number of public transport users in the Camp Hill-Carina-Carina Heights area, I ask that these top-up facilities be provided to Carina as a matter of priority.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP) (11.58 am): I rise to highlight some issues in the Ebenezer-Willowbank area. It is encouraging to see the minister for DIP in the chamber. I am sure that the Minister for Transport, Minister Nolan, will be most interested in this as well. The state government has put up Ebenezer-Willowbank as a major industrial area. Some planning for that is in place. However, the minister must take note of the fact that there is a substantial urban population at Willowbank. Those people have lived there for a long time and it is important that their issues are taken into account, particularly the fact that an access road to Ebenezer Road will need to be built prior to the development of the industrial land, otherwise there will be too much disturbance to urbanisation.

Another issue relates to Mutdapilly South Ebenezer. I implore the minister’s department to refer to the area as Mutdapilly South Ebenezer because there is confusion about Ebenezer and South Ebenezer, especially in relation to the weasel words used about the difficult-to-locate, high-impact, large-footprint industries--in other words, the stinky, smelly, noxious industries.

I have surveyed my electorate. I have written to about 50 or 60 residents of the area, which also covers parts of the electorate of Beaudesert. I have received an overwhelming response of negativity about the impacts from this issue. It is really important. It was highlighted again this morning when the environment minister spoke about the Ace Waste incinerator burning medical waste at Willowbank and the buffer that is required. Those sorts of issues will come up. I implore the minister to make sure that people’s private land is not used for a buffer. The buffer must be used by the people who have the facility.
Mr Hinchliffe: It is about the usage; it is not about the ownership.
Mr RICKUSS: I take that interjection.

Ms FARMER (Bulimba--ALP) (12.00 pm): The budget that was handed down yesterday by the Treasurer delivered on the Bligh government’s commitment to a strong economy for Queensland. I was very happy to see that the Bulimba electorate will continue to play a key part in that commitment, particularly with regard to attracting new investment to our state. I refer particularly to the funding that has been allocated in the budget towards the Aerospace Centre for Excellence. After a decade of unprecedented industry growth, the government’s vision for Queensland as an aviation and aerospace hub for the Asia-Pacific region is fast becoming a reality. This is strongly supported by initiatives such as the Aerospace Centre for Excellence.

Through the government’s Queensland Investment Incentives Scheme, Raytheon Australia has been funded to establish the centre, incorporating an aerospace headquarters facility in Murarrie. Since July 1998 the incentives scheme has supported the creation and retention of 25,135 full-time jobs with companies that have invested capital expenditure of $1.736 billion in Queensland. Many more jobs have resulted from in-kind support from Invest Queensland. In the case of Raytheon, financial support was given to the company for the relocation of staff, training and payroll tax rebates. Among the top four defence contractors in the country, Raytheon employs some 1,100 people nationwide.

The establishment of the centre in Murarrie will expand Queensland’s already impressive aerospace capabilities, with our state now regarded as the centre for Australia’s aerospace industry and with almost 30 per cent of Australia’s aviation firms now located here. Businesses in the Bulimba electorate have and will in the future, thanks to the initiatives announced in the budget, receive abundant support from the Queensland government. Our local partnerships only enhance this support, and I make special mention of the South East Brisbane Chamber of Commerce, headed by the redoubtable Penny Cutting, which recently celebrated membership of 100. This is a remarkable achievement that clearly reflects its determination to be relevant to small business in our area. Together with the members for Greenslopes and Chatsworth, I have been working with the chamber to help develop the potential of our local small and medium sized businesses, with the excellent support that is available from the Queensland government. With small business being the largest employer in our state, the government’s focus on building its potential is a key plank of our plan to build a stronger economy. I congratulate the chamber, Raytheon and the Treasurer.

Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (12.02 pm): I rise to speak in order to offer support to the remaining 2.9 million consumers of nicotine based products in Australia. At the same time, I would like to ask you all to give up. I did. Smoking is the leading cause of preventable death in Australia. Each year more than 15,000 Australians die from smoking. The figure exceeds the combined total of deaths caused by motor vehicle accidents, homicide, suicide, breast cancer, AIDS and illicit drug use. Half of all long-term smokers are likely to die because of smoking. Long-term smokers lose an average 13 years of life compared to nonsmokers. Even when smoking is not fatal, smoking related disease and disability causes distress and leads to reduced quality of life for smokers, their families and their friends for many years.

I am a former smoker. Fortunately, I was able to beat the habit several years ago. The cost of smoking to the community in terms of loss of life and the financial cost to the health system is quite overwhelming. However, the smoking industry claims there is a benefit for the economy. An independent report released last year details an analysis of economic arguments put forward by the tobacco industry. The report, prepared by two health economists, assessed the economic impact of both the tobacco industry and public health measures aimed at reducing tobacco use. It put the economic contribution of the tobacco industry at about $1 billion a year but the estimated social costs of smoking at $31 billion per year--yes, $31 billion per year.

World No Smoking Day was 31 May. I encourage all remaining Australians who smoke to seriously consider giving up. You owe it to yourself! Something that the federal government may need to take on board is this: if it is serious about stopping smoking in this country there is only one course of action, and that is to ban the sale of cigarettes. The government continues to take the revenue on board, but it is putting people’s lives at risk every day. All people in politics need to take that on board. If we are serious about stopping smoking and saving money, kill the subject and not the people.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (12.04 pm): Let’s face it: a lot of Queensland men do not live a healthy lifestyle. Many of us would rather eat a meat pie and chips at the footy than do some exercise. The life expectancy of Australian men is up there with the best in the world, but Australian males die, on average, five years younger than women. Next week is International Men’s Health Week and there is no better time for men to think about how we can live longer and healthier lives.

The Bligh government cares deeply about men’s health, and this year our government will take unprecedented action to emphasise the importance of men having regular health checks. Next week I will host a ceremony to recognise people who have made a contribution to boosting men’s health in Queensland. Those to be recognised will include doctors, nurses, public health experts and men’s health advocacy groups.

However, the highlight of Men’s Health Week will be the Pit Stop free men’s health checks at five Bunnings stores in South-East Queensland. Men visiting those stores will be able to put their bodies through the pits, in a manner similar to taking their cars for a service. Men will be able to get free health checks for their chassis, or weight; their oil pressure, or blood pressure; their duco, or skin; fuel additives or exhaust, or alcohol and/or smoking; and--two that will provide a lot of interest--their extractor, to test for bowel cancer; and their spark plugs, to test for testicular cancer.

I can assure members that none of the tests is invasive! Men who pass through most of the health stations will get a roadworthy certificate. Those who do not will get advice on what they can do to improve their health. Further Pit Stops will be rolled out across Queensland later in the year, and I encourage all men to take up the offer of a free health check. I say to Queensland men: put yourselves in the driver’s seat this Men’s Health Week and take the time to have your ‘parts’ checked. It could save your life.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (12.05 pm): Recently a constituent came to see me, very concerned that a police raid has been conducted on her home. The raid occurred on Thursday while she was at work and, naturally, she felt violated, as any law-abiding citizen would. She also felt helpless because not only had she been unable to find the answers to the questions she had, because the local police station was closed until the following Tuesday, but also when she did manage to get to talk to someone she was informed that ‘they had received information from the public’. Being a resident of a very small town, the raid was witnessed by many and the ensuing gossip was devastating. If she were guilty of any offence I would be among the many to condemn her. However, for someone who is innocent this would have been an extraordinarily humiliating ordeal, regardless of the truth of the--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Please stop the clock. Member for Nanango, can you advise me that charges have not been laid as a result of this?
Mrs PRATT: No, they have not.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Thank you.

Mrs PRATT: I would not be bringing it up if they had. Regardless of the truth, in the town she is now looked upon as a possible drug manufacturer or dealer because, as the saying goes, there is no smoke without fire.

The major concern is that the constituent is now on record for having her home raided by the police because they believed they had sufficient evidence to cast doubt about her activities and a record will be triggered every time the police get suspicious of drugs in the area. After talking with police, my constituent wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I have taken home the impression that the evidence was my purchase of Chemists’ Own sinus and hayfever tablets. Apparently these can be used to manufacture the drug the police were looking for. Because I have to keep using this medication, I can probably expect to be searched regularly.
XML.Hansard-Body: I find it is somewhat worrying that the legal purchase of medication can trigger such serious police action. The fight against crime should not be as intolerable as the crime itself. This constituent abhors drugs and understands that drug proliferation must be fought at every turn. However, it is regrettable that people get swept along and caught up in the mess. Surely they are not guilty until they are proven to be guilty, and if she cannot be proven guilty my constituent needs an apology.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The time for private members’ statements has expired.
Resumed from 15 April (see p. 1464), on motion of Ms Boyle--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr HOBBS (Warrego--LNP) (12.09 pm): I rise today to speak on the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. This is an historical bill insofar as the current City of Brisbane Act is 86 years old. Brisbane City was proclaimed a municipality in September 1859, over 151 years ago. That is quite a long time ago.

Brisbane is our capital city and we love it. Brisbane, I believe, is a very liveable city, and we have grown to like it, to love it and to understand the parts of it that are so important to us. Of course much has changed over the years in the development of this great city. I can recall coming in here in the seventies and the smog would be over the city from the burning of wood fires, wood stoves and suchlike, and that has all changed. The river itself has changed. It is a lot cleaner. Conditions in relation to stormwater run-off and that type of thing have certainly improved the quality of the environment around our city.

The lack of infrastructure is an issue that dogs every city, some worse than others. I think here in this state, and certainly in Brisbane, the lack of infrastructure has caused a lot of heartache for a lot of people. We have recently been through a water shortage, with water restrictions and expensive pipelines put in place, and that has been an enormous burden on the public. It has also been an enormous cost when you consider the ramifications of that rushed infrastructure. It was certainly necessary but very, very costly to the end user.

The state population policy is an issue that I will cover soon. I do not believe that we have managed that well. We have not understood the real implications of the population boom that we have had and the needs of the community and the importance of putting in place infrastructure to manage the increasing number of people and the changing lifestyles. I congratulate Campbell Newman and his LNP team--and in fact all of the councils over many, many years--that have put a big effort into improving Brisbane, improving the livability of this great city. I commend the foresight of the recent council with the building of tunnels--obviously we have to go underground now. It would have been far better if we had made the roads much wider and had a lot more foresight, but that is the way cities are built. There will certainly be improved traffic flow once the tunnels are all completed. The CityCat has also been a wonderful service provided to our commuters, our visitors, our tourists, and the general commerce of the city.

Brisbane City is the largest provider of local government services in this state, with 26 councillors and the mayor. So it is a significant local government--I believe with its budget it is probably bigger than Tasmania. It certainly has a lot of differences in relation to other local governments across this state. The Queensland Constitution establishes a Queensland system of local government, and the local government system sustains the social fabric of our communities. As I mentioned, these communities are experiencing rapid change. The Constitution that we have recognises local government. I would like to see local government further recognised in our Constitution--and in fact entrenched in our Constitution so that governments in the future cannot change too much about local government without at least having a review by the people of Queensland. I think that is something we can reconsider down the track.

With these rapid changes and the need for us to have the legislation that we are dealing with today, we need to understand the challenges that we have for the future. With our population studies, we need to understand where we are going. Over the past 40 years the population has grown at an average annual rate of 1.4 per cent per annum, taking the overall Australian population to 22 million in 2010. Over the next 40 years, the rate of population growth is expected to slow to 1.2 per cent on average per annum. In 2010, there will be an estimated five people of traditional working age for every person aged 65 and over. By 2050, only 2.7 people of traditional working age are projected for every person aged 65 years and over. There is going to be a significant change in the age of our people. We have an ageing population and we need to have the infrastructure to manage that change.

Challenges to population growth can be managed provided governments continue to plan well ahead of time for infrastructure, housing and service delivery needs. The important thing is that in Brisbane itself the population growth, by selected local government areas, is quite high. From 2003 to 2008, Brisbane had a percentage growth of 1.8 per cent. There are higher growth rates throughout the state, the likes of Mackay, Gladstone, Cairns and of course the Fraser Coast, which is screaming along at 3.9 per cent. So there are significant population increases throughout other parts of the state. But Brisbane itself is what we are dealing with today. Even that 1.8 per cent is still a significant increase that we need to be able to manage.

Population forecasts for Queensland, taking into account likely job growth and demand for migration from elsewhere, suggest that by 2031 total state population will be in the order of 6.3 million and the South-East Queensland population will be in the order of 4.2 million. So we are likely to have 4.2 million here in the south-east corner. Such forecasts will lead to concerns, especially among parts of the population of South-East Queensland, that continued population growth in the state or at least in the south-east is not sustainable, and the quality of life of Queenslanders is reducing as the pressure of growth demands new and challenging growth management measures.

Clearly we have to have a good population policy. I know some work has been done in recent times. The LGAQ instigated a study. The government has talked about its growth summit and so forth. So it is on the agenda. But the reality is that we have to have a really good policy, not just words. We need to have something that really works. Effective monitoring of land and housing supply and demand is essential to identify where there is a need for government intervention or initiatives to enhance affordability. That is certainly an issue that we need to consider. There is also enormous industrial growth, particularly in other parts of the state, with minerals and petroleum.

Government changes have caused a lot of concern to local governments across this state and the Brisbane City Council is no different. In a lot of ways I do not think we have been able to manage that change well. There certainly has not been a lot of consultation in the past with local governments about change. This bill before the House today is probably an exception where there has been considerable consultation and, believe it or not, pretty much universal agreement in relation to this bill. That is very welcome. It can be done. It is easy to do if you do it right. If governments want to go out there and try to bulldoze their way through, there are going to be repercussions down the track. Eventually it just will not work because if governments have not consulted correctly then they have not done the job right and that will result in bad legislation.

The amalgamations across the state were not handled well. The subsidy withdrawal was announced in the budget last year and it is certainly shown in this year’s budget, where this is the last year for a lot of those water and subsidy grants that were available to local governments. This will have an enormous impact on local governments and it will have other flow-on consequences. This bill itself talks about long-term planning, yet we have governments that keep on changing the rules. I think that is very hard. How can local governments possibly plan ahead when the major component of their funding is in fact changed? It was changed last year virtually overnight. Those are some very important issues that we need to acknowledge.

The bill establishes and provides the powers, responsibilities, obligations and requirements for Brisbane’s system of local government. This bill again is principles based legislation. It focuses on outcomes and develops the local government’s own operational procedures and processes. Basically, we will have a smaller bill and we will have more regulations. It is very important that those regulations are tested. I understand they will all come into being on 1 July this year, which is not very far away, and I understand that those regulations are being tested. We need to ensure that the regulations work well. We have to trust that is happening, and I understand that it is. We hope there is a high level of compliance in relation to principles based legislation.

The bill before the House covers a wide range of local government activities and responsibilities, and I will try to touch on a few of those. The bill maintains the Brisbane City Council as a body corporate, which of course is good and that is how it should be. Other councils in Queensland have not got that status. It was taken away from them for a political reason and it certainly should not have been. They should have that corporation status returned to them.

The bill mentions the power to conduct joint local government activities. Of course we have our ROCs, our Council of Mayors, and other entities that are important for a city like Brisbane, and they need to be able to carry on that work. The bill covers the responsibilities of councillors, and that is important as well. Councillors make up a collection of elected members that constitute the council’s executive arm. The council appoints a CEO to implement the decisions of the executive arm by overseeing the work of officers of the council in the administrative arm.

The mayor’s responsibilities include being the agent between the executive and officers of the council by directing the CEO and senior contract employees. This is a model that has been used across the state. To a certain degree, it is hard to change from that but there are some problems with this that I would like to quickly deal with in the House today. At the end of the day, councillors are elected and they need to be able to deliver the type of local government that their people want. It is often difficult if there is a bunch of bureaucrats, I suppose you could call them, in there who cannot shift from their certain views. I am not saying that councils are trying to go outside the law or whatever the case may be, but the reality is that at the end of the day the elected officials should be able to deliver a local government that the people in their area want, not necessarily what some people within the departments think they should have.

There are some rumblings out there in Queensland that councillors are starting to believe that they are being snowed, that they are not being told the full facts. I think there will be ramifications of that down the track, so we need to watch this space to ensure that we fully understand where we are going with this.

The bill details the responsibilities of councillors, including the mayor, who must have a strategic approach, similar to a board of directors. That is okay in principle, but as I said before, I think there could be some issues with that which we need to watch. It is incumbent on the CEO to develop with the mayor a very good working relationship. That is often the secret in these situations. If there is a good working relationship between particularly the CEO and the councillors, then things can run a lot more smoothly. If there is conflict, there are often many problems. The bill also deals with wards. There are 26 wards and if there is any change to that, it has to come before the parliament. That seems to be quite a good way to deal with that.

There is some controversy in relation to the powers of the Establishment and Coordination Committee, and I will deal with that later. This bill actually recognises that committee. It gives statutory recognition to the committee that is presently a standing committee of council. In relation to the chairperson of the council, the bill recognises the parliamentary nature of council and recognises the appointment by resolution of a chairperson of the council to preside at all council meetings. It is different to what other councils have, so I think it is important we fully understand that.

The bill deals with the local law-making process, and that is particularly important. Councils need to ensure that their local laws reflect the opinions of their communities. The minister has the right to oversee those local laws and will advise if they can proceed. Those laws must satisfy any conditions imposed by the minister to ensure the overall state interest is dealt with satisfactorily. Also, councils have to ensure they do a regular review. I was a councillor and chairman for a long time, and these things can often slip by and councils do end up with some very old local laws that certainly get a bit behind. It is important that they are regularly updated.

There are a number of other issues dealt with in the bill, including a councillor’s discretionary funds. This issue has made the news in recent times.
