These have to be clearly defined and must be used only as prescribed in a regulation. Councillors should recognise that it is important they make sure they do this right. Another matter is that the chief executive officer is not subject to direction. Again, the mayor must have a good working relationship with the chief executive officer. It is important that occurs.

The bill deals with the qualifications of councillors. A person who wants to stand for council must be a resident of and a registered elector in Brisbane and not be disqualified based on any other clause, which can be bankruptcy or other issues. It is particularly important that they are able to do that. One element which is wrong in the legislation--and this is a philosophical debate between both sides of the House--is that if you are applying to be a member of the Queensland parliament you cannot remain in local government. In fact, you can stand for the federal parliament and not lose your job as a councillor. We know the reason why that is the case--that is, the majority of councillors who come into parliament are conservative. Anyway, that is the way it is and we will change that one day. I think local government is a good grounding for parliamentarians because they know the process. We also get far better quality parliamentarians. It can be done.
Government members interjected.
Mr HOBBS: If those opposite had been councillors they would understand things a bit more.

An issue that has caused a lot of controversy is giving direction to council staff. This is an issue that we need to be talk about a bit. I agree with the fact that you cannot have everybody giving directions. Directions have to come from the mayor and CEO and then go down the line. At the end of the day, we need to make sure that this works effectively.

As I mentioned before, there is an issue that I want to cover that is particularly controversial. That is the amendments to the Right to Information Act. People need to be aware that councils like cabinets are able to put information aside for 10 years so it cannot be viewed. That provision has always been there in relation to committee work. It has been extended now to include the budgetary process and extended to all councils in this state. I do not think it necessarily needs to cover the whole state but it will. I am agreeing to this on the basis that the councils are now so big that they probably do need this provision. With smaller councils they do not need to restrict information. Once we have councils as big as the Brisbane City Council that are basically political they need to have a reasonable working structure that allows them to get on with their job without a sideshow going on and people trying to disrupt the process. That does happen.

It is important that the information is still provided. I would encourage many of the councils throughout the state not to use this provision. They do not have to if they do not want to. It is up to them. If they need to use this provision then it is there for them.

There are a lot of provisions in this bill that we could talk about for a long time. However, the time for the consideration of this bill is restricted, which is disappointing. We should be able to allow all members of the parliament to debate the bill in detail. This is a major bill that will impact on a lot of ratepayers. A lot of members of this parliament represent people in this great city of Brisbane. It is important that they talk about the issues that are important to them.

This bill is basically an update of the existing legislation which uses modern terms. As I said, the consultation has been effective. I think this legislation will go all right, and I certainly hope it does. The Brisbane City Council is a good council. It is one that is progressing well. There is certainly a lot more work to do. I wish them all the best in that regard.

Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (12.33 pm): I want to make a short contribution to the City of Brisbane Bill that is being debated here today. It has often been said, and I am sure will continue to be said, that local government is the layer of government that is closest to the people, is the most involved in the delivery of services to the people and affects people most in their day-to-day lives. I speak with a degree of knowledge of the Brisbane City Council having spent six years in that place--four of them under a Labor administration--
Mr Hinchliffe: Four of the best years.

Mr NICHOLLS: I will deal with some of the history as well for the member for Stafford’s illumination. I had three years under Campbell Newman and the Liberal-Labor administration. The detail that we are dealing with here today is in relation to the administration and administrative principles that apply to the legislation about the constitution of the City of Brisbane.

It is interesting when we look back at the history of the City of Brisbane to see the arguments that were put forward in the early part of the 20th century about why we should have a greater city of Brisbane and a City of Brisbane council. It was really a debate that was carried out in the newspapers of the time. The Moreton Bay Courier and others were very strong advocates of creating a greater Brisbane city council.

The bill before us today replaces the City of Brisbane Act 1924--the original piece of legislation. Those members who have had the necessity or the pleasure to plough through its pages would certainly have learnt a lot about the improvements in drafting of legislation over the last 90-odd years and a lot about how lawyers can charge so much money for making so little sense out of something that is so convoluted. This bill replaces that act and incorporates some regulations from 2004 which sought to update that act. This bill will bring the local law-making process up to speed and reflect modern drafting practices and modern terminology.

This bill also deals with some aspects of the Local Government (Chinatown and Valley Malls) Act and the Local Government (Queen Street Mall) Act which were special parts of the legislation brought in to allow the council to do certain things, including building the Queen Street Mall--that great success which was started under a Labor administration. No-one would quibble with the outcomes of that. The Valley Mall and the Chinatown Mall might be subject to more contentious contemporary debate but anyone who has been to the Chinatown Mall would agree that the outcome is a big improvement over what was a tired and rundown mall. The process of getting there was perhaps a little longer than most people would have liked.

The original City of Brisbane Act 1924 merged the cities of Brisbane and South Brisbane--the towns of Hamilton, Ithaca, Sandgate, Toowong, Windsor and Wynnum and the shires of Balmoral, Belmont, Coorparoo, Enoggera, Kedron, Moggill, Sherwood, Stephens, Taringa, Tingalpa, Toombul and Yeerongpilly--to form the current city of greater Brisbane. Can members imagine if we had all those shires and towns operating today? In the confined area of Brisbane, it would be a very different outcome to what we see today.
Mr Hinchliffe interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: In fact it is not. It is completely different. The member for Stafford, who is also someone who has had some long-term experience with the Brisbane City Council in a prior life, can try to twist words as much he likes, but the reality is that we are talking about the history of the creation of the City of Brisbane in 1924, not the cold-hearted manipulation and destruction of communities that was undertaken by Labor in 2006 and 2007 without any consultation, without any public debate and without any public input. The City of Brisbane was the result of 20 years worth of debate, consideration and consultation. The amalgamation of local authorities under Labor in 2007 was the result of the storm troopers coming in in jackboots and saying, ‘We are going to do it this way and we are not going to give you a chance to say a word about it.’

There was a process in place, which people often forget, that we on this side supported in relation to the shape, size and sustainability of councils. That process was thrown out the window after October 2006 by the Labor government. That was a proper process that was leading to a rationalisation of councils and authorities throughout the state. It had buy-in by those local authorities and by the Local Government Association. It is quite a different set of circumstances. For the member for Stafford to say that there is any similarity between the creation of the City of Brisbane and the cold-hearted actions of the Labor Party in destroying communities under its amalgamation program four years ago is completely and utterly wrong.

The other issue that is interesting is that when Brisbane was formed it was formed as a greater city. That in fact means that the mayor is not just a mayor but a lord mayor and is entitled to the use of the honorific, the right honourable, which puts it in line with cities like Manchester and London in the United Kingdom. This goes back to, I guess, the formation of cities and the creation of aldermen under the Danelaw dating back to 900 or so.

There is a great deal of history in some of the names that we use today and in some of the terminology that we use. I think it is good to keep some of that terminology so we understand that where we are today is as a direct result of many hundreds of years of the rights of cities to govern and control themselves. I think that is important, because certainly Brisbane’s right to govern and control itself is of vital importance and we know that the people of Brisbane want that to be the case.

The new city council replaced the 20 local authorities and reduced the number of aldermen and councillors from 205 to 26. Brisbane was one of the first cities--in fact, it might have been the first local authority in Australia--to establish a town planning department to deal with issues relating to town planning. I suspect that, in terms of dealing with town planning matters, nothing has got any easier from 1926 through to 2010. In fact, there are a number of good books around about the history of Brisbane. In terms of north Brisbane, in my part of the world, there are some very good books about complaints when blocks of land were carved up from 10 acres down to one-acre blocks and then from one-acre blocks down to half-acre blocks and then half-acre blocks down to 32 perches and then down to 16 perches. It is a continual theme and we need to be big enough to understand the history of change and the difficulties that councils have in adapting to change. And of course, the strategies that councils have in terms of dealing with change have also improved and been made better so that people feel less like it is being imposed from on top and more like they are having a say in determining their own outcomes, as indeed they are.

Unlike councils in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide and Perth, where the local councils are generally responsible only for a relatively small central business district, the City of Brisbane covers a large area and administers a larger part of the Brisbane metropolitan area and has a larger population than any other local government area in Australia. In fact, the population of the Brisbane City Council is roughly equivalent to the populations of Tasmania, the ACT and the Northern Territory combined and also has, commensurately, a budget to match. The council administers a budget of over $3 billion. On that note, we will be getting details of the Brisbane City Council budget delivered by Lord Mayor Campbell Newman this morning. In fact, if it follows prior history, it will no doubt be a ripsnorter of a budget that will deliver outcomes in spades for the people of Brisbane--as it has done in a way that up until 2004 they were unaccustomed to receiving.

When I look at the history of this legislation and what this bill does, I think it is great that this bill recognises Brisbane as the capital city of the state of Queensland, and it makes that particular recognition in clause 3. It has a clear update of the language. Earlier I made mention of the tortuous language that was used in the legislation in 1924, which was subsequently really changed each time there was an amendment made to the legislation.

The bill clearly makes provision for what is called the Establishment and Coordination Committee. In this legislation it is called the ECC, but those of us who have been there know it as E&C--that is, if you like, the civic cabinet of the Brisbane City Council made up of the chairs of each of the other committees which meet on a regular basis to conduct the business of the city under the guidance and supervision of the Lord Mayor. It is effectively an essential part of the City of Brisbane. If it had not been recognised, I am sure anyone who would have cared to seek some sort of judicial review would have found that implicit in the operation of the City of Brisbane is the operation of the Establishment and Coordination Committee. So this effectively, if you like, gives in writing recognition to what would have been recognised in all of the circumstances anyway--that is, the Establishment and Coordination Committee of city cabinet.

The bill also makes provision for the position of chairman of the council. In much the same way as this parliament has a Speaker who controls--or tries to--the conduct of debate between both sides of the House--
A government member interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: I mean no disrespect to the chair in those circumstances. Nonetheless, the chairman of council also directs the flow of business of council. That position gives the call to councillors and provides for the flow and conduct of the administration of the council chamber and the business on the council Notice Paper .
Mr Hinchliffe interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: Like I have seen in this parliament, I have seen many chairs with whom I have had numerous debates and discussions, as it should be in any democracy. However, recognition of the formal chair of council is also an implicit recognition of the political nature of the Brisbane City Council. When the Brisbane City Council was originally set up, it was also of course the intention of the then Labor Party that was in power in Queensland that it would stroll into control of the Brisbane City Council. We see the thought process--that is, that it will establish the council and then its nominee will stroll in and take over the mayoralty and win the wards. In fact, that did not happen and we have a bridge named after Sir William Jolly, who in fact won, much to the chagrin and despair of the Labor Party, which thought it would be able to manipulate council and get its own man in. I guess there is a lesson about trying to manipulate the Brisbane City Council and I guess both sides of politics have learned that lesson. It was learned by this side of politics in the 1970s when it tried to change the way the council elected its mayor and its aldermen. However, I have to say that probably the best friend that the then mayor, Clem Jones, had in state parliament was the Liberal Party Treasurer at the time who made sure that funding was provided in spades for the establishment of green space and for the operation of that council and also the Powerhouse at New Farm.

We have the implicit understanding of the political nature of the Brisbane City Council, and it is a political council. There are two sides of politics, each with a contest of ideas that goes on. One side wins and one side loses and one side has the control--
Mr Hinchliffe: Even when it was the CMO.

Mr NICHOLLS: Even when it was the CMO, so we have had that nature of the council since its inception. The results of that, irrespective of whether you supported one side or the other, are in what we see in Brisbane today. That is, you have bridges that link up, you have roads that join up, you have decisions that have been able to be made collectively by a civic cabinet that are for the better interests of the whole of the city of Brisbane rather than individuals putting their hands up and screaming and fighting over some funds for their particular electorate. We are able to get that overarching type of application of the political overlay to deliver the efficiencies that are needed to run a city of the size of Brisbane with the population it has. The legislation does a good job in formally recognising the role of the City of Brisbane and the way it goes about doing that is clear. The bill uses clear language.

The other issue is in relation to the power of the mayor. In this respect, clause 14 relates to the responsibilities of councillors. In terms of those responsibilities of councillors, the very clear extra responsibilities of the mayor have been set out, and there is some value in doing that. After the 2004 election we ended up with an unusual provision. That is, I think it was the first time in the history of the City of Brisbane where the mayor was from one political party with a large--
Mr Hinchliffe: No, not quite.

Mr NICHOLLS: It was in my memory, anyway. We ended up in the situation where we had a Liberal Lord Mayor with a minority Liberal team supporting him on the floor and being able to pass votes and a Labor majority. There was argument in the early stages about what the legislation meant and what legally it could do. I think it involved lawyers and barristers and all sorts of threats in the early days, from memory. The reality, of course, is that it was always going to be worked out as a political solution and not a legal solution, but this legislation goes some way to clearing up the rights and responsibilities of the mayor and making sure that the mayor has some primacy in terms of dealing with the offices of council and budget.

What we have here is legislation that enshrines the strong mayor model. In terms of cities around the world which have a strong mayor model, the strong mayor model applies to Chicago which has the Daley inheritance and the Democrats who control a Labor town. Of course that is a strong model. There is Bloomberg in New York City, which has a strong mayoral model. You have a city council, but it is not as strong as the mayor and the executive power. You can contrast that to somewhere like Los Angeles, which has a mayor in name but who is someone without a lot of power. That is the weak mayor model where, if you like, the mayor’s executive action is fairly well constrained by his necessity to go back all of the time and seek approval from the council in order to do what he wants.

Here, quite clearly, the mayor’s powers are set out. When one looks at the history of Brisbane, certainly one sees that its history is of strong mayors. I do not think anyone would say that Clem Jones was anything but a strong mayor. I think he refused to give notices of meetings even to his own side on the basis that if you gave them notice of meetings and had them along it would only encourage them to ask more questions and he did not want to answer any from either side.

Certainly, I think Sallyanne Atkinson, a former Lord Mayor, was also a strong mayor and had a certain style about her. I do not think that anyone would ever dispute that Jim Soorley was someone who brooked too much opposition or too much argument in any way, shape or form and was certainly perceived to be a strong mayor. Those who have had dealings with Campbell--the current Lord Mayor--would say that he also has a very strong and firm vision for the city and knows in which direction he wants to take it. Those people are elected to do that. That is the whole point. So I think that the clarification of the rights, roles and responsibilities of the mayors and the councillors of the City of Brisbane is a worthwhile inclusion.

The legislation makes some changes. I think one that is slightly mystifying relates to carrying out beneficial activities for the City of Brisbane where investments are being sought to be made or enterprises are being sought to be entered into by the City of Brisbane with private enterprise. The legislation contains a provision that requires the council to seek the approval of the director-general before proceeding down an investment path. I would have to say that it strikes me as very, very odd that a council such as the Brisbane City Council has to go to the state government to seek approval to enter into beneficial enterprises with private enterprise. That seems particularly odd when we consider the strength of the Brisbane City Council’s balance sheet and its finances.

Between 2003-04 and 2009-10, the council’s budget capital spend has increased by 321 per cent and, unlike state Labor, that has been done by keeping debt under control. In 1993, under Labor, net debt peaked at $1.683 billion. Net debt will peak again in 2014 at $2.07 billion before the federal payment of $400 million. So before any funds or grants are received--
Government members interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: Mr Deputy Speaker, my, they are sensitive, are they not? Before any federal funds are received, debt per person is 14.8 per cent less in 2014 than it was in 1993. After the federal money is received, debt per person will be 31.5 per cent less in 2015 than it was in 1993. In that time--and I heard mention of infrastructure and what was being done--what has the Brisbane City Council done? It has completed the Eleanor Schonell Bridge at the University of Queensland, it has implemented nine new bus zone routes, it has introduced 450 low-floor air-conditioned compressed natural gas buses, it has completed the Clem Jones Tunnel, it has upgraded the Chinatown Mall for $8 million, it has a $1.2 Road Action Program, it is purchasing 500 new rigid equivalent buses over four years, it has invested $100 million for walking and cycling, it has a rapid transit scheme, it has six new CityCats over four years and new ferry terminals, it has almost completed construction of the Go Between Bridge and it has begun construction on the Hale Street link. That has all been done without going into the red in the way in which state Labor has done. So we can see that the need for the council to ask the state government for approval about how to spend its money is completely and utterly redundant. If we took the state government’s word on it, we would be going into the red, we would be going into deficit and people would be paying more and more.

I would also like to raise for the minister’s consideration the issue of clause 37, which relates to election signs. It is always a contentious issue. But all in all, I think that the legislation meets the needs of making governance for the City of Brisbane more reliable, simpler and clearer.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (12.53 pm): I rise to participate in the debate on the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. I understand the need to modernise the legislation that deals with the City of Brisbane, but one area of the bill that I intend to touch on briefly before lunch is part 4 of the bill, which makes amendments in relation to the Right to Information Act 2009. I understand that, as a result of the proposed amendments contained in this bill, these amendments will flow through in due course to other councils in Queensland.

We often hear calls for more open and transparent government. Sometimes when there are requests for information, unfortunately, the right to information is not able to be accessed because, in relation to the state government, the information might have been taken to cabinet. We are seeing adopted in this bill a similar proposal. Under these amendments, there will be similar opportunities for councils to say, ‘I am sorry, that information is restricted and it will not be available for 10 years.’

Councils have operated very effectively under the committee system and I do not believe that we need to move down the road of legislating new restrictions on the opportunity to access information to better understand deliberations that some councillors are making on matters that come before the council. I refer to part 4 of the bill. Clause 333(4) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Without limiting subsection (3), the Minister may make guidelines about a publication scheme of the Brisbane City Council requiring the scheme to set out that the council has available information of or about the council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those establishment and coordination committees will have the opportunity to exclude information so that it is not available to the public. This is a new direction for many councils. I think that, if the minister wants to go down this road, we need to set out very clearly better guidelines and better restrictions because I have a genuine concern that some councils and some councillors will realise that there is an opportunity to keep some important information out of the public arena by taking that information into this proposed new cabinet consideration.
I refer to the wide ambit of material that can be protected under this proposal contained in part 4. Clause 334 inserts a new subsection 4A, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (1) Information is exempt information for 10 years after its relevant date if--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: and there are whole range of options. The clause states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) it has been brought into existence for the consideration of the committee; or
(b) its disclosure would reveal any consideration of the committee or would otherwise prejudice the confidentiality of committee considerations or operations.
XML.Hansard-Body: Those provisions are very wide. I do not know how much wider the scope of those provisions could be extended. Then the clause lists a whole range of other matters that are excluded. I refer members to new subsection 3, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (3) Without limiting subsection (1), the following documents are taken to be documents comprised exclusively of exempt information under subsection (1)--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) committee submissions;
(b) committee briefing notes;
(c) committee agendas;
(d) notes of discussions in committee;
(e) committee minutes;
(f) committee decisions;
(g) a draft of a document mentioned in any of paragraphs (a) to (f).
XML.Hansard-Body: New subsection 4 then states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A report of factual or statistical information attached to a document mentioned in subsection (3) is exempt information under subsection (1) only if--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) its disclosure would have an effect mentioned in subsection (1)(b); or
(b) it was brought into existence for the consideration of the committee.
XML.Hansard-Body: By crikey, I think that is as wide a scope as possible for material. Then the proposed new section goes on to refer to the committees. The definition in the bill defines a committee as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the Establishment and Coordination Committee under the City of Brisbane Act 2010 and includes the Establishment and Coordination Committee, as constituted from time to time before the commencement of this section, under a local law of the council.
XML.Hansard-Body: Before I resume my seat, I urge the minister to reconsider the necessity for this part 4. I believe that councils have operated in the past very effectively without needing this new protection from the release of information that might be sought by the public. It is important to ensure that we have the best open and transparent local government in Queensland. I believe that this proposed amendment is not necessary. Councils would operate better without the opportunities to take important or sensitive information into their proposed committee system simply so that it remains out of the public arena for up to 10 years.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (12.58 pm): I rise to speak in support of the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. This bill gives formal legislative acknowledgement to Brisbane as the capital city of Queensland. And what a beautiful and vibrant city it is! Eighty-six years is a long time, but that is how old the City of Brisbane Act is. I believe that it is clearly in need of modernisation. The current act is definitely out of date for a progressive and fast growing city in 2010, especially one that seeks to be Australia’s new-world city.

Although Brisbane was proclaimed a municipality on 6 September 1859, Brisbane owes its status as Queensland’s capital city to custom rather than status authority. Nevertheless, I believe that Queenslanders know that Brisbane is our capital and this bill gives the legislative acknowledgement to Brisbane as our Queensland capital. It is the largest local government in Australia and so warrants this standard-alone legislation.

The bill recognises that, in comparison to other Queensland local governments, the Brisbane City Council--or the BCC--is unique because it is the largest provider of local government services in Queensland. There are 26 councillors, other than the Lord Mayor, who each represent the interests of residents of a ward. The mayor has a unique responsibility as the mayor of a capital city. The council has an establishment and coordination committee that coordinates its business. The chair of the council presides at all of its meetings and is responsible for ensuring that its rules of procedure are observed and enforced.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Ms GRACE:
Mr Deputy Speaker Powell, it is great to be speaking during your first time sitting in the chair as Deputy Speaker. I congratulate you. Well done. The bill retains and updates provisions unique to the BCC such as the wonderful City Botanic Gardens and river crossings as well as our lovely malls here in Brisbane. The bill also ensures, and I welcome, best-practice measures in public administration standards with emphasis on transparency, effective processes, democratic representation, open good governance and ethical and legal behaviour of councillors and council employees.

Brisbane ratepayers do expect and deserve a local council that is genuinely transparent, is responsive to public needs, practices social inclusion and whose processes are above reproach. I believe that this bill ensures this outcome. The BCC Establishment and Coordination Committee is recognised in the legislation because the committee is the peak body of the council and reflects the size and complexity of decision making made by the council.

The Establishment and Coordination Committee is what the BCC terms its civic cabinet, with similarities to state cabinet. The committee consists of the mayor and BCC standing committee chairs, who each have specific portfolio responsibilities. The committee often addresses sensitive issues such as employees’ remuneration and working conditions, water restrictions and contracts. Consequently, council can choose to withhold committee documents, such as minutes, from public release if doing so is not in the public interest. Information that has been brought into existence for the consideration of the BCC Establishment and Coordination Committee is exempt under the Right to Information Act 2009. Information that would reveal any consideration of the committee or would otherwise prejudice the confidentiality of committee considerations or operations is also excluded from right to information. Committee meetings are not open to the public, although committee reports are presented to an ordinary meeting of council for approval. Details of committee activities can then be included in council minutes which are published on the council website.

This bill also recognises the unique roles and responsibilities of the mayor. The City of Brisbane Act is largely based on the Local Government Act but with some differences. Similar to the principle of the separation of powers that operates at the Commonwealth and state levels of government, the bill makes clear the separate and distinct responsibilities of councillors, the mayor, the chief executive officer and council staff. It is the responsibility of all Queensland mayors to provide a visionary and strategic role in economic, social and environmental management.

The Brisbane mayor has additional responsibilities. The differences for the Brisbane mayor reflect the size and complexity of council organisation and decision making. The Brisbane mayor alone has powers to appoint the CEO and senior contract employees who are council’s senior executive service--I think that is most appropriate; prepare the budget for presentation to the council; chair the Establishment and Coordination Committee; and develop and implement new policies.

Equally important in this legislation are the roles and responsibilities of the CEO. BCC CEO responsibilities are legislated for the first time in this bill. The role of the town clerk is no longer necessary and so is not part of this legislation. Under the bill the CEO is clearly responsible for the appointment and direction of all staff, other than senior contract employees. This supports the separation of responsibilities between the executive arm and the administration arm of council and is essential to reinforcing the line management authority of the CEO. The bottom line is that this separation is a key feature of effective democratic governments.

Under the bill, council is required to publish annually the remuneration of the CEO and senior contract employees. This can be done by publishing the number of these most senior of contract employees within each remuneration band. In order to provide a level of flexibility, council staff, including the CEO, may be concurrently employed by more than one local government. Obviously this would be dependent on the size of the local council, workloads and their ability to fulfil the requirements of the position.

In closing, I also support new provisions in the bill that enable councillors from all sides of politics to better service their wards by providing them with rights to obtain and use information relevant to their wards. Obviously the bill includes provisions prohibiting misuse of such material and clarifies information that will not be available. I believe that this is a very important provision that will enable councillors to better service the wards they represent and not be unreasonably denied access to relevant and necessary information such as on a purely political basis. I commend the minister and staff and all stakeholders for their hard work and input in the development of this bill and I commend the bill to the House.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP)
(2.36 pm): In speaking to the City of Brisbane Bill, I thank the minister and her staff for the work that they have done both on the Local Government Act and the City of Brisbane Bill. It is something that has been near and dear to my heart after seeing the excesses that existed in my area under the former Livingstone shire council.

Similarly to the Local Government Act, the bill sets out definitions of material personal interest, conflict of interest--and I will speak to that--and council employee discipline and appeals. In relation to material personal interest, the Local Government Act carries virtually the same provisions. Councillors are required to make decisions in the interests of the community. In many cases they are a lot closer to the community and can be involved in some of those local organisations that deal with the council. They are required to disclose personal interests which may influence their voting. This includes any interest which may result in a direct benefit or loss to the council or a close associate. Personal interest offences occur when councillors fail to make this disclosure. For example, it could be a councillor voting to award their own company, or a company they own shares in, a contract with the council or a councillor voting to award a major council information and technology contract to a company of which the councillor’s wife is the owner. That originally was one of the bases for extending that definition in the Local Government Act, which will start from 1 July, and it will also be included in this bill.

It is not that anyone in the Brisbane City Council has actually done that, but because, as I said, of the local contact they really need to be fully aware of what a material personal interest is. For instance, I mentioned the former council for my area. It does become a real problem when the local mayor owns a business that contracts with the council to provide entertainment. That has actually continued under the new Rockhampton Regional Council. I trust that it will not occur under the Brisbane City Council actions.

Regardless of circumstances, any failure to disclose a material personal interest is actually official misconduct and would be referred by the CEO to the Crime and Misconduct Commission for investigation and prosecution. If found guilty, there can be a jail term of up to two years or a fine of up to 200 penalty units, which now amounts to $2,000. There is an exemption from MPIs for ordinary business matters. The bill covers a number of other acts. It contains some amendments that align the Local Government Act with the City of Brisbane Act.

I believe the biggest difficulty for material personal interest is the possibility of conflicts of interest arising. On the surface, conflicts of interest might not always appear to some people, although in some cases others have been well aware of it and they have always managed to arrange for it to benefit them. An example of that is if the council was making a decision about a grant to upgrade a football club building and a councillor was a member of that club. Another example would be if a councillor’s wife was the member of a netball team that had applied for a lease on a sporting field. If a councillor identifies a conflict of interest, then they are required to disclose the interest and leave the meeting. If there is uncertainty, they can notify the meeting and the remaining councillors have to decide whether or not a conflict of interest in fact exists. If they decide that it does, the councillor must then leave the meeting. A failure to disclose is an official misconduct and is required to be referred to the Crime and Misconduct Commission for investigation.

One thing that prevents this sort of thing occurring is the register of interests. As every one of us knows, we have to disclose our personal interests and those of our spouses. Certainly the extension of disclosure to include other members of the family, in both the Local Government Act and the City of Brisbane Act, takes it a little bit further than the imposition on us parliamentarians. However, as I said, the nature of a lot of dealings really requires that that be done. I do not know whether it is a conflict of interest if a councillor who makes decisions about rates has declared the value of their property wrongly. It might be worthwhile for the CEOs to look closely at the councillors who sit on those councils. I am aware of one who has made a declaration as to value and receives a rates adjustment. That sort of thing has to be stamped out in councils throughout the state.

I note that the member for Clayfield mentioned the formation of the City of Brisbane and how that was different to the amalgamation of councils throughout the state. In actual fact, that was 90 years ago and it was fairly acrimonious at the time. I think the proof of the pie is in the eating. Ninety years down the track, it works well for the City of Brisbane and I believe that under the new Local Government Act the rest of the state will operate in a similar way.

Another area that I would like to cover is employee discipline and appeals. Apart from senior executives, the CEO of the council is responsible for appointing council staff and they are the ones who can direct and take disciplinary action. When the disciplinary action will be taken and what type will be prescribed by regulation. The bill also amends the Local Government Act to insert the same clause and bring the two together. This aligns the BCC employees’ discipline matters with other local government employees in the state Public Service and could offer considerable advantages to council staff compared to the current arrangement. The Department of Infrastructure and Planning will continue to work closely with stakeholders to develop a regulation that balances the rights of employees with the needs of the council and, obviously, the needs of the community. In all other respects, the bill actually updates the operations of the City of Brisbane. Additional regulation will be provided once the bill becomes an act of this parliament. Hopefully, the Brisbane City Council will continue to operate in the way it has for the past 90 years. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (2.44 pm): Mr Deputy Speaker, may I also offer my congratulations to you on your first occasion in the chair. I think it is great that an opposition member has been included on the panel of temporary speakers.
Ms Grace: Let’s not go too far.
Ms DAVIS: You do some things right.

I rise to speak to the City of Brisbane Bill 2010, which was introduced by the Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Partnerships on 15 April 2010. Local governments are an autonomous, efficient and accountable system of government. They respond to community needs to enhance the quality of life in metropolitan, regional and remote areas, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait island communities. I believe that relations between state, federal and local government should be conducted in a spirit of mutual respect with an emphasis on partnerships and cooperation. It is for this reason that I would like to recognise the degree of cooperative consultation between local government services and the Brisbane City Council in the drafting of the bill being debated today.

I understand that Brisbane City Council had a few reservations regarding some aspects of the draft bill that was circulated in March 2010, but that following meetings between council officers and the department the provisions of the bill are generally supported by the current administration at City Hall. During this consultation, stakeholders asked that the bill facilitate efficient, accountable and effective governance and service delivery. Clear expectations and high standards about transparent decision making, inclusive community consultation practices and local government performance are addressed and the groundwork appears laid for a sensible but more adaptable approach to enterprises, partnerships of many secure kinds, and sustainable financial arrangements and accountability.

This bill seeks to strengthen and support the largest local government area in Queensland and gives Brisbane City Council the capacity and flexibility to serve the people of Brisbane, including the residents in the Aspley electorate which falls wholly within the Brisbane City Council boundaries. Brisbane is a youthful and enthusiastic city, spanning city to bay and hills to bush. It is appreciated by residents and visitors for its friendliness and optimism, and respected for its leadership and achievements. In 1859 Brisbane was declared a municipality, a city with its own local government. Indeed, my husband’s great-great grandfather, William Pettigrew, was one of the people who signed the petition seeking the declaration of the municipality and was later a long-serving alderman and mayor. Therefore, the history of this city has a special resonance within our family. The first aldermen were men who had helped to establish Brisbane as a hub for development and the councillors who serve today are still building Brisbane as the commercial centre of Australia’s northern development.

In 1925, the Queensland state parliament passed the City of Brisbane Act, establishing a single government in Brisbane, replacing about 20 local authorities and joint boards. The current number of councillors, which is to be set firmly as the number of wards in this new bill, was established at 26, replacing some 200 aldermen for the same Brisbane area. That was an efficiency gain which appears to make recent local government amalgamations a simple political act. Today, Brisbane’s leadership in civic governance under Campbell Newman delivers active and healthy communities, drives a strong economy, sustains a clean and green environment, has created a city of cultural vibrancy and has provided an enduring legacy of liveability for future generations. Moreover, the current Brisbane administration has spurred this state government into long overdue action on resolving the transport gridlocks in the city.

We have been generally well served in the past by lord mayors of all persuasions with their unique brands of leadership and governance styles. But as we progress it is important that Brisbane, as our state capital, moves with current best practices in governance. That is why I am pleased to see that the bill incorporates a principles based approach, a chief executive officer with defined responsibilities, and requirements for long-term financial planning and reporting.

This principles based approach will hopefully give Brisbane the flexibility to build on its current policies, operational procedures and processes, and also make the new legislation more user-friendly for council employees, residents and ratepayers. Guiding legislation needs to be user-friendly for council employees because our Brisbane is facing new pressures and challenges as we move into the future. Every year, more and more people call Brisbane home. We face the challenges of securing sustainable water supplies, managing for people movement and maintaining Brisbane as a highly desirable place to live. It is, however, a substantial task to manage our current and future challenges--and that is why it is important that councillors understand their roles and responsibilities as they strive to ensure better outcomes for our residents.

Indeed, better outcomes for residents in the Aspley electorate are being delivered every day because in our part of the world we are represented by ‘can-do’ councillors. Councillor Amanda Cooper in Bracken Ridge ward, Councillor Norm Wyndham in McDowall ward, and Councillor Fiona King in Marchant ward are the councillors who every day are at the coalface of service delivery to our residents--delivering better outcomes through their unique brands of servant leadership. Each of them brings their own particular spark to our patch, and I want to put on the record my thanks to them and their office support staff for making themselves available at any opportunity to work together with me in tackling local issues.

One of those local issues that we now face together, with a distinct lack of cooperation from the state government, is dealing with the local impacts of ULDA developments. Brisbane has already been tasked to find the planning space for another 150,000-plus people. Given its size and organisational capacity, Brisbane is well placed to respond to this challenge with development planning that provides integrated solutions worked up through local neighbourhood planning processes.

I will end my contribution by saying that this unfortunately contrasts with the ULDA development process implemented by the state government whereby development sites--of particular interest to Aspley residents is the proposed high-rise development of the QUT Carseldine campus playing fields--are chosen merely because vacant land exists within state ownership, rather than through any coordinated or integrated approach to urban planning. In these developments, Brisbane City has no effective input and is merely left to try to deal with all the boundary impacts of these developments, which include substantial traffic impacts, loss of suburban character, and loss of suburban green space. It is a shame that the state government could not take a leaf out of the Brisbane City Council book.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (2.52 pm): I would like to focus on the outcomes of the processes of the bill. Everything else has been well covered by other speakers. This is a bill that represents the wishes of the incumbent Brisbane City Council in part. There have been reports in the local press that possibly raise concerns about accountability of the councillors. It would seem that these issues raised may have been emotional and sensational rather than addressing practicality.

Brisbane is the third largest city in Australia and will be the second largest within 10 years. The Brisbane City Council is the largest council in the world--certainly Australia’s largest--and its budget is currently larger than South Australia’s operating budget. This claim, as extraordinary as some may believe it to be, is true because of the size of the Brisbane City Council’s current road, bridge, busway and urban renewal program. Moreover, it is due to the growth of the city beyond its 2.5 million current inhabitants. With growth comes demand for infrastructure, major new city planning and major spending related to higher population densities where previously there were fewer people per square metre.

Brisbane as a city is not just moving beyond splitting the old 32-perch block into 16 perches and building sixpacks on amalgamated blocks but also moving to become a city where the latest Sunday Mail report on 23 May is proposing unlimited height densities in the city, eight storeys at Wynnum, 30 storeys in the Valley including New Farm, 20 storeys on the south side, 10 storeys at Chermside and five storeys amazingly at Coopers Plains. We have gone beyond duplexes, semidetached and battleaxe developments. Brisbane is becoming a very diverse city that is going to test both the public and the governments in the next 20 years as Brisbane’s population more than doubles. I say ‘governments’ because all levels of government--local, state and federal--will need to be involved. The Brisbane City Council act was drafted initially in 1859 but then the amalgamations came in 1925. Uniquely, it is a local government with its own separate state legislation. On reflection, this was probably a very sensible decision by a forward-thinking government of the day. We have ended up with a very good result from that decision.

Brisbane’s urban sprawl, as homeowners and prospective homeowners are in ever-growing numbers, is growing still. The South East Queensland Regional Plan does make amendments to cater for far higher inner-urban density, infill development, urban renewal and better land utilisation. What the plan really cannot do is completely limit further urban sprawl that really is former satellite communities in different councils growing by virtue of the increased flexibility of the regional councils and their proximity to Brisbane. Improved transport corridors, better passenger rail and bus links to Brisbane and some decentralisation out of the city drives that. Without doubt, we are almost at the point where Brisbane is SEQ central, with the Gold Coast, Ipswich, Jimboomba, Beaudesert, Caboolture, Redcliffe and Redlands all merging as outer Brisbane.

The impact of this is that not much has changed in the wider perspective, but the act affecting Brisbane needs considerable adaptation because of these changes. It would seem that, in spite of many attempts at trying to drive change in Brisbane by town planning task forces, urban renewal groups and road construction, the end result has been that the mixed effects of market forces, opportunity, evolution and tribalism have driven those changes.

Overwhelmingly, cost has been the major driver of change. Decentralisation appears to have been only marginally successful due to the mixed effect of individuals unwilling to move them or their families from the communities where they grew up and those in middle management being influential within their organisations, driven by the perception of negative impacts on their careers to move to outer-lying areas. In Brisbane, housing that has been built primarily near these larger industrial areas has a very mixed history, and the bill addresses those points.

Brisbane, like its railway system, is very much a city of determined provincial urban families. The metropolitan rail network has one western link to Ipswich through Indooroopilly and Chelmer, a northern line to Caboolture and the Sunshine Coast, a north-eastern line to Shorncliffe, a southern line to the coast and a south-eastern line to Cleveland. Only the eastern suburbs are not uniquely linked, but the river and Moreton Bay are their own critical links. The public in all of these communities are historically likely to wish to live near siblings, parents and friends. Policy of local government, particularly within the bill, needs to relate strongly to the considerable effects of these trends.

Incoming residents to the city are diverse and may pursue the same great Australian dream of homeownership, and the bill addresses that. There is a trend of empty nesters moving into the city into high-rise buildings. Family size is decreasing and there are fewer relatives to lean on. There is a major reticence to go into dependent care for the elderly, who tend to stay on too long living in their homes. This then causes an overhang in the market. But there are changes linked to both divorce and intergenerational change which are also having a significant impact on inner-city living.

The BCC act needs to be reflective of the changes that are occurring in the market. It would appear that the Labor state government is overly focused on its own needs rather than on the outcomes required by Brisbane residents. This is not only regrettable but may potentially be a serious error. The evidence for this statement is the two recent decisions of the incumbent state government and a further review of the SEQ plan itself. The first is the failure to correct the lack of links between the eastern suburbs, the bayside, the northern suburbs and the city with Teneriffe and New Farm. The second is the recent announcement of the conceptually flawed cross-river rail link, which merely moves the bottleneck to either side of the river from the Merivale Bridge for five years at best. This $8.5 billion plan opposes all other major international best practice metropolitan transport solutions. All other major cities of greater or comparable size and some of lesser size embrace circle lines which mirror ring-roads in the city. This is not radical thinking; this is the norm. The proposal here is clearly that the cross-river tunnel is in the wrong place.

The SEQ plan, which relates to this bill, and in significant part has been raised by the member for Aspley, was Labor’s grand statement on the future of SEQ. What has happened under Labor has been a consistent process of highly dubious approvals for developments that are exemptions to the SEQ plan. Much of this creep into both greenfield area and green zones is highly dubious at best and destructive at worst. In between, it has placed intolerable demands on the current infrastructure plan and spend by the BCC that should never have occurred. When one adds the failed council amalgamation strategies in surrounding areas, particularly with regard to the Scenic Rim, one sees that it then has an impact which has to be picked up within the BCC plan.

The current proposal to promote the idea of proportional representation of councillors in regional councils outside Brisbane, rather than by a divisional election, will only compound the negatives of the amalgamation as it applies to Brisbane, particularly with regard to growth impediments and a focus on process over outcome. The flawed water grid is a clear example, particularly when it applies to the Brisbane solution.

The Brisbane City Council’s initiation of the original Airport Link was groundbreaking. The state then took it over and initiated BrisConnections, and I think the decision on that is out for the time being. If you compare the two plans, I think there is a significant difference. What I am saying is that there are two plans going on in South-East Queensland and the state is focusing on jingoistic name plans using the words ‘future proofing’ very frequently, whereas the BCC is focusing on needs and outcomes for everyday people. That is what the bill entrusts them to do. There can be no greater example of this than the cross-river tunnel at $8.5 billion for the state, and the comparison to the BCC’s Go Between Bridge and the Clem7 tunnel, particularly at a time when the Clem7 tunnel is receiving great criticism.

At the moment, 50 per cent of all existing freight movements continue out of the Hamilton wharves. Also, cattle and coal haulage trucks come in mass convoys through Toowoomba into the city from the north-west. However, the cross-river tunnel plan continues to move the freight through the city. The BCC has massively focused itself on linking the inner south to mass transport and the inner city commercial transport to effectively bypass the city at reasonable peak hours for a $5 billion expense. This means that the state government planning is focusing on maintenance of the status quo, whereas the BCC is focusing on the future and keeping pace with it. Fortunately, the existing act has delivered this change for Brisbane.

Honourable members may all falsely believe that none of these so-called distant, interrelated facts do tell the common story I have presented, but you all should reconsider, particularly those on government benches. The flaws in the theory that ‘if you build it, he will come’--which is from the famous movie Field of Dreams --are as follows: one, the building needs to be planned and be thought through with an economic and social impact assessment; two, the building needs to be real, not just hype talk advertising future projections or, worse still, a pack of lies; and, three, the building needs to be appropriate, whether this means energy efficient, comfortable, proportionate, affordable, et cetera.

The BCC act, as big as the bill is now, may not be appropriate for a capital city of Brisbane’s current size in a tropical climate in a First World country so close to Asia. Is the bill too prescriptive? Is there far too much emphasis on trying to limit the BCC because of fear? This is the concept of a state government becoming more irrelevant as local governments become more relevant. Is the problem that the size of the Brisbane council--it being almost like a state--makes the current Labor government feel threatened by the BCC, especially with a progressive, forward-thinking LNP mayor in Campbell Newman who has been a very agreeable fellow? Is local government taken seriously enough by the Labor government here in Queensland? Is it time for the state government to start taking the idea of partnerships between itself and the BCC more seriously?

Labor’s future--just like the incoming LNP government’s would be--is very much linked to the success or failure of Brisbane. So what do we need to see in the bill beyond those questions I have raised? We need maturity in relationships, and I think we need to look at Sydney and Melbourne. We need town planning, and this should be about thorough town planning because currently it is terrible, it is too slow and it is not progressive. We need to be creating families and we need to think about models of cohabitation. We need to reduce the idea of focusing on process over outcome. There needs to be easy transfer of title. There needs to be ease in sectioning off granny flats because of the intergenerational issues. We need to think about growing communities. We need to get those community feelings going again. We need to focus on community volunteering programs that lead to interconnection. The focus needs to be overwhelmingly on connections and not just on cars and transport, like with the current issue of tunnels. The other issue that could be reconsidered is the reinstating of trams. Light rail on the Gold Coast has been currently suggested and this may be an alternative for Brisbane.

There are a considerable number of process issues in the bill. There is the issue of building high-rise if you have to--that is, we are going upwards. Communities are having greater densities whether they like it or not. We need space for 156,000 new dwellings by 2031 and we need to cater for the 40,000 new residents. I had heard that figure was 50,000, but these discussions are about 40,000. We need to make the idea of the quarter acre block a redundant concept.

You might ask why this is of interest to the electorate of Gaven. The short answer is the micro-economics of globalism, economics, practicalities and commuters. Once the M1 was built, and in part the railway line to Robina initially on the Gold Coast, there was a direct link between Gaven via Nerang and Brisbane. It is indivisible. It exists for all the other areas I named earlier as well. There is a heavy emphasis on construction and there are people employed or contracting in my Gaven electorate, and there is also a high number of people currently employed in Brisbane but living a hinterland existence of bliss in my electorate. What occurs in Brisbane is of importance to my electors. This applies to many outer Brisbane regions, so what ticks in Brisbane has great significance beyond the city itself.

To analyse the bill in another way, this bill addresses population numbers, density and vertical solutions. It does not address connections, understanding communities, innovative state solutions, horizontal growth and the connections of those. I agree with the statement of opposition councillor Milton Dick in the Sunday Mail on 23 May, when he stated, ‘The plans had not lived up to their expectation of listening to residents’ concerns.’ He did not look to where the blockage was or was too afraid to state the obvious. The Labor government talks connections but delivers population and higher population density. This is short-term nonsense that only enriches the real estate speculative bank balances of Labor mates. It ultimately destroys communities.

Connections is about transport only in part, and cars are only a part of that. We need to link communities to one another. We need to build better links in communities. This bill is about Brisbane and talks about where it should start. The cross-river tunnel as proposed does not make sense. It is too deep at the Petrie Bight end of Edward Street to be cost effective and it replicates the transport connections we already have. There should be cross-river tunnels at Merivale Street under the existing Merivale Bridge and there should be a new tunnel between New Farm and Woolloongabba via Hawthorne. New Farm is all about urban renewal and high density and it has very limited transport options, as have the eastern suburbs.

An inner circle of trams should rotate around and link to the eastern suburbs at Park Road through South Bank and Merivale Street. There should be new tunnels through the city to take the load off the current existing network. The existing Ipswich, Gold Coast and Cleveland lines could then rotate around the loop, with the Gold Coast going straight through to the airport. The Cleveland line terminates at Ferny Grove currently and Ipswich terminates at Caboolture, but by utilising the loop configuration this would end.

So this is what the state Labor government should be doing, and this is what should be done with integration within the bill. It behoves a forward-thinking state government to get it right. To be fair, the minister seems to have followed the script given to her. Our futures are all collective. It must be strongly emphasised that if we get it right for Brisbane it will synergistically work for the state as well. If changes in the bill are a mixture of agreement to the less contentious issues, general agreement to the bulk of procedural issues and not enough flexibility on necessary changes needed for the future, then the bill is a failure. Maybe there is far too much status quo, with too much suburb after suburb hub and spoke sprawl included.

For those members who do wish for something greater for the state capital of Brisbane, it will not occur without some political pain for those on the government benches. Some of you are wondering what political pain that may be and fear the unknown. It is the very problem that confronts Labor and it is one that it alone created. It is that suburb after suburb blandness that drives the Labor machine, seat on seat constituency. It will be destroyed in part by the very things that are needed to resolve greater Brisbane’s problems.

For those government members who are looking to the future, if you embrace those changes your party has an equal chance of claiming the future back as your own. Just how many amongst the factions have the courage to put the public interest ahead of their own--I suspect the answer is too few.
Debate, on motion of Dr Douglas, adjourned.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, this morning the Leader of the Opposition gave notice of a motion relating to various aspects of the health department’s new payroll system and calling for the establishment of a royal commission. Later during question time I ruled two questions out of order that clearly related to matters relating to the health department’s payroll system.

The member for Callide, both after the second question had been ruled out of order and later after question time, raised points of order about the rulings and also raised the wider application of the rule as regards debate on legislation where there are notices of motions on the Notice Paper that deal with subjects that may be relevant to the legislation. Specific reference was made by the member to the possibility that current matters on the Notice Paper may mean that discussion on those subject matters may be prevented during debate on the appropriation bills later in the week.

Unfortunately, the rule of anticipation, although well known, is not well understood. The rule of anticipation is an ancient rule of procedure and its application in Westminster parliaments was once much wider and more strictly observed than in modern practice (see Erskine May 23 rd edition at 389 and Mareau and Montpetit 1 st edition at 476). According to the rule, proceedings could not anticipate a matter on the Notice Paper that was a more superior form of proceeding. Over the years the rule has been mitigated in Westminster parliaments so as to give the Speaker the discretion in its application, as it is a rule that if too strictly applied can lead to absurd results or disadvantage minorities. If the rule was unfettered, the simple expediency of giving a notice of motion on a subject matter would preclude lesser or equal proceedings such as questions.

Standing Order 231 contains the modern expression of the rule in the Legislative Assembly. Standing Order 231(2) expressly recognises the role of the discretion of the Speaker and gives, according to previous Speaker’s rulings, ‘considerable discretion’ to the Speaker. Thus a Speaker has allowed a matter to be debated or a question asked if a matter on the Notice Paper , or even a bill, has remained on the Notice Paper too long without debate, thus allowing questions or other proceedings to continue because a bill has not been dealt with within a reasonable time (see Speaker McGrady 23 November 2000 PD p.4190). Similarly, Speakers have ruled questions out of order as they anticipate debate on notices of motion that would be dealt with later in the same day (see Speaker Fouras (AS) 11/5/2005 PD p.1324).

I think it important that I make the following points clear about the application of the rule in standing order 231, as it relates to our current practice. Firstly, the rule never applies so as to prevent a superior proceeding from being blocked by a more inferior proceeding. Thus consideration of a bill and debate within a bill will not be delayed or hampered because a notice of motion, adjourned motion or a question on notice about the subject matter is pending on the Notice Paper . They are all inferior proceedings. A bill is a superior form of proceeding to an adjourned motion (Harris 4 th edition, p.308) which is superior to a notice of motion or a question with or without notice. Therefore, the notices of motion on the Notice Paper cannot act to delay or hamper consideration and debate of the appropriation bills or any other bill.

Secondly, as per standing order 231(2), I will always consider whether a matter should be allowed by considering the likelihood of matters on the Notice Paper being debated within a reasonable time. All members can give at least one notice of motion each and every sitting day. Theoretically, there could be many dozens of notices of motion on the Notice Paper , but the reality is that only one notice of motion is likely to be dealt with each sitting week. I exercise my discretion so as to ensure that questions are not impeded by notices of motions that are unlikely to be dealt with and will most likely lapse under standing order 74. My clear understanding was that the notice of motion given by the Leader of the Opposition regarding the health payroll system was the motion intended to be dealt with during debate of private members’ motions this evening, as per established practice, and thus that is why I applied the rule of anticipation.

Thirdly, in accordance with standing order 231(3), the anticipation rule does not apply to prevent questions or debate which anticipate debate of the annual appropriation bills and, additionally, for the reasons given above, the debate on these bills is conversely unaffected by the notices of motion on the Notice Paper, as they are inferior proceedings.

Lastly, it will always be incumbent on the Speaker or whoever is in the chair to make a judgement call as to whether a matter anticipates another matter. Unfortunately, these decisions have to be made almost immediately and often where notices of motion are given and questions asked in immediate succession. I stand by the rulings I made this morning and note that it is within the control of the opposition as to what notices of motion they move for debate that evening and what questions they ask. If those on my left want to debate a matter on the Wednesday evening, perhaps they should avoid questions on the subject that morning.
Resumed from p. 1917, on motion of Ms Boyle--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (3.15 pm): To rise to participate in the debate on the City of Brisbane Bill. I particularly want to focus my attention on two separate aspects of the bill. Cabinet confidentiality is a contentious beast even on a good day. If it is used properly it may have a noble purpose but generally it has the potential to usher in some rather pernicious tendencies. It is widely recognised by the public in Queensland as a mechanism for wheeling truck-loads of documents that have the potential to be troublesome, especially in the future, into cabinet where they can be hidden behind the skirts of cabinet and not cause any embarrassment to people in the future. Whilst the practice sounds as though it has a somewhat noble purpose, there is the political reality of how it is used as opposed to how it is meant to be used. The reality is that the political process often uses cabinet confidentiality for a much more nefarious purpose.

I think it is beholden on us as members of parliament to really ask the general public in Queensland what they think of the concept of using cabinet confidentiality to limit freedom of information access to certain documents. It is my understanding from the people I speak to that generally people would regard that as a mechanism to hide documents rather than a mechanism for good governance. As such, I am particularly concerned about that particular aspect of the City of Brisbane Bill.

Secondly, I have concerns about the way the bill deals with exemptions for rate purposes. Most people in the House would know that as well as being a member of parliament I am also an ordained minister. This is an area that is pretty close to my heart. I think often the important voluntary work and social work done by churches in their role of providing social welfare as well as spiritual welfare and in their various community roles is often very much misunderstood or underrepresented.

In this parliament we have particular days, weeks and, in fact, even years where we recognise all the tremendous voluntary work that is done in our communities. I might say that, when it comes to voluntary work, many churches provide a tremendous amount of social welfare for people in our community who have great needs. That is really done not only on a voluntary basis but out of the goodness of their heart.
If we want a clear spiritual perspective on how it should be, the book of James chapter 1 verse 27 gives that. It says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Pure and genuine religion in the sight of God the Father means caring for orphans and widows in their distress and refusing to let the world corrupt you.
XML.Hansard-Body: I understand that there are many religious people over the years who have made a shameful representation of what the teachings of Scripture are and have been absolutely terrible and scurrilous representatives and examples of the Christian faith. Indeed, we need not confine this particular debate just to the Christian faith but more generally to places of worship across-the-board.

Often when places of worship are providing these important social welfare functions and counselling functions and many other functions, they do so in a quiet and unobtrusive manner that does not seek any particular glory for itself and also, largely speaking, does not seek any government funding. Again, these things are done out of the purest of motive. Certain aspects of this bill are very concerning to me and I have given that background to have this particular part of the debate. There are exemptions from council rates accorded to religious groups throughout Australia. This is not something that is unique to Queensland. For the most part, of course, the criteria that are applied for the granting of those exemptions are fairly similar all throughout Australia. There is a uniformity, as it were, pretty much across the nation. But in Brisbane, however, the criteria are entirely different from those applied to the rest of Queensland and, for that matter, Australia, and this is a concerning aspect of this bill.

Property that would be exempt from general rates in every regional local government area may not be exempt in Brisbane. Furthermore, what is exempt in Brisbane one year may not be exempt in another year, and it is unlikely that the practices of the respective religious, charitable and educational institutions differ in any major respect from region to region in the state. Compared to other Western nations, Australia has one of the healthiest views of separation of church and state. It has not become some sort of a dogma or mantra that people get ridiculous about. We see the important role of educational institutions which are entirely church based, and they have provided some of the best value-for-money education in our state for many years.

Of course, there are differences between Brisbane and other parts of Queensland in terms of demographics, concentration of population and perhaps average land values, and there may be very good reasons Brisbane is treated differently from many local government areas in certain respects. Recently I have conducted a major research project looking at the different rates that are levied across all of the local government areas in Queensland post amalgamation, and clearly Brisbane is a different animal when it comes to that. There is no doubt about that. But that does not really provide any good reason rating exemptions accorded for places of worship in Brisbane should be treated any differently from those of the balance of Queensland, because they are not commercial in nature. They are providing that same community caring advocacy and function right across the state and across our country. It is clear and simple to me that to apply a rule that recognises the different nature of Brisbane and then to apply it across these charitable institutions could end up being inequitable at an absolute minimum.

Section 957 of the Local Government Act 1993 provides for the power to exempt land by regulation, for example, for religious, charitable, educational or public purposes. Section 41 in schedule 4 of the Local Government Regulation 2005 provides that land owned by a religious entity is exempt from the payment of general rates if the land is less than 20 hectares and is used for one or more of the following purposes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) religious purposes, including, for example, public worship;
(b) the provision of education, health or community services, including facilities for aged persons and persons with disabilities--
XML.Hansard-Body: To see this, one only has to look at the Uniting Church with Blue Care and Meals on Wheels. They are entirely church based organisations which provide a very recognised social function. Section 41 in schedule 4 continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (c) the administration of the religious entity;
(d) housing incidental to a purpose mentioned in paragraph (a), (b) or (c) ...
XML.Hansard-Body: They are exempt from rating. That is a rather broad college of exemptions. It is a rather broad brush and certainly gives the option as intended by that particular regulation.

The parts of the Local Government Act 2009 that relate to rates exemption have not yet been proclaimed and are not yet in force, but those parts provide that land is exempted from rates, including land that is exempted from rating under another act or regulation for religious, charitable, educational or other public purposes. It would appear that the position under the Local Government Act 2009 will be different from that under the Local Government Act 1993. But in Brisbane again the position is entirely different. Under the City of Brisbane Act 1924 and under the City of Brisbane Bill 2010, Brisbane City Council is accorded the power to make its own resolution for rates exemptions for religious, charitable, educational or other public purposes, and that resolution can clearly change from year to year.

What might be property that would be exempt from general rates in every regional local government area then may not be exempt in Brisbane. Furthermore, what might be exempt in Brisbane one year has no guarantee of being exempt in the following year. I would urge the minister to consider the generalised nature of charitable, religious and educational institutions of that ilk and the important social function they play right across-the-board. I would urge the minister to address that in this particular bill and make sure that places such as places of worship and charity are treated equally right across-the-board and there can be no exemption in this bill that would be fair and allow for that situation to change.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (3.25 pm): I rise to speak to the City of Brisbane Bill, and I acknowledge that we have to pass two bills today and have to try to contain our comments.
