The major part of the bill I want to speak about relates to amendments to right to information, but I acknowledge that this bill modernises, if you like, much of the City of Brisbane Act--the only local authority in Queensland to have its own act of parliament when the rest are governed by the Local Government Act.

Many of the principles that are espoused in this bill are principles that the majority of councils try to adhere to anyway. It does, however, mandate them so that they now become an obligation. With regard to a pecuniary interest declaration, I do not believe that councillors in the main will have a problem with that. Councillors today understand the need for transparency. The ones I have spoken to understand that the community not only has to have confidence in them but also has to have the confidence that those councillors elected to represent them do not have any ulterior motive.

That brings me to the amendments to the Right to Information Act. I understand that there have been people in the LNP who have defended the Lord Mayor’s request for this change to effectively give cabinet exemption to information taken into the Brisbane City Council chambers. There would be a number of councillors throughout the state, because this exemption will apply to all councils in the state, who would welcome this ability to claim information to be exempt. However, if you spoke to constituents I think their point of view would be diametrically opposed, particularly those who have had dealings with councils that perhaps have had not the result that they would have hoped for.

The community in my electorate has been forced to accept an amalgamated council. That still for some is a rancour. They are concerned at some of the actions of council. That is to be expected when there is a new group of councillors in some way acting differently from the previous two councils. However, I would say that the vast majority of people, if not the entire community, would say that they do have the right to as much information as possible that is used as the basis for the setting of rates and charges not only so that they can understand the justification that council has used to set the rates and charges but also so that a council’s rationale is transparent and able to be questioned. I believe that that, with the passing of this bill--and it will pass--will be at risk, if not in reality then in perception. That is a great disappointment, because part of the basis of community is reality and part of the basis of community is perception.
The member for Beaudesert photocopied and handed around to us here a Courier-Mail article that says very strongly some of what I believe people in the community would be saying. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This week State Parliament is scheduled to debate the City of Brisbane Act 2010, which, when passed, as it presumably will be, will extend State Cabinet secrecy provisions to the Brisbane City Council. In other words, the council will, for the first time, be able to refuse to publicly release information for no other reason than it has gone before its civic cabinet.
XML.Hansard-Body: Councils throughout Queensland have had a committee system. When I was a member of the Calliope shire council there were matters, particularly town planning matters, that were dealt with in committee. They were effectively in camera. But much of the debate was often carried out in the public domain and I do not believe that the structure of withholding information was anywhere near as firm as this legislation will create.
The article states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: What is at issue here is a principle, not a debate about what size an organisation needs to be before it can start hiding behind a cabinet exemption clause.
XML.Hansard-Body: That comment relates to Lord Mayor Campbell Newman’s reasonable argument that the scale, size and structure of the Brisbane City Council is unlike any other local government in Australia and is, in fact, more akin to the state government. The article states further--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ...the new rules will also give the government ‘the power to publish guidelines for the council for the proactive release of civic cabinet material’ which will ‘mirror what the Queensland Government has already implemented for State Cabinet in the interests of improved transparency and accountability.’
XML.Hansard-Body: I think that, in the minds of many people in Queensland, if a government, irrespective of political persuasion, wanted to withhold information that was divisive, that was confrontational, that was provocative and it was close to an election, they would wheel it into cabinet--and I can remember having debates in here about the reasonableness of trolleys of files being taken into the cabinet room--so that the action of wheeling them in rendered them cabinet-in-confidence, and that unreasonableness and the lack of transparency would create suspicion in the community.
The article goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is a nonsense and a strange way indeed to deal with council information. First you pass a law giving the council new weaponry for withholding information, then you issue guidelines on how this newly protected information might be made public in the future. Why not just leave things the way they are, for better or worse, rather than introducing new layers of rules, regulations, paperwork and, most importantly, secrecy.
XML.Hansard-Body: In his contribution, the member for Warrego said he would encourage councils not to use the provision. Can I say that those councils that wish to remain open and accessible to their communities probably will not. The ones that do not remain open and accessible are probably the councils that the community has the most concern about. They are the ones that will be given additional protection by this bill. I do not believe this provision is necessary and I believe that it will be a matter of great concern to the community.

Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (3.33 pm): I would like to briefly provide my support for the City of Brisbane Bill 2010, which is currently before the House. Specifically, I will direct my comments to the principles behind the legislation and after that I will touch on matters surrounding the financial and infrastructure sustainability and accountability aspects of the bill.

The whole point of this bill is that it represents a new approach to the governance of local government in Brisbane, with the intention of removing prescriptive processes and thus allowing the council greater flexibility. As such, the principles based legislation aims to be high-level, outcomes focused, encourage innovation and is considered by stakeholders to be comprehensive and, in addition, also allows practitioners to focus on outcomes and develop their own operational procedures and processes. However, it is important to note that that does not mean that the legislation will be less enforceable. Finally, it is hoped that the legislation will achieve higher levels of compliance by requiring the council to comply with the spirit as well as the provisions of the bill.

As members would be aware, the Local Government Act 2009 is also principles based. Both the City of Brisbane Bill and the Local Government Act are based on the same five principles. Those local governments reflect best practice public administration standards and they include transparent and effective processes and decision making in the public interest; the sustainable development and management of assets and infrastructure and the delivery of effective services; democratic representation, social inclusion and meaningful community engagement; good governance of and by local government; and, of course, ethical and legal behaviour of councillors and council employees. As such, as members can see, within the parameters of these principles the council may exercise choice about processes as long as the processes are rational, justifiable and transparent.

These principles highlight the absolute essentials of responsible, inclusive and transparent governance that Brisbane ratepayers expect and certainly deserve. As such, anyone performing a responsibility under the legislation must consider the application of the local government principles. Of course, a breach of the principles would be a breach of the act and, accordingly, would be enforced. I should also clarify my comments by mentioning that I am also advised that for matters needing more detail and a certain level of prescription, regulations will be developed in consultation with stakeholders before the commencement of the new legislation.

I would now like to briefly comment on a couple of financial infrastructure sustainability matters and to assure everyone that the government believes that the future stability of the Brisbane community is not negotiable. That is why the bill clearly sets out requirements for financial sustainability and accountability. As we all know, the council faces challenges in financial governance and service delivery and it has competing priorities in terms of population changes, the ongoing sustainability of the council and the community and providing significant levels of infrastructure. In addition, the council carries a heavy load of community expectations about the management of public infrastructure and assets for the long-term benefit and viability of the Brisbane community as well as to deliver essential services and account for all public moneys in the short term.

With that in mind, to help future councils of Brisbane city manage this load, the bill requires a focus on longer-term planning and higher levels of accountability to the community. These practices are not new to councils but they are now legislated for both the present and the future, as they are for all other Queensland councils. As we all know, councils are considered to be financially sustainable if they are able to maintain their financial capital and infrastructure capital over the longer term. As such, I am confident that this council will continue planning for future service delivery and infrastructure through the development of long-term financial, community and asset management plans. As such, I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs KIERNAN (Mount Isa--ALP) (3.37 pm): I rise to speak to the City of Brisbane Bill and, in particular, to a number of amendments identified by the LGAQ during the drafting of the regulations under the Local Government Act 2009 and the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. The Local Government Act 2009, which comes into effect on 1 July 2010, signals a new and exciting era for local government in Queensland. That act has a strong focus on building sustainable and inclusive communities and reflects contemporary community expectations of local government.

As we know, the world has changed--and quite significantly--since the Local Government Act 1993. The Local Government Act 2009, when it comes into effect, will deliver a new and innovative framework for local governments across Queensland. It has to be said that the drafting and preparation of the 2009 act was 2 years of hard work and collaboration between local and state governments. The community engagement process was exhaustive. Being a member who was involved in much of that process during the development of the 2009 act, I would say that it was one of the most consultative processes that I have ever been involved in.

We know that more than 70-odd mayors, councillors, senior staff and other stakeholders took part in the development of that legislation. Many meetings were held across the state and many local issues were taken on board. Certainly, further extensive consultation has gone on in respect of the proposed amendments.

I also take this opportunity to congratulate Minister Boyle and her staff, and most particularly Michael Kinnane and his staff, who have done a tremendous job over the past couple of years. Where we are with local government today is a real credit to their commitment. There is no doubt that today’s local governments are required to deliver a more diverse range of services and infrastructure than ever before. They are required to operate in the complex business environment encompassing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and urban, rural and remote lands. It is also very clear that the environment surrounding public administration today has shifted quite markedly.

As a result, the act clarifies provisions relating to responsibilities of mayors and CEOs. Importantly, the act reflects Queenslanders’ expectations that their elected representatives will look after the interests of all residents. Ratepayers not only want to understand how local government processes work but also expect a high standard of delivery of services. Above all else, local residents today want transparency in decision making and expect councils to look past today and plan for future generations.

The act will deal more clearly with councillor conduct. The act provides clear principles, roles and responsibilities and more effective penalties. Apart from councillors, mayors and local residents phoning me across my 14 council areas, there are questions within the community that they want clarified or are seeking information about and a great many of those questions are about the conduct of councillors.

I think that the code-of-conduct approach that has been replaced with a new system for dealing with complaints about councillor misconduct and poor performance is appropriate. Inappropriate meeting conduct by councillors will be dealt with at a local level under new powers for mayors to warn and suspend a councillor, similar to the Speaker’s role in parliament. Those new powers will be well received. An independent regional conduct review will be put in place to investigate serious allegations against councillors and the state local government remuneration and discipline tribunal will be set up for more serious performance complaints. The panels and the tribunal will be able to use a range of penalties, from mediations and fines to issuing warnings or suspending allowances.

In serious cases of misconduct the Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships will be able to recommend to the Governor in Council the suspension or dismissal of an individual councillor. This new power is widely supported by stakeholders and is fairer than the status quo of dismissing an entire council because of the poor performance or misconduct of a few. The minister has also retained the power to recommend to the Governor in Council that a council be dissolved if a situation presents no other alternative.

The act provides a structure to encourage local government decisions that are in the public interest. Councils will be responsible for their community’s involvement in the democratic process, social inclusion and meaningful community engagement. They must practice good governance and ensure the ethical and legal behaviour of councillors and their officers. The new act certainly ensures the continuation of the highest standard of transparency and accountability that ratepayers are demanding.

The act retains provisions and serious penalties relating to the misuse of information to cause detriment to council. Detriment here is not about political embarrassment or disagreements between councillors, nor is it about matters that are and should be in the public domain. It is appropriate that there is public debate about the positives and negatives of council projects, plans and policies. This is in the public interest and will not trigger the misuse of information provisions. To cause detriment to the council has now been clearly defined in the legislation and it includes to sabotage a lawful process of the council, including adopting a budget or conducting a tender process, for example, or to cause the council to suffer a loss in its lawful performance of a function or commercial activity, including the loss of future contracts.

Councils will be exempted from requirements under the Right to Information Act 2009. Council considers a range of options and possible projects as it works towards reaching a balance between income, with its impacts on ratepayers, and expenditure, capital works programs and employment generation. Although this issue was brought to the government’s attention by the Lord Mayor of Brisbane in relation to his council’s budgetary processes, the provision under right to information will also apply to all local governments right across Queensland.

Further, following discussions with the LGAQ, an amendment today clarifies the parameters of the material personal interest provisions. This amendment makes it really clear in defining an ‘ordinary business matter’ that a person does not have a material personal interest merely because they are a member of a non-government, charitable or religious organisation involving no personal financial gain or loss to a person. If anyone has ever been on a small council, as I have been, they will know that half the room stands up. It is like a revolving door, or it used to be. Whether a person was on the local kindy or church committee, everyone thought that they had an interest. With smaller council numbers it makes it doubly difficult. This is an excellent amendment.

In response to concerns about what constitutes family or personal interest declarations, the legislation will now stipulate very clearly that this is a parent, child, sibling or partner and should therefore only very occasionally require the councillor to withdraw from participation in council business. As I said, there are 14 councils on my patch. We could be a one-third of a Queensland supercouncil. The new act will be supplemented with a concise set of regulations. Again, I compliment everyone involved. I think the extensive consultation that has been undertaken to get to this point is certainly to be commended and congratulated and on that note I commend the bill to the House.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (3.46 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. I wish to focus particularly on that section that deals with the council’s responsibilities and powers. Today, we saw a remarkably dishonest attack on the Brisbane City Council by the transport minister. But, of course, that is not unexpected from this minister. Today, the minister got up and tried to compare the performance of the Brisbane City Council on public transport to that of the Queensland state government. Today, the Brisbane City Council released its budget. It is a remarkable contrast to see the performance of this council, dealing with the responsibilities under this act to look after the people of Brisbane, compared to this state government on the issue of public transport.

Let us look at the outstanding record of achievement on public transport that has been achieved by the Brisbane City Council under Lord Mayor Campbell Newman and the LNP. If we look at today’s budget we see that it continues a 50 per cent growth in bus patronage and a 73 per cent growth in ferry patronage over the last five years. Again, an outstanding example of this council looking after the people of Brisbane as opposed to this state government, as is its responsibility under this bill, is that in 2010-11 the Brisbane City Council will spend more than $1.2 billion to improve public transport, fix congested roads and make it easier for people to walk and ride around the city.
Mr Finn interjected.

Mr EMERSON: It is interesting to hear the member for Yeerongpilly talk about it because I know that his former constituents, who are now in my electorate, complained bitterly about the lack of performance by the state government when he was their member over issues like public transport. It is remarkable to hear it. It is remarkable how they repeatedly tell me about that.
Ms BOYLE: I rise to a point of order. By no stretch of the imagination are the comments the member is making in any way relevant to the bill before the House.
Dr Flegg: He can’t take his own point of order?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): It is not a point of order. I would remind the member for Moggill that, while a person is taking a point of order, it is up to me to rule on that, not him.

Mr EMERSON: I was referring to the outstanding performance of the Brisbane City Council in terms of its budget as compared to that of the Queensland state government, particularly in terms of public transport. Let us continue to look at the council’s wonderful performance and what is in its budget, which was released today. Let us look at the responsibilities of the council. Council will continue to subsidise public transport in Brisbane by $173.71 million over the next 12 months. It will spend $56.26 million on new buses and $4.4 million on another two CityCats. Under the LNP and Lord Mayor Campbell Newman, the Brisbane City Council is continuing to deal with traffic congestion to make Brisbane an even better place to live.

In contrast, the Bligh government is throwing up its hands on the key issue of congestion. I know this because I have asked the infrastructure minister about dealing with congestion on roads in Brisbane. When I have discussed it with him, he has said, ‘Don’t worry about that; that’s a matter for the Brisbane City Council.’ The city council is dealing with it, but don’t bother talking to the Queensland government. Anyone stuck on the Walter Taylor Bridge or stuck in gridlocked traffic elsewhere everyday--those people in Sherwood, in Corinda, in Graceville, in Chelmer, in Tennyson--should not bother talking to the Queensland Bligh government, because they do not care about congestion. Once again the Brisbane City Council is dealing with congestion, but the state government and the responsible minister--have a look at questions on notice--simply say, ‘Don’t bother me; go talk to the Brisbane City Council.’ That is why under this act--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I remind the member for Indooroopilly that debate is to be directed through the chair and not across the chamber at other members.

Mr EMERSON: Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate your guidance on that. As I was saying, this is an outstanding budget compared to the sad state of affairs under the Bligh government. Today the transport minister attacked the Brisbane City Council. Earlier today we heard the Premier speak about walking down the street and talking to the people. The Premier knows that if she walked down the street, 69 per cent of people would say that she is the worst Premier this state has ever seen. I urge--

Mr WALLACE: I rise to a point of order. I have had a look through the bill and I do not believe discussions on the transport minister or the Premier are located in the bill. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to make a ruling on this dissertation by the member for Indooroopilly.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I have already made the ruling in terms of the minister’s point of order originally. The bill deals with financial sustainability and accountability. At the present time the member has not overstepped those boundaries, but he is getting very, very close.

Mr EMERSON: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I said, it is important that we see what the people of Brisbane want from their elected representatives, particularly on the issue of public transport. Clause 14 of the bill refers to the responsibilities of councillors. Clause 14(1) states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A councillor must represent the current and future interests of the residents of Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is important that the residents of Brisbane are looked after by the Brisbane City Council, because they are not being looked after by the state government. I urge the minister to come with me to my electorate and chat with my constituents. She can come to the Indooroopilly Railway Station and find out what the people who use that station say about public transport and whether they think the Brisbane City Council is doing a good job. I can tell members what people are saying about the state government, because I use public transport all the time. They ask, ‘Why are fares going up? Why aren’t the timetables reliable? Why aren’t the trains turning up?’ The Brisbane City Council is looking after the future interests of this--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Indooroopilly, will you come back to the objects of the bill, please.

Mr EMERSON: Certainly, Mr Deputy Speaker. As I said, this is about the future interests of the residents of Brisbane, as referred to in clause 14(1) of the bill. This is about the interests of Brisbane. I will conclude on that point. The Brisbane City Council is looking after the interests of the people of Queensland and the people of Brisbane, unlike this state government.

Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (3.53 pm): Brisbane is a fabulous place to live. It is a city that is blessed with features such as Mount Coot-tha, the Brisbane Forest Park and the Brisbane River. Clearly, it is a place where people want to come to live. That has not happened by accident. To some extent, the City of Brisbane was created as something of an experiment, with one local authority covering a whole capital city with nearly 40 per cent of Queensland’s population. It is a party political council. It is a council that would have the potential to play a lot of games when it comes to state government legislation. Therefore, I am pleased--and I am sure that the Brisbane City Council is pleased--with the general direction that this bill has taken.

The bill deals in particular with the financial viability of the council. The Brisbane City Council has achieved what a lot of other authorities have been unable to achieve. Brisbane City Council projects include the Inner City Bypass, the Coronation Drive reconstruction, the Waterworks Road upgrade, the completion of the Clem7 tunnel and, in particular, the upcoming Hale Street link and Northern Link. The Brisbane City Council has managed to achieve those major infrastructure projects without any of the blow-outs in debt that we have seen from the state government.

If we look at issues in Brisbane where we need to do a lot better, they are not the issues of the Brisbane City Council; they are the issues of the state government. They are issues such as the appalling congestion on Moggill Road, the complete lack of any commitment from this government to desperately needed projects like the Kenmore bypass or the upgrade of the Western Freeway, which again seem to have been omitted from this budget. The Brisbane City Council--

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Moggill, I would remind you of my ruling in relation to the member for Indooroopilly. Perhaps you could come back to the bill, thank you. We are not dealing with the budget. We are dealing with the City of Brisbane Bill.

Dr FLEGG: The budget of the Brisbane City Council shows $2.5 billion being spent on capital expenditure in the past two years alone. In the past three years that is 208 per cent more than Labor spent in its past three years in office. All of that has been done in a setting of below-average debt. In fact, the debt for the City of Brisbane peaked in 1993. In a number that the state government could well be jealous of, in 1993 the debt-to-revenue ratio in Brisbane was 131 per cent. In 2010-11 it is under 53 per cent. The Brisbane City Council has been able to deliver projects such as the Hale Street link and Northern Link in a setting where it can retain public ownership during, at the very least, the early years when the greatest value is created by the build-up in traffic on those links.

Because of prudent financial management over recent years, the Brisbane City Council does not have a massive noose of interest payments around its neck, as we see with the state government. Rather than being able to deliver those sorts of projects and keep them in public ownership, the state government has been forced to sell projects, both new ones and old ones. Recently the member for Mount Ommaney raised a petition in relation to upgrading the Western Freeway. Once again, state government infrastructure has let the City of Brisbane down. It is extraordinary to see a member who has been here for the better part of a decade suddenly realise that there is a problem with the Western Freeway. Perhaps we ought to take a leaf out of the book of prudent management of the Brisbane City Council.

Certainly, the western suburbs of Brisbane have a fabulous hardworking team of councillors. Margaret de Wit, Jane Prentice, Peter Matic, Matt Bourke and Geraldine Knapp have strongly represented that area. I think that is part of the reason, at the council level, we have managed to deliver on many of the things in western Brisbane. However, in reality, western Brisbane has been strangled by the failure of the state government to address its responsibility to its state controlled roads and public transport in that area.

In view of the limited time allocated to this bill, I will cut my remarks off there. I think Brisbane residents are very proud of their city. To a significant extent we have something that is unique in Brisbane City Council in terms of its size, in terms of having the whole city covered under one local authority, in terms of much of the responsibility that is handed to the council, particularly in areas like public transport and the like. Let us hope that we can build on that into the future.

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--Ind) (3.59 pm): I am mindful of the time limitations, so I will be as brief as possible. At the outset, I acknowledge the enormous amount of work done by the staff, the minister’s department and the minister herself in putting this bill together. I would like to contribute to the debate on the City of Brisbane Bill 2010.

Clause 26 refers to the mayor being a member of the standing committees of the council. I think this is a good move because we have seen the role and powers of the mayor somewhat undermined in recent years. So I think it is good to strengthen those powers. I assume that where it says ‘take part’ in committees that the mayors can vote in those committees. In the five years I was on the Logan City Council, there was only one instance where the mayor had to cast a vote when it was six-all. Other than that, the mayor was largely a figurehead. So it is good to see that the involvement of the mayor on the standing committees is noted.

Clause 32 refers to the local law register, and I think it would be wise to have those local laws publicly available, as the clause suggests. I assume that would be on the internet or on the Brisbane City Council website. This would save a lot of unnecessary time for all parties involved who are trying to look at local laws, subordinate local laws and interim local laws for themselves. It would also save a lot of staff time if they were to be provided on the internet.

Clause 37 refers to election advertising. This somewhat surprised me. It has always been a contentious issue for candidates and often council officers in ensuring that they police those local by-laws. To see that the Brisbane City Council is not able to ban how-to-vote material or election advertising is inconsistent with other councils across Queensland. I suggest that that power should be enshrined in this bill so that the Brisbane City Council can make those decisions in order to make it a level playing field. That was always a contentious issue that took up a lot of man hours in the Logan City Council. I am pretty sure that there are councillors on the Sunshine Coast who are moving to eradicate election signs. It is interesting to see that the Brisbane City Council itself does not have those powers.
Clause 40 refers to suspending or revoking particular local laws. The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Minister has the power to revoke or direct a change to a local law if he/she believes the law contravenes another local government related law ...
XML.Hansard-Body: To me it should be a given, a prerequisite, that before a local law comes into effect it does not contravene another local law. I see unnecessary intervention by the minister instead of making sure that the council gets it right in the first instance. It should be a prerequisite rather than saying, ‘You can do it sloppily because we might catch up and have a look at it later on.’ I think that should be tightened up to ensure that the council gets it right in the first instance.

Clause 43 refers to the register of beneficial enterprises. Once again, I think it would be wise for the register to be available on the internet for the sake of efficiency and accountability. Chasing that information often wastes a lot of staff time. That would keep people in the loop from the outset.

There are a series of clauses relating to the powers for entering property. But nowhere does it specify a minimum notice required. This is somewhat concerning. Even if you are renting a home, the RTA has to give a minimum of seven days notice to enter the property, whether that be for an inspection or whatever. There should certainly be a minimum requirement for the council to enter a property. A lot of residents have been up in arms after coming home to find a council officer on their property, inspecting whether a dog is registered or otherwise. It can be quite concerning when those powers are given somewhat flippantly to council officers. In some instances they have more powers than police officers. So there needs to be a requirement for a minimum notice to let residents know when council officers intend to enter their property.

It is disappointing to see once again that there is a huge amount of discrimination in that councillors are not able to stand for state election without having to first give up their job. I think councillors are in the best position or in a better position than most in terms of understanding the machinations of government and understanding the provision of front-line services of government, having come from the grassroots level. It equips them to come into state parliament with the knowledge required. They certainly have a greater appreciation than someone coming straight into state government without that previous experience. Once again, I have to put on record my extreme disappointment that allowing a councillor to stand for a state government seat without first having to relinquish their job is not in the bill. I do not see it applying to any other job in Australian politics. I think it is something that would contravene the discrimination act as well.

Finally, and most importantly, is the notion of ‘civic cabinets’. I understand the terminology would be used in that sense, given it has an annual budget of $3.4 billion. But what we have to understand is that there are mechanisms already in place for those sensitive issues of commercial-in-confidence and public tendering for contracts. It is very concerning to see that the right to information powers given to the council potentially shut down transparency, which the bill says numerous times is what it is trying to enable. What is also concerning is that it mentions stakeholders, being the CEO, council staff and officers in the department. That is great. But where--and this is key--are the members of the public? They are key stakeholders because they are who make up this public enterprise. I think it would be very remiss of this government not to ensure that the public were heavily involved in that consultation process. After all, without ratepayers, the residents, such a council would not exist.

I think it is very concerning in that this will make it a private public enterprise, which goes against the whole notion of transparency, democracy and accountability as we know it. After 86 years the legislation does need to be changed in terms of wording and relevance because it was somewhat outdated, but the definitions of ‘transparency’ and ‘accountability’ always remain the same. So I think this is giving unnecessary powers, in my firm opinion, to councils regardless of whichever side of politics they are on. Having listened objectively to members from both sides of the House, it is very concerning that there was a lot of political underlining rather than raising the potential damage that this would create. In fact, an article in the Courier-Mail states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: BCC Opposition Leader Shayne Sutton has broken Labor ranks by opposing the exemption. She said her position had been made very clear to the State Government.
“Local residents already have trouble getting information from Brisbane City Council as it is, this will make it much more difficult,” she said.

BCC previously attempted to prevent the release of documents surrounding the controversial rate rise for the CBD units by arguing the committee which made the decision should be given State Cabinet status.
XML.Hansard-Body: Correct me if I am wrong, Mr Deputy Speaker, but we have seen large elements of the LNP over the years accusing the state government of the very same so-called offence. I think it is an absolute tragedy here today that there have been very few members of the House who have alerted us to this very notion of adopting potentially the same dangerous precedent to create a secret council. What this is now creating is another mini state government. As the opposition has highlighted over many years, the freedom of information and the right to information laws have had to be slowly implemented to the point when sometimes you have to wonder whether you are in communist Russia. Unfortunately, there has been very little debate on this today other than the politically motivated comments from either side of politics, depending on what side of the fence they declare themselves to bear allegiance to.
Clause 92 refers to the power to levy rates and charges. The last line in the explanatory notes states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Given the level of community interest in this issue and the broad powers of the council, openness and accountability are essential.
XML.Hansard-Body: Can you believe it? This is the same bill which promotes the potential secrecy at the will of the council when they so please, yet in relation to the power to levy rates and charges the explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Given the level of community interest in this issue and the broad powers of the council, openness and accountability are essential.
XML.Hansard-Body: I cannot believe this is stated in the explanatory notes to this same bill. It is completely hypocritical of the intent of the bill. It says the direct opposite. It is diametrically opposite. It is a very sad day if we have an opposition that will support this bill when that same opposition has been knocking the state government for those very notions that this bill is laced with.

I have lost count of the number of times ‘transparency’ and ‘accountability’ have been said throughout the debate on this bill. You have to wonder when something is repeated so many times whether or not it is actually the intent. When we look at the devil in the detail, what we see here is a very dangerous precedent. It is not a state government. I understand there may be political motivations to support this bill, but what it does highlight is that we have Shayne Sutton, the Brisbane City Council Leader of the Opposition, saying it is a bad thing; we have a Labor government saying it is a good thing; and we have an opposition that goes a bit quietly, quietly. What we are seeing here is that, once again, the major parties are two heads of the same creature. It is enough to make you want to start your own political party.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (4.10 pm): I rise to speak very briefly on the City of Brisbane Bill 2010. I would like to make a very quick comment first. When people in the House agree to go through a bill pretty quickly and have it debated by a certain time and the maths are done so that each person gets a set time in which to speak, it would be appreciated if members did not waffle on for a vast number of minutes so that other people miss out on their opportunity to speak. I know that the Leader of the House said she was not going to guillotine the bills tonight, and that is commendable, but I know that because people took more than their allotted time during the last sitting week I did miss out on having a chance to speak. I want it on the record that I do not like it happening and I do not think anybody else does, either. I will quickly get back to the bill. I am mindful of the time and I am not a person who raves on for a long time, so I am pretty sure I will be within the eight minutes that I have been allotted today.

If you have to talk about any city in Australia, I think the city of Brisbane is the most liveable city--if you have to live in one, that is. In saying that, I do not know a lot about the machinations of the Brisbane council or anything else and I will not address any of that because many people already have. The part of the bill that I do want to address is the right to information from our councils.

What I notice--and correct me if I am wrong--is that this government is giving the power to local governments to lock away information for 10 years. I assume that means it is locked away from the state government as well. A lot of issues arise in our communities that need investigation at times, but if this is the case and information is locked away, I want to know how you get around that. How are you going to circumvent the fact that you have given that right to lock away information for that period of time? I can foresee that troublesome documents and anything that might cause any hardship to the council of the day--
Mr Wellington: Politically embarrassing.

Mrs PRATT: Exactly. I take that interjection. Politically embarrassing documents may be wheeled away and locked away for a certain time if it is thought that they may have any effect on an upcoming council election, or whatever. I am not happy with this part of the bill. I would like to see it removed altogether. I know that the people in my electorate have enough trouble getting any information at all at the moment from the councils. They come to me in absolute frustration. They are led around by the nose, from department to department, and after weeks and months sometimes and a multitude of letters they do not get any information whatsoever. I am of the opinion that local governments should not be politically aligned, but that is a trend that seems to be coming in more and more.

I am also aware that most councillors do recognise when a conflict of interest arises and most of them do play their part. The member for Mount Isa was right in saying that it can often be like a revolving door when people think they have some sort of conflict. Often there is not even one there, but just in case they head out.

I can see this freedom of information provision being abused in the future. I believe it has been abused by state governments in the past and I think it will be abused again in the future. I think most people want to know why it is in there. Why is that power being handed to local governments, which are supposed to be even more open and accountable? I think the first thing people are going to ask is why. Why do they want to cover something up? They are supposed to be open and accountable. Those words echo around this chamber more often than not, to the point that I do not think anyone understands anymore what open and accountable really stands for.

I do not think there is much trust with any politician, be it state, local or federal, and I think this will just put another dint in what little confidence and trust there may be. So I find it very sad that that is there.

Other members have actually spoken about the article that was printed in the Courier-Mail. For those who have not read it, it is called ‘Creeping cloak of secrecy’. I think it says in a nutshell exactly what concerns there are with this particular bill.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (4.15 pm): By rising to consider the City of Brisbane Bill 2010 and briefly contribute to the debate, it gives me another opportunity to say, ‘Thank God for Independents in this chamber.’ Thank God for members of this chamber who are prepared to put their communities first and the interests of political party powerbrokers last. The only people who will benefit from the passage of this bill will be the millionaires, the billionaires, the union and bureaucratic elite, and the politically connected property developers--not the workers and ratepayers who have to operate by one set of rules while the well-connected political mates benefit from the backroom deals.

By altering the RTI laws, the City of Brisbane Bill 2010 increases the chances that those backroom deals will remain in the back room, hidden from sight, and it increases the chances of corruption or the misuse of public funds. The City of Brisbane Bill 2010 introduces a layer of bureaucracy which enables elected decision makers to hide their actions and decision-making processes involving billions of dollars of public money from scrutiny. It decreases the level of public accountability for holders of public office, and it invites organisational dysfunction and corruption.

It has also set a precedent for this sort of lessening of accountability and transparency to be shared throughout Queensland, not only Brisbane. My constituents of Burnett are not happy with many of the decisions that the newly amalgamated Bundaberg Regional Council has made. Some decisions are poor choice, and some decisions have been forced on the council because of the high cost of the forced amalgamation and the need to raise extra revenue.

If the legal principle contained in this legislation is allowed to be replicated in the Bundaberg Regional Council, for example, then important decisions--like approval for overseas owned companies who want to mine sand near the houses of local residents in Gooburrum and approval for another environmentally delinquent overseas company, Holcim, to establish a quarry near the growing coastal communities of Coral Cove and Elliott Heads and a marine park--will be covered up and shrouded in further secrecy. We have already seen the worrying development of pre council meetings being held behind closed doors. I thank the member for Beaudesert for his local government expertise and alerting us to the dangers of this legislation. I repeat the warning and question of the Courier-Mail : ‘What are they trying to hide?’ I oppose this bill.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (4.18 pm), in reply: I am very pleased to speak to the House in response to some of the questions and issues that have been raised by members. Some members who spoke fairly recently expressed a lot of concern about the right to information exemptions, but I am pleased to reassure them that they misunderstood the exemptions that are provided for in the City of Brisbane Bill. I will address those specifically a little later.

The legislation formally acknowledges Brisbane as our state’s capital. It puts in place a contemporary governance framework that will help guide Brisbane on its journey to becoming Australia’s new world city. The bill is further evidence of the Bligh government completing the task we set out to do: to create a robust local government sector, second to none in the country. This commitment has been supported also by partnerships fostered in developing the legislation, including with the Brisbane City Council and the Local Government Association of Queensland, where our ongoing dialogue has resulted in amendments to the legislation as required.

I reassure members of the House concerned about that that the revision of the bill and the creation of a new City of Brisbane Bill was publicly advertised and submissions were called for. I also reported on it in the newspapers and on radio wherever I could in order to encourage public comment, but there was, in fact, very little public comment. It has been primarily the key stakeholders--that is, the LGAQ, the Brisbane City Council led by CEO Jude Munro as well as the Lord Mayor and his team and the opposition led by Shayne Sutton and her team--who have made comment.

May I take a moment to recognise the good contribution of the CEO, Jude Munro, not only to this bill but in fact to local government over many years. It is with some dismay that we heard the news fairly recently that she will be stepping down from her position as CEO of the Brisbane City Council. This is a huge loss to the world of local government. She has indeed been an eminent leader of men as well as women. She has been a tremendous role model to those women aspiring to a career in local government. She will be missed. I place on the record not only my view about her tremendous contribution but that of the Department of Infrastructure and Planning, and in particular Local Government Services, and wish her well in her next positions.

There are several amendments to the City of Brisbane Bill that are presented today to clarify, amongst other things, the local law-making process. The legislation gives council the power to develop its own process for doing this with the provisos being that local laws undergo a state interest check and are approved by the minister before gazettal. In essence, this means that the same rules will apply to local law-making in every council in Queensland. However, the process will be simple and timely. Model local laws and subordinate local laws will be excluded from requiring approval before gazettal.

There is also an amendment to provisions dealing with roadworks and materials that are local government property. It now includes roads or works built by developers and donated to the council. An example has also been included in the legislation to give it further clarity.

As well as the amendments to the City of Brisbane Bill there are amendments to the Local Government Act. These include removing references to divisions when it comes to councillors requesting information from the chief executive so that consideration is given to the needs and interests of the wider community and provisions to prevent the release of confidential information by a councillor, including making the release of confidential information misconduct that would be required to go before the Local Government Remuneration and Discipline Tribunal. These amendments will ensure the smooth implementation from 1 July this year of the City of Brisbane Bill 2010, the Local Government Act 2009 and the regulations made under each of these important pieces of legislation.

May I address some of the issues raised by honourable members, in particular, the most controversial, which is that of the right to information exemptions as they will apply to local government. There are two issues. The first applies to all local governments and is for papers prepared for their budgetary consideration. It provides an exemption for those papers and those papers alone. This is not the business of monthly meetings or the ordinary business of council but rather only those papers that are prepared for budgetary consideration by the council. They are exempted from being available through the right to information legislation for a period of 10 years. That applies to all 73 councils in Queensland. It is an option for councils, however, not a mandate. So it may be that those councils that wish to will still release their budgetary considerations and the papers associated with that when they announce their budgets.

We are, however, extending the right to information exemption provisions for the City of Brisbane to its Establishment and Coordination Committee. The Establishment and Coordination Committee is, in effect, a mini cabinet. It is the committee that is chaired by the Lord Mayor and on which sits the chairs of all the standing committees of the council. It is our view, in supporting the request of the Lord Mayor, that their deliberation should be exempt in the same way as some papers are exempt for the state cabinet. The Premier, as the minister responsible for the right to information legislation, will set some guidelines, as have been set for state cabinet, about the release of decisions of the E&C and associated papers. These are limited exemptions and not well reflected in the balanced articles in newspapers that are the articles on which some members of the House have based their own views.

I do, however, put on the record an eloquently expressed explanation for why these are appropriate exemptions. This is a quote from a judgement published by the joint majority in a High Court case of the Commonwealth v Northern Land Council in 1993. That judgement states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: But it has never been doubted that it is in the public interest that the deliberations of Cabinet should remain confidential in order that the members of Cabinet may exchange differing views and at the same time maintain the principle of collective responsibility for any decision which may be made.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Further on in the decision the justices say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the disclosure of the deliberations ... is liable to subject the members of that body to criticism of a premature, ill-informed or misdirected nature and to divert the process from its proper course. The mere threat of disclosure is likely to be sufficient to impede those deliberations by muting a free and vigorous exchange of views or by encouraging lengthy discourse engaged in with an eye to subsequent public scrutiny ... It is not so much a matter of encouraging candour or frankness as of ensuring that decision-making and policy development by Cabinet is uninhibited.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is why we agreed with the Lord Mayor and have applied a similar provision as applies to our state cabinet to the E&C of the Brisbane City Council.

Other members have raised other matters. The member for Clayfield asked why it should be so that the state has any interest in monitoring the debt of the Brisbane City Council and monitoring its intentions with regard to beneficial enterprises. It may be of interest to that honourable member to know that recently the council was debt free, and proudly claimed that, after the state took over the water assets. But that situation is no longer so and debt has increased in the Brisbane City Council. It is the Auditor-General’s view, as well as that of the QTC, that it is appropriate that we monitor debt in the Brisbane City Council as we do for all the other councils of Queensland.

There were some other matters raised. One in fact was raised by the member for Maryborough. I offer my congratulations to him. I wonder whether he has taken this bill so seriously that he has sat up in bed late at night reading the clauses in detail. I congratulate him on spotting, in the main bill, an error on our part. We had not included, as we should have, the provisions in relation to land on which rates are levied that gives the power to local governments to not charge rates particularly for church and other charitable organisations. The member will be pleased to hear, then, that we similarly had spotted that error on our part and that it is reflected in an amendment to the bill before the House and will be fixed this afternoon.

I am pleased also to reassure the honourable member for Beaudesert, who was concerned about the power that council officers may have to simply enter a property in the Brisbane City Council area without any notice. I reassure him that that is not so. Reasonable written notice is required. This is defined as giving, at least seven days before a property is to be entered, information to the owner and the occupier of the council’s intention to enter the property, the reason for entering the property and the days and times when the property is to be entered.

However, there are some emergency provisions where there can be entry by a council worker for urgent action, but only for public health and safety reasons should emergent conditions warrant it. The power of entry other than to a home on the property is then available to carry out work which may be exercised without giving notice but only if it is justified on public safety grounds. They are the main matters that need attention this afternoon. There were some matters of detail that I would be pleased to address with individual members should they wish to further discuss these with me at a later time.

I want to put on record my sincere congratulations to the departmental team who have worked so hard not only on the City of Brisbane Bill but also on the amendments to the Local Government Act last year and before that. Their good names should be read into the record, and so I will do that. My sincere thanks to Ross Alcorn, Rhyl Hurley, Sally McCone, Rosie Caulfied, Jo Chiu, Robyn Taylor, Kate McMahon, Sarah McPherson, Elizabeth Altoft, Kylie Barnes and the inimitable David Dobbs. I recognise the tremendous cooperation we have had from Jude Munro and the staff of the council. I recognise the vibrant debate that we have also had with Campbell Newman and his team and with Shayne Sutton, the opposition leader, and her team. It has been difficult to find a fair and balanced way forward between the majority party and the opposition on several occasions, although I think we have found that way forward now. It is really clear, and I put on the record, that the Lord Mayor and the opposition leader have demonstrated to me their very strong commitment to their responsibilities as elected members of the Brisbane City Council.

In conclusion, local government is critical to the future of Queensland and in the spirit of the Queensland Constitution the state stands committed to working with this third sphere of government to deliver a stronger Queensland for this generation and the next. The City of Brisbane Bill has been purposefully designed to encourage practitioners to understand the spirit of the legislation, not just the letter of the law. The bill provides for a new, modernised statutory local government framework for the City of Brisbane in the face of a new era of growth and development. This is an important step forward for Australia’s premier capital city and for Queensland. I commend this bill to the House.

XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 332--

Mr WELLINGTON (4.46 pm): In the minister’s reply she spoke about the reasons these significant amendments have been introduced--because of the size of the Brisbane City Council, the large budget that the Brisbane City Council has and the very detailed matters that the council has to consider. My question in relation to clause 332 is: is it proposed that this right to secrecy provision will be extended to other large councils, such as the Sunshine Coast Regional Council?

Ms BOYLE: I thank the member for the question. No, there is no proposal--no discussion at all--that that should be so. The difference with the Brisbane City Council is the existence--on the record and it has been so for many years and is continued in the City of Brisbane Bill--of the E&C Committee, which is a cabinet-like structure and which is not the practice of other local governments. No discussions have taken place in regard to this provision applying to any other councils and it is not my intention to hold such discussions.
Clause 333--
Mr WELLINGTON (4.47 pm): I take the minister to subclause 4 of clause 333, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (4) Without limiting subsection (3), the Minister may--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: this is a discretionary provision--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: make guidelines about a publication scheme of the Brisbane City Council requiring the scheme to set out that the council has available information of or about the council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee.
XML.Hansard-Body: Could the minister explain why she needs that discretion? Could the minister also give some advice about the types of matters that are considered in the council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee? I am looking to the boundaries of the matters that are considered under those committees.

Ms BOYLE: The relevant minister in this case is the state government minister responsible for the Right to Information Act, and that is the Premier. In terms of the exemptions for cabinet, the Premier has overseen the development of our publication guidelines, which are now printed in the ministerial handbook. So the intention with the Brisbane City Council is that the Premier, as the responsible minister, would similarly develop guidelines about the publication of decisions or matters that go before the E&C Committee. That that has not been done before means that at this stage we cannot be too prescriptive about what will be in those guidelines, other than my understanding is that it is the Premier’s intention to follow the pattern of those requirements for state cabinet and the release of publications following cabinet, as outlined in the ministerial handbook.

Mr WELLINGTON: Is it proposed that those guidelines will be available and completed prior to this bill becoming law? Could the minister clarify the boundaries of the matters that are considered by the council’s Establishment and Coordination Committee?

Ms BOYLE: So far as the first question is concerned, no, it is highly unlikely that those publication guidelines will be decided prior to 1 July. They are a matter for the Premier to work on and no announcement has presently been made about when they will be complete.

The E&C Committee is the pre-eminent Brisbane City Council standing committee. Its membership comprises the mayor and the chairs of all other standing committees of the BCC. The bill recognises this administrative practice. The Establishment and Coordination Committee may consider any business of the council. It may consider future planning matters or future policy decisions. Its minutes have not been widely circulated or published. So it is the Lord Mayor’s view that that standing committee of the council will operate as it has after this bill progresses through the House today and becomes law. The right to information provisions will only be validating the practice that has been occurring with the E&C Committee for many years.
Mr WELLINGTON (4.52 pm): I take the minister to schedule 3 of the Right to Information Act 2009, subsection 2(3), which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Without limiting subsection (1), the following documents are taken to be documents comprised exclusively of exempt information under subsection (1)--
XML.Hansard-Body: My question is: why can we not remove and delete the opening words ‘Without limiting subsection (1)’ and limit, restrict, isolate the matters that are intended? When I read that section it seems it is as wide as it can be. I think we need to make it very clear what is deemed to be covered by this section. My request is that the minister remove the opening words ‘Without limiting subsection (1)’ and start that clause with ‘The following documents are taken to be documents’ to be covered in that section.

Ms BOYLE: I accept the point of view of the member for Nicklin. These are words that have been drafted by those who are specialists in the drafting of legislation. I do not myself see that there is much of a difference between keeping in those words, but I would not be prepared to withdraw them on the spot without further discussion with the parliamentary draftsperson.
Mr WELLINGTON: I take the minister to schedule 3, subsection 2(4), which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A report of factual or statistical information attached to a document mentioned in subsection (3) is exempt information under subsection (1) only if--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (b) it was brought into existence for the consideration of Cabinet or for the State’s budgetary processes.
XML.Hansard-Body: Again I ask: why is it not possible to have the following range of words included: ‘to specify’, ‘to limit’, ‘to restrict’ the range or matter that could be taken into the secret chamber? My suggestion is that we could have additional words ‘ranging from or including all or some of the following’. My preferred wording would be ‘it was brought into existence only for the consideration of the committee’, or ‘it was brought into existence solely for the consideration of the committee’, or ‘it was brought into existence specifically for the consideration of the committee’.

What I am trying to do is to make sure that there is not an abuse where material is taken to this committee which otherwise should not be taken to the committee. My intention in raising this matter is to make it very clear what material can and what material cannot go into this committee--which material is not available for release to the public until 10 years later.

Ms BOYLE:
I understand the point of view of the honourable member but I do not believe that we can satisfy it this afternoon. We are not trying to restrict the business of the Establishment and Coordination Committee. Through this and other clauses we are recognising its existence and attesting to its importance as a mini cabinet of the City of Brisbane which, as has been mentioned by several members, is arguably the largest council in the world, certainly in Australia. This is a major multibillion dollar corporation. It is reasonable that the chairs of the standing committees can meet, can have materials brought into being for their consideration and that have some exemption provisions under the Right to Information Act.

Our objective today is not to limit those matters, not from the point of view of the government, but instead to prescribe some publication in relation to the decisions or the outcomes of those committee proceedings. As has been mentioned earlier, that will be a matter for the Premier as the responsible minister in the months ahead.
