XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Workers’ Compensation & Rehabilitation & Or Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 18 May (see p. 1547), on motion of Mr Dick--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (5.06 pm): Labor’s TJ Ryan may have introduced Queensland’s first compulsory workers compensation scheme in 1916, but in 1995 and, indeed, in 2010 it has been his political offspring that has all but brought the scheme to its financial knees, to the verge of insolvency and decay. There has been an enormous journey, an extraordinary effluxion of time and a compromising of ideology in the nine decades since TJ Ryan introduced the scheme. The Labor Party led by Anna Bligh in 2010 is but a pale imitation of the party headed in 1916 by TJ Ryan, a man whose principles were honed and sharpened in the forge of 20th century class warfare--the battle over basic workers entitlements, wages and conditions.

TJ Ryan’s Labor Party is a far cry from the supercilious, smarmy, sugary spivs of the modern-day Labor Party, who mouth platitudes as they watch over the decay of the workers compensation scheme, as they sit back in the comfort of their offices in full knowledge of diligent and loyal health workers opening yet another very empty pay packet. TJ Ryan would never have tolerated such a fundamental breach of faith with those who are most loyal to him or he to them. He, in good conscience, could never have let his administration become so divorced, so detached, so cold, so removed, so disconnected from his roots and from those who had given his party its very lifeblood.

It is said of politics that a day is a long time. In the context of Labor’s journey in the last century, it has been an indistinguishable millennium. Until two decades ago, in Queensland people largely took for granted competent public administration, administration built around prudent financial outcomes, value for tax dollars spent, timely service delivery, the best performing economy in Australia, lower taxes, a world-class public hospital system, educational outcomes amongst the best in Australia, timely construction of infrastructure such as bridges, dams and roads and, indeed, a well-balanced and fair workers compensation scheme with adequate reserves to meet the needs of employers and, more importantly, injured workers.

Two decades later, Queenslanders’ expectations of their government have been so lowered that they no longer have any such expectation of their government. Indeed, they dare not expect excellence from their government for fear that it be blunted by the likely revelation of disappointment. This basic expectation of government has been redefined by two decades of waste, political and administrative incompetence, imprudent financial outcomes, little value for tax dollars paid, untimely service delivery, the second worst performing economy in Australia, a failing public hospital system, the worst educational outcomes in the country, neglected infrastructure, and when it is built it is years late and billions of dollars over budget, and a workers compensation scheme on the very verge of collapse.

The common denominator in this administrative and financial collapse of the basic fabric of public service administration in Queensland has been almost 20 unbroken years of Labor government. When the Queensland government changed in 1989, it was around the question of malfeasance and integrity of government and not around basic service delivery which people took for granted. Today the focus on the Labor government is not just on malfeasance and integrity of government but also on its ability to effectively administer the basic organs of government. Nowhere is this fundamental administrative incompetence more evident than its handling of the workers compensation scheme and nowhere is its supercilious, sugary, smarmy spin more evident than the WorkCover scheme--a largely fraudulent narrative of excuses based around the all too used scapegoat of the global financial crisis.

Labor would have us believe that the WorkCover scheme was going swimmingly before the GFC. But its largest investment losses occurred more than 12 months before the term ‘global financial crisis’, or GFC, had even been invented. Indeed, if one looks at the WorkCover’s annual reports one can see verification of that fact. In 2005-06, WorkCover had an underwriting profit result of $576 million. Their investment income in that year was a paltry $374,000. Yet in the following year they had an underwriting profit result of minus $323 million and an investment income of $411 million. Indeed, insofar as their underwriting profit was concerned, they had a $900 million turnaround in their underwriting position--that is, from the positive towards the negative in 2006-07. That was despite what were record investment incomes. The situation deteriorated year on year from there on in.

The common denominator was not the global financial crisis; it was indeed something else. Mismanagement, a lack of financial prudence and a giveaway mentality have now been cloaked in the veil of the great GFC bogeyman. Queenslanders deserve far more than to have the custodians of their workplace injury insurance scheme insult their intelligence by blaming external forces for what is intrinsically and basically an internal management problem. The GFC had an effect, but its effect was minor. The Deloitte report indicated that unfunded liabilities of the scheme would be more than $8 billion in a few years, taking the problem beyond the realms of an investment earnings issue.

What are the fundamental faults of the current scheme, the source of its malaise? For many years the scheme earned major returns on its investments. Did the government decide to properly manage these windfalls, to tuck them away for a rainy day? No. It decided to increase the payouts, to give it all away. The government coupled these windfall investment earnings, which mesmerised them to their very core, with a laissez faire giveaway attitude--an attitude which was akin to a sideshow where, as they say, every child player wins a prize. Indeed, almost every claimant did win and they won big time and they won some more. But, ultimately, there are always going to be losers. For all of this opulence, for this giveaway disposition, someone had to pay the piper. There had to be losers. The losers are the businesses of Queensland which are burdened with higher premiums and higher excesses. If you rang up and made a demand, you received.

Proper common law case management was a concept as alien as icebergs in a desert--just ask and you will receive. Even plaintiff lawyers were embarrassed at the propensity for capitulation of the WorkCover common law division. They were not a pushover; they pre-emptively fell over. During precourt conferences it was not unusual for the common law division to offer amounts which were beyond the wildest dreams of not just the claimants but the most ambitious ambit claims of the plaintiff’s lawyer. This spectacle of mismanagement left more than one lawyer within the common law division in an attitude of disbelief. We have heard that being said publicly, and we have seen that from information which has recently come to the public fore.

Indeed, a former lawyer for the common law division told me personally that he witnessed the inglorious spectacle of an argument between a claimant and their lawyer, but not for the reason that you would think, Madam Deputy Speaker--that is, the claimant not receiving what they considered to be a just payout. It arose because the claimant’s lawyer had told the client most optimistically to expect a little over $100,000 for their injury. Yet when they attended a precourt conference and asked the common law division what payment offer would be made, the division offered in excess of $200,000. The plaintiff’s lawyer was stunned and the claimant was furious in their assertion that their lawyer was selling them short. This was a gravy train of Labor’s making, a gravy train which would inevitably run dry but did not need to in such spectacular fashion. There was no hunger, no appetite, no energy to contest claims--applying equally to the most flimsy or speculative of claims. Hand it out and hand it out was WorkCover’s motto.
Ninety-eight per cent of common law claims were settled outside of court--no contest, no questions asked, just shovel it out, with no reference to the fact that there was a tomorrow.
Ms Grace: Where’s your proof?

Mr SPRINGBORG: Indeed, as the member for Brisbane Central interjects, it is very, very clear that one of the fundamental problems which has been identified through what we know of the Deloitte report and what has been publicly ventilated is the fact that this division has not properly managed its common law claims, has not properly scrutinised them and has not properly contested them, and that is a matter of fact.

Lawyers in the common law division were little more than office ornaments, subsumed in a culture of payout--do not contest and do not challenge--and many of them were dismayed by what seemed to be this direction. Queensland employers could but sit idly by and watch their advocate, apparently compromised, roll over time and time again, when their only expectation was that there would be just and proper scrutiny of the common law claim. Effectively there was no champion for Queensland employers, stunned by the realisation that there would soon be a day of reckoning--that day of reckoning taking the form of higher premiums and the day of reckoning for Queensland workers being the restrictions on the scope of their claims.

Not one person--not one--would argue against an injured worker receiving just recompense--compensation, assistance, and rehabilitation to help them return gainfully to employment--or entitlements for life if they cannot return to work. All of these things were properly designed to protect workers and their families in the event of workplace injury or disease or death. No-one ever envisaged a scheme as badly mismanaged, as badly regulated, as open to abuse as what we have seen under the Bligh Labor government. This scheme needed tightening. It needed a refocusing to make sure that those most in need actually received.

As we debate injuries in the workplace and the scheme designed to compensate legitimate claims for such injuries, we do so with the knowledge that, under this Labor government and its so-called mantra of protecting workers, Queensland has one of the highest death and injury rates in workplaces of any Australian state or territory. It is one of the most complicated, overregulated systems, with little or no focus on prevention and early intervention. This point was raised by the Queensland Law Society in its submission that identified the onerous duty imposed on employers in Queensland by the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1995.

Whilst the minister has crafted a narrative of diversion and deception to justify his actions, he has refused to justify his reform with associated openness. There has been no discovery or disclosure of the actuarial reports relied upon by the government as the basis for this legislation. Despite the integrity and active participation of interest groups, such as Commerce Queensland and the Queensland Law Society, there has been no release of that data. This has left not only the opposition but also many of the consultation groups smelling a rat. These reforms are veneered under a smear of suspicion and duplicity. We are asked to vote to support new laws simply on the say-so of a government which has established a new pinnacle of dishonesty and deception since the last state election. This is a step I and the LNP are reluctant to take.

The opposition was stymied at every turn in its request for information. Our attempts to gain access to the actuarial reports under right to information were blocked. This was done on the basis that applications made to WorkCover fell outside the RTI Act for commercial-in-confidence reasons. This is strange indeed, as WorkCover is compulsory for all employees, with the scheme having a virtual monopoly on insurance, with the release of such information unlikely to compromise its position with the few self-insured. Confidence in his approach, confidence in his legislation, should bend the minister towards the release of the actuarial data relied upon to advance these reforms. The minister’s refusal to do so will see a perpetual question mark placed over his legislation and the foundations of the change which he champions in this place.

As history records, Queensland Labor and deliberate deception on WorkCover crises are not strange bedfellows. They have shared the pillow more than once--the last time in 1995, on the eve of the state election, when Matt Foley, then minister responsible for the scheme, told the parliamentary estimates committee that the scheme was actuarially sound. This was deception on the eve of a state election--something which Labor is most comfortable with. It worked then, so why would the 2009 state election be any different, when the government deceived on privatisation and fuel tax and, as we now know, even the state’s WorkCover finances?

The sense of deja vu must now be obvious to all. Within weeks of the 1995 state poll, which Labor narrowly won--with 46.6 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, I might say--the Labor Party admitted that the workers compensation scheme was on the verge of insolvency and was $300 million in the red. It admitted just after the election that the WorkCover scheme in Queensland was on the verge of insolvency and was $300 million in the red. Does it sound familiar? It should. Oh, how things change that stay the same. It was left to the then coalition government, as is the lot of conservative governments, to fix the financial mess made by Labor of the once proud scheme. In the absence of openness or the disclosure of actuarial data to justify these changes, we are left to take this government and this minister at face value. A positive step to do so should be against one’s better judgement based on its record of deceit.

WorkCover Queensland, the entity responsible for the administration of the workers compensation and rehabilitation scheme, is a government owned statutory authority. In 2008-09 it insured more than 156,000 employers and registered over 92,390 statutory and 3,600 common law claims. The entity employs 840 people across Queensland. Its claimed philosophy is to provide the best possible benefits and rehabilitation programs for injured workers at the lowest possible premium for employers. Has this been delivered, when premiums are now to be raised, Queensland workplaces are amongst the most unsafe in the country and the scheme is reaching the point of collapse?

Under WorkCover, there are two options available for injured workers. The first is the statutory scheme offering direct lodgement with WorkCover. It provides a worker who suffers an injury at work entitlement to statutory benefit under a no-fault system. A person is entitled to statutory benefits if their injury was caused by work, irrespective of whether the employer was at fault for the injury. Benefits may include hospital and medical expenses, lost wages or lump sum compensation payment for permanent impairment.

The second avenue is the common law scheme that can be settled through the courts. It is the common law claims and the associated cost to the scheme that have contributed to the present situation. The bill includes provision for WorkCover to impose higher premiums on an employer if their premium rate repeatedly exceeds the relevant industry rate. It also introduces a provision clarifying an issue of law that arose in the case of Bourk v Power Serve which resulted in an employer’s automatic presumption of negligence when an injury occurred under the Workplace Health and Safety Act. A plaintiff then had the established grounds for their common law claim, as negligence was presumed under the Workplace Health and Safety Act. A respondent was then placed at great difficulty in defending themselves against such an automatic presumption of negligence, when in fact there may not have been any negligence at all.

Significantly, this bill harmonises common law claims through the scheme with the Civil Liability Act 2003. Capping limits on claims in line with the Civil Liability Act should move a number of smaller claims out of the common law scheme to the statutory scheme. Superficially, the changes being put forward should assist in putting a sounder, financially secure base under the scheme. They should minimise speculative claims.

The introduction of a contributory negligence discount that can be applied to payouts has merits. Why should someone who has tripped over their shoelaces after being reminded to tie them up over and over be entitled to as much as someone who has slipped in a dangerous situation? Clearly, they should not. Should someone who is intoxicated at work and who is injured be entitled to the same amount as someone who is not intoxicated and who is injured? Absolutely not. They are new provisions which are contained in the government’s legislation and on the surface we support. Introduction of the contributory negligence principle may lead to more personal responsibility in the workplace, a reduction in claims and maybe a reduction in the upward pressure on premiums. Speculative claims serve no-one, not worker nor employer.

The bill contains provisions that allow for the awarding of costs against a person whose common law claim is dismissed. In his summary, the minister should inform the House of how many common law claims have been dismissed in the last three years. Theoretically and most likely, in a practical sense, this should have the effect of deterring non-genuine common law claims. This bill uses the Civil Liability Act and its schedule as the basis of its statutory provisions, with the principle of no fault for its payments. By contrast, the common law scheme is based on established negligence.

Amendments contained in this legislation are as useless as window-dressing unless they are complemented with cultural change. Arguably, if WorkCover had contested more speculative claims, if they had argued more strongly, if they had pursued more fervently the merits of each case, then none of this may have been necessary. When these amendments pass, as they inevitably will on their own, nothing will change. Clear direction of intent must be conveyed to WorkCover that they must contest common law claims more aggressively. Their job, after all, is to sort the wheat from the chaff, to separate the genuine from the non-genuine claim, to sort merit from the lack of merit. If that is their modus operandi then a fundamental and necessary change has been achieved. If not then the legislation is as worthless as the paper on which it is written.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House:

Condemns the ongoing failure to properly pay Queensland Health workers their proper salary and entitlements and calls for the urgent creation of a commission of inquiry that will investigate and report on the failed payroll system including:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. the involvement, knowledge and responsibilities of Ministers Gordon Nuttall, Stephen Robertson, Paul Lucas and Robert Schwarten;
2. any prior warnings of potential failures of the new computerised payroll system;
3. the cost, including anticipated future cost, of restoring a working payroll system for Queensland Health employees; and
4. the anticipated timeframe upon which it is expected a fully operational payroll system will be operational.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is interesting on the day after the budget was brought down to have a look at what the Treasurer, the member for Mount Coot-tha, said yesterday about what state governments are about providing--that is, services. This year $42 billion will be expended for the 4 million people of Queensland. The Treasurer said in his budget speech at 2.30 pm yesterday--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In this State Budget we report back and recommit ourselves to this task, providing Queenslanders with a chance at the dignity of work--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: But there is no mention of paying them. He continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is Labor’s first commitment and our calling.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: But they will not necessarily pay them. He continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The fair go ... the advancement of all, regardless of where you line up at the start.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is a bit hard to be halfway through the race--and people find out that even though they are doing the work they are not being paid for it and the government cannot pay--and find out that this is acceptable for a Labor government when it claims that its interest is its workers.
What did we find under the heading ‘Helping Queensland households’? The Treasurer stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A helping hand to those who need it most--as is our calling.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is all very Churchillian, but it would be nice for those who work for Queensland Health, whether they be the doctors, nurses or allied health professionals or the orderlies, cleaners or the thousands of other workers, to be paid. Under the section of the budget speech headed ‘Investing in health and hospitals’, there is not one word about paying our workers on time. Instead of that we get a commitment in the budget papers of $4 million to supposedly fix this payroll scheme. Clearly, it is going to take a lot more than $4 million to fix it when we hear of the number of hours that people are doing to try to fix up the thousands of current payroll issues. Finally, the Treasurer said yesterday--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We are a proud government, determined to continue the legacy of Labor in building a modern Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: One where we do not pay our health workers! He continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... proud of our commitment to jobs and to the workers of Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: These are workers who obviously will not be paid. He again continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Through the tumult of the last two years, we have put the dignity of work as the guiding light for our policies.
XML.Hansard-Body: He made no point about the dignity of pay. That is the interesting thing about this government. It is big on the Churchillian statements, but when it comes to the things that state governments are supposed to provide--a decent day’s pay for a decent day’s work--it has been unable to do it for 12 weeks or six pay cycles.

That is why we have moved this motion. We have not done this lightly. The consequence of this motion that calls for the creation of a commission of inquiry does implicate a number of ministers. It implicates former health minister Gordon Nuttall, the former member for Sandgate; former health minister Stephen Robertson, the member for Stretton; the current health minister, Paul Lucas, the member for Lytton; and Robert Schwarten, the member for Rockhampton and Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology.

Under the Westminster tradition, ministers have responsibility for things that happen in their ministry. One of the most remarkable things that we heard about two or three sitting weeks ago was the Minister for Health, the member for Lytton, state that as a solicitor he had no knowledge of computer technology and nor did his colleague from Rockhampton, the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology, who is a former teacher and a former chippie. In his words, there was no need for them to uphold the normal Westminster traditions. They would not take the Westminster view of responsibility. They denied responsibility for what has happened in Queensland Health and throughout this state for the last 12 weeks.

The former member for Sandgate, Gordon Nuttall, was responsible for signing the 10-year IT contract in 2005 without it going to tender. The member for Rockhampton, Robert Schwarten, is the minister responsible for whole-of-government ICT and is responsible for the agency CorpTech. CorpTech is directly responsible for delivering the new Queensland Health pay system. It was part of shared services.

The member for Currumbin, the member for Lockyer and I came into this House in 2004. We all remember going to our first estimates committee where we heard about the benefits of shared services and how it was going to save money across government. It has done so in other jurisdictions but not under Labor in Queensland. We cannot find out the true details of how much it is costing. That is what a commission of inquiry would investigate and report on. It would not report on the narrow terms of reference that the Auditor-General will have been given. We know that is the Labor way--that is, to send something away and get a report subsequently when the media are not necessarily interested in it anymore. A damning report, such as the one on the A1GP fiasco, would come down some weeks or some months later and the government would say, ‘That is all right. We have moved on.’ Why would it have moved on? Because there is another crisis.

That is the problem with this state Labor government. Since 1989 we have had, in portfolio after portfolio, services that are the responsibility of the state government to provide unable to be provided, crisis after crisis and minister after minister refusing to take responsibility. The people who suffer at the end of all of this are the workers of Queensland--the people who deserve to be paid.

The former minister for health, Stephen Robertson, and the current Minister for Health, Paul Lucas, were responsible for the management, oversight and decision to go live with this system, to ensure a smooth transition to the new payroll system and to have contingency measures in place if something went wrong. I know that the member for Currumbin, the shadow minister, has put out numerous press releases about this very matter since September last year. But these warnings were ignored. Clearly, the information that the shadow minister was receiving was accurate. The government failed to act on the advice.

The health minister was personally and regularly briefed about this payroll system. He should be held responsible for what has happened in his department. There is very clear evidence that the minister should have known some time ago that the health department payroll project was a high-risk venture which was not ready for rollout. The health minister is yet to explain why the payroll system was allowed to go ahead without a contingency plan in place. The people who are suffering are the people whom we asked about in parliament this morning. Those questions were ruled out of order. But this government needs to answer those questions.

There are other issues involved here. There were prior warnings of potential failures. We know that an RTI request from 2008 shows that the Shared Service Initiative has not delivered any viable alternatives to Queensland Health in the past four years and it has cost burnt at least $400 million. As we have already said, with existing problems and incomplete testing the program still went live. Millions and millions of dollars have been poured into the system, yet the checks and balances were overlooked.

As we have said, there has been a cost burn attributable to Health of approximately $100 million. The budget papers allocate just $4 million to fixing the payroll mess. That is a joke. There is no way that the opposition or the public could guess at the financial cost of fixing this mess. I think the Labor government has no idea, either. It has no idea how bad the mess is. It is totally out of its depth.

Beyond the direct financial cost there are many other costs involved with the payroll debacle. There are reputation costs. Who is going to want to work for Queensland Health after what has happened? We are already hearing anecdotal evidence about this. I met a nurse in Mapoon who had worked for Queensland Health in regional Queensland for a number of years. That is a very small community on the cape. She said to me about three weeks ago that after having her pay affected as it has been she has taken a contract in regional New South Wales. That is anecdotal evidence that we are getting from around the state. There are obviously other junior doctors, nurses and allied health professionals who feel the same. Other workers, especially casuals or those with unusual leave entitlements, have faced ramifications due to the fact that this government has not been able to pay its workers properly.

The final aspect of this motion asks about the anticipated time frame. When can Queensland Health workers expect to be paid by a fully operational payroll? This government has no idea. It cannot say when the system will become fully operational. Even the Nurses Union--that great friend of this Labor government--says that there is no idea, after its meetings with the government, when this payroll system will become operational. It has given this government supposedly to the end of the financial year, but there is no confidence that it will be fixed by the end of the financial year. Queensland Health workers and all other public servants throughout Queensland deserve to have these questions answered. That is why we have called for a commission of inquiry. Tonight I urge all members to vote in support of this motion.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (5.40 pm): I second the motion. Tonight we are talking of a process that commenced a number of years ago but in March this year went live and was let loose on the employees of Queensland Health with devastating consequences--devastating for the employees themselves and devastating for their family members. Doctors, nurses, cooks and many others have been abandoned by this government and the health minister. In fact, the health minister’s first response to this fiasco was to absolve himself of any liability and any responsibility. The doctors, the nurses, the cooks and the maintenance workers need a champion--someone who is able to ask the hard questions of the health minister and his executive team and ask how his department allowed the SAP system to go live and why so many lives have been torn apart by this negligence.

A review under the Commissions of Inquiry Act 1950 allows for powers to compel witnesses, hold witnesses in contempt and commissions are not bound by rules as to procedure or evidence. The inquiry will guarantee the following: (1) it will be held in public; (2) it will call members of the government and other parties to give evidence and be cross-examined in public; (3) it will compel the production of documents; and (4) it will provide wide-ranging recommendations as a consequence of its findings. There is no doubt that there is significant public concern and real doubt about what took place leading up to the debacle in March of this year. This needs the full glare of an independent inquiry to make accountable those who are liable for what has taken place.

Yesterday in this chamber I gave a speech about a number of matters that post event showed how ill-prepared the minister was and his executive was in relation to what has occurred. But that did not deal with why it happened. What the inquiry will establish is clearly who the officers were who determined the process was ready to go; the involvement, if any, of the director-general, the deputy director-general for corporate services and the project team officers; the process to acquire the system; whether testing was done and by whom; and, importantly, if any pressure was exerted to activate this system well and truly before it should have gone live, because we know the consequences of what happened in March of this year.

The fallout has been well reported, but it clearly includes employees not getting their pay in full or not getting it at all. People are missing mortgage repayments, thus placing at risk their homes, and people are terminating their employment with Queensland Health but not being able to obtain severance documents, to name but a few. If that is not bad enough, there is now a major impact upon the morale of nursing staff across this state. I was talking to a nurse last night who had been with Queensland Health for 40 years and she was telling me that nursing staff are stressed because they do not know if their pay will be in their account every second Wednesday. They do not know what to do and they do not know who to turn to.

There has been a massive redirection of resources from Deputy Director-General Mike Walsh all the way down, and every time one person is moved it leaves a gap that has to be filled. Every time that occurs there is a domino impact. It is like trying to plug the holes in the dyke: at some point in time you run out of fingers, and in this case you run out of people. Payroll units are under incredible stress dealing with increasing amendments, putting other tasks on the backburner or handing them to junior staff who do not have the competence to deal with them, thus again increasing the risk of further mistakes occurring. But that is not bad enough. In April 2010 this appeared in a notice from QNU involving nurse unit managers--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This has led to an inability for many to adequately perform their nurse unit manager role and ultimately to ensure the safety of staff and themselves.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So it is now impacting across the whole nursing system and placing the lives and the care and the condition of patients at risk on a regular basis.
XML.Hansard-Body: This process will allow the full light of a public inquiry into a disreputable, a disgusting and a very sad situation that has rolled out across this state and will roll out for months to come. We are coming now to the end of the financial year. I can guarantee members that this will go on for months and months. To think that $4 million will fix it is simply a joke!
Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (5.45 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That all words after “House” be deleted and the following words inserted:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • notes the Opposition’s call for an investigation into this matter by the Auditor-General;

• recognises the importance of the independent Queensland Audit Office producing a report to Parliament on all aspects of the Queensland health payroll implementation that the Auditor-General sees fit;
• notes that the Auditor-General is currently preparing a report on the implementation of the health payroll system;
• supports the Auditor-General being able to complete his investigation and report unfettered;
• expresses its full support and confidence in the independence and rigour of the Queensland Audit Office; and
• acknowledges the additional expertise KPMG brings to its separate review report into payroll implementation, to be delivered upon completion of the Auditor-general report.
XML.Hansard-Body: I start by reaffirming the government’s commitment to fix the problems associated with the implementation of Queensland Health’s new payroll system. I have spoken in this place many times on this issue over the past months to apologise to our hardworking staff and to update the parliament and the public on developments to stabilise the new system. I have met with front-line Health staff and payroll staff across many facilities and districts, particularly nurse unit managers, operational staff who have high levels of casual staff and payroll hub staff. The Minister for Public Works and I sat down with them in Rockhampton as they showed us how they enter data. I have personally apologised to them for the difficulties this payroll implementation has caused. I have heard the issues that they have faced on the ground, sought their advice about how to address the immediate challenges and also discussed how we might improve the payroll business process into the future.

What have those opposite done? What is their solution? What have been their constructive suggestions? On 13 April, in response to the payroll implementation, the Leader of the Opposition came into the House and attacked the victims. He had a go at the nurses through the Queensland Nurses Union as a base political move. The government is actually interested in finding solutions--getting the job done. It is clear that Queensland Health employees and the government have been let down by the new system, and it became evident that it would not be sufficient for this to be examined and dealt with on a purely internal basis. That is why we brought in KPMG to oversee the stabilisation of the new system to focus on getting people paid and to review business processes overall going forward.

I do not need to spend much time talking about the independence of KPMG. It actually costed the Victorian Liberal Party election commitment in 2006 and the Liberal Party director is a former senior manager at KPMG. It has served governments with distinction. But that was not good enough for the member for Caloundra, because then he wanted a judicial inquiry for a short period time. On 13 April he said, ‘KPMG shouldn’t be the sole source of information. We’ll have a judicial inquiry.’ Then they forgot about that, because that was not the flavour of the month. On 20 April the member for Clayfield called on the Auditor-General to investigate the payroll implementation. He was quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: These are important matters of public interest. It is important that the independent Auditor-General report to parliament on all aspects of this fiasco.
XML.Hansard-Body: On 19 April he and the member for Currumbin wrote to the Auditor-General seeking the Auditor-General to deal with it. Of course, the Auditor-General, with the government’s support, is dealing with it. So we have two independent inquiries--KPMG and the Auditor-General--and that does not satisfy the opposition. What is worse is that those opposite have not even got the response to them. They actually have not even seen the answers to them. So they called in KPMG. They supported KPMG. They called in the Auditor-General and then they did not like how it went. So now of course what is their solution? Of all the people that you would want to put in charge of finding a solution, they are calling in the lawyers in calling for a royal commission. As if the tens of millions of dollars that a royal commission would spend and the time that it would take would do one thing about paying our nurses!
Mr McArdle: You think not paying nurses is a joke!
Mr LUCAS: I had the good grace to be quiet during your contribution.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable member for Caloundra!

Mr LUCAS: I heard the honourable members opposite in silence on this matter. It is a serious matter. What did they want to do? Call in the lawyers! Call in the lawyers! Lawyers are masters at hindsight. What we need is to stabilise this pay system and work out what needs to be done for the future. That is why we have those independent people there. What is the government doing? We are continuing to work hard in terms of putting in place emergency assistance processes with local contingencies with no net financial disadvantage to make sure our staff are not disadvantaged, in consultation with unions. We are committed to ensuring that no staff member is directly financially disadvantaged as a result of the pay issues. We are dealing with the Australian Taxation Office. We are also working with RemServ and the government’s service provider to assist staff who may have salary sacrifice payments, and similarly with superannuation. We are doing everything in our power to reduce incorrect pays. We are working further to increase the efficiency of the system.

I have to say this--and I will say it over and over again: it is not satisfactory. But let us stop playing the sleazy politics of the opposition. On 13 April they blamed the victims. On 20 April they called for the Auditor-General. On 30 April they criticised KPMG, which they previously supported, and called for a judicial inquiry. On 21 May they criticised KPMG’s cooperation with the Auditor-General. Now they refuse to support the independence of the Auditor-General and have called for a royal commission. They wanted an Auditor-General and they got it. They wanted KPMG and they got it. They wanted the changes in staff and they got it and now they do not want them. One thing is for sure: calling in the tens of millions of dollars for a royal commission when there has not been one iota of evidence to suggest official misconduct--and remember we also have a CMC--speaks volumes about what the opposition members have said. They have not produced one document to suggest it.

Although during the debate on this motion the member for Caloundra referred to a whole lot of senior public servants, he did not name one in a motion, because this is a politically motivated act and will do nothing to sort our nurses’ pay.

Tabled paper: Copy of a media release, dated 30 April 2010, titled ‘Independent inquiry needed for health pay crisis’ [ 2391 ].
Tabled paper: Copy of a Brisbane Times article, dated 20 April 2010, titled ‘Auditor-General must investigate health pay bungle: LNP’ [ 2392 ].

XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (5.50 pm): I rise to second the motion moved by the Deputy Premier. At the outset, I reiterate the words of the Deputy Premier. This opposition is simply on a political witch-hunt. It is not interested one iota in solving this problem. It is not interested in nurses’ pay. It is not interested in any shape or form in trying to get to the bottom of this matter. All it wants to do is to chuck millions and millions of dollars down the political lavatory.
Mr Elmes interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I heard you in silence.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Noosa. The minister has a point.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Millions and millions of dollars which could go into our health system would go into a royal commission. I will tell members what this is. It is an absolute slap in the face for the Auditor-General. The members opposite wanted to bring in the Auditor-General. ‘Bring in the Auditor-General,’ they said. ‘We are not happy with KPMG. We think they are biased.’ They were not game to say that outside, of course, but that is basically what they said. So they slurred the name of KPMG in this place. Then they went on to say that they wanted the Auditor-General. But were they happy with what the Auditor-General was doing? No. By the way, he reports to this parliament, where it can be debated, on the 29th of this month. That does not satisfy them. The Auditor-General has the right to go to the bottom of every single document, every single piece of paper that is around in the bureaucracy that he can get his hands on.

But they are not satisfied with that. They have these RTI documents over there, and out of all of those they cannot find one where I have said on any occasion that it is right to go or that I have been advised that it is not right to go--not one! Yet on that basis they want to have a royal commission that might cost--I don’t know; let the lawyers loose with the chequebook. I do not know how much it might cost--$20 million or $30 million. Before the Auditor-General has a chance to report to this parliament they say straightaway, ‘We do not trust the Auditor-General.’ I trust the Auditor-General. I do not know what he is going to say. I have not seen his report yet. But I am certain of one thing: his independence remains intact and his dignity to investigate this matter ought not be besmirched in this place, to which he has to report. That is exactly what this motion is.

We have over a period of time heard an attack on SAP by all of those who have not been game to go outside to say it--that those systems are no good. That has been said in this parliament. All I can say is what I have continually said. I have never had advice that any of these problems may arise. Never have I had that and there is no document that I have ever seen that tells me that this would be a disaster. So, on that basis, what was I to do? Was I to say, ‘No, you can’t go on that date. Nobody has told me that there is anything wrong with it, but I am just going to second-guess and say, “No, there is something wrong with it,” and so you don’t do it,’ when four people, who are highly paid by the government to make this decision, have made that decision to do so? Did I have any evidence put before me by the opposition to say, ‘No, this is a problem’? No, I did not. Otherwise I would have done something about it. So on the basis of no complaint, on the basis of no evidence, I was suddenly going to intervene in a process that was being rolled out? As it turns out, it should not have happened. The Minister for Health has said that. I have said that. But the reality is that we were no more likely to intervene in the process than I would in building contracts that we have established all over Queensland on the basis of somebody walking past me in the street and saying, ‘I don’t think you should build that there.’

Where is the evidence for a royal commission? Where is this burning desire to say that we are a mob of crooks? I tell members where it is: it is with those opposite--the honourable members who sit over there, in a policy-free vacuum, incapable of making any contribution to this debate that is anything other than to besmirch the names of the people who are associated with it. Where is their forensic examination of what occurred here? Where is their attempt to understand the complexity of this system? The idea that you could roll out a system like this that has 140,000 amendments every fortnight, that pays 76,000 people--the most complex payroll system that has ever been implemented by IBM. Where is their forensic assessment of that? There is none, because they are too lazy. It is far easier to sit here and say, ‘Let’s waste a bit more of taxpayers’ money for our own political gratification.’ That is all this is about. I say: let the Auditor-General go on with his work. Let us not nobble the independence of the Auditor-General. I support the amendment moved by the Deputy Premier.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (5.55 pm): I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition that condemns the government’s ongoing failure to properly pay Queensland Health workers their proper salary and entitlements and calls for the urgent creation of a commission of inquiry that will investigate and report on the failed payroll system. As the months pass since the ill-fated ‘go live’ of the IBM contracted SAP Workbrain computer system and the extent of the Health payroll fiasco unfolds, it is interesting to explore the history that led to this preventable cataclysm that is still wreaking havoc on so many workers’ lives.

While the Premier beats her chest and says that she will punish those who are to blame and while the Minister for Health cops most of the flak, another of the key culprits has managed to hide under the radar. The Minister for Public Works--or should that be the ‘Minister for Public Waste’--who usually puts on a brash vaudeville performance in the parliament as the head court jester, has been noticeably silent while his own Labor government has allowed health workers’ wages to be robbed from them for six pay cycles and still counting. Normally one to jump vigorously into the fray to defend workers’ rights, the minister has been as quiet as a mouse while health department staff desperately try to pay their bills. The minister has been too busy hosting rooftop parties for bureaucrats and going on jaunts to Germany to pay attention to what is happening in his own department.

In 2005, a 10-year contract for German software company SAP was renewed by Premier Beattie without going to tender, which outraged local IT vendors. As I was told during the estimates hearing last year, the target of whole-of-government consolidation has now changed to the retaining of multiple systems--four or five payroll systems and two or three finance systems. Changing the terms of the IBM contract would, one have thought, incurred more money. However, in September last year, when I asked the minister if these changes would cost more, he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We have a budget that we were given at the start and we will keep to it. We were given the project and we were given a budget and that budget will stand.
XML.Hansard-Body: I wonder if the minister still stands by that comment. In January 2008, a four-year contract for SAP, and awarded to IBM, was signed. In July 2008, Public Works took over CorpTech and the SAP, HR and finance program from Treasury, supposedly to consolidate whole-of-government systems. Of course the minister is no technical expert. No-one who has met him would question that. But if you are inheriting an entity, that being CorpTech, that had spent $400 million over four years between 2004 and 2008 with no result, would you not be asking questions? Was the minister not in the loop? Where was Minister Schwarten, the honourable member for Rockhampton? Was he aware of this breach of contract? These questions would be thoroughly dealt with in a commission of inquiry.

But what about the minister’s chief adviser, Chris Cummins? He was probably too busy changing factions so that he could run for the federal seat of Fisher. Why is this minister not paying attention? If the minister is not responsible then who is? He seemed to know the answers in estimates--or did he? The director-general ended up having to answer most of my questions.

Labor’s scheme for a whole-of-government payroll and human resource system was bungled from the start. The minister has claimed that no planning was ever completed for the rollout of the program to new agencies and that all the future planning had been deferred since the Queensland Health payroll fiasco. This Labor government has overpromised and underdelivered. How much more money has been wasted on this minister’s watch and how many more workers will be robbed of their hard-earned pay? Queenslanders deserve a commission of inquiry to get some truth on this inexcusable and terrible situation.

Bad administration by inexperienced employees was poorly overseen and allowed to continue under Minister Schwarten. He and the health minister are still in denial. Pretending to be clueless about workings in his department--a department he has headed for more than a decade--pretending to have no responsibility for projects he ultimately signs off on, will not wash this time. The Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology cannot avoid the truth for much longer, a truth that health workers who have been denied proper pay deserve.

Decent people who have worked on this project tell me that this payroll system will never--that is, n-e-v-e-r--work. Other departments are on hold, being propped up by ageing Legacy systems because of lack of leadership. One person said that the only thing the new Health payroll will do is make a lot of people rich. This person said that a year ago.

What is the real cost of this unforgivable bungling by two incompetent ministers and their deceitful Labor government--the personal cost and also the financial cost? We cannot begin to comprehend the stress, uncertainty, depression and anger felt by those caught up in this debacle. As a former nurse I wish to add my disgust at the way this government has handled this avoidable disaster. I support the motion of the LNP before the House and encourage others to do so.

Ms DARLING (Sandgate--ALP)
(6.00 pm): I am pleased to contribute to this debate on the issues surrounding the new Queensland Health payroll system. Quite frankly, the continued problems with the payroll system are unacceptable and should never have happened. We are not talking about pay slips and processes; we are talking about people being properly rewarded for their hard work and people being able to pay their bills and support themselves and their families.

This government is just as concerned as the members opposite about the distress that this has caused our many dedicated Health staff. That is why the Queensland government has a plan to get to the root of the problems and fix them as soon as possible. The government has commissioned KPMG to undertake an independent review of the implementation of the Workbrain and SAP 3 systems. The Queensland Auditor-General is currently preparing his report on the implementation of the new payroll system and he should be allowed to get on with his job. It is appropriate for the Auditor-General to investigate all those issues raised by members opposite.

Emergency assistance for staff in hardship was set up as soon as the payroll problems came to light. Specific staff in each facility or district can approve funds by cash, cheque or overnight payroll adjustments. When the system stabilises, Queensland Health will contact staff and negotiate a repayment schedule for these cash advances and other salary overpayments resulting from incorrect pays. If any member of staff feels that repayments are being suggested before their pays have been sorted, they should contact their line managers immediately.

In consultation with health unions, Queensland Health has committed to ensuring that no staff member is directly financially disadvantaged as a result of the current pay issues. In instances where staff have incurred late fees or other charges as a direct result of the introduction of the new payroll system, Queensland Health will reimburse the staff member for those costs. Queensland Health can also provide letters, if needed, to agencies such as Centrelink and the Department of Housing on behalf of individual staff members.

Advice is currently being sought from the Australian Taxation Office regarding any steps that may be put in place to assist staff who may be affected by under or overpayments. To date, additional payroll staff of approximately 200 have been employed, taking the total payroll staff to approximately 830. A dedicated payroll assistance website has been published to provide staff with access to the latest updates and information about the payroll situation.

I have been contacted by staff from Eventide Brighton, which is in my electorate, as well as staff who live in my electorate and work at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital about a range of inaccuracies in their pays. I want to reassure my constituents who have experienced problems with their pays that these mess-ups are not a reflection on their value to the health system, nor are they part of any strange new health policy. If they received an incorrect pay slip, it is a mistake and it will be fixed. The solution is taking longer than anyone would wish and I am concerned about the stress that this is causing staff. I want to make it clear to my constituents that the government has thrown all the resources it can into fixing this system and I will continue to fight for each and every big or little pay problem.

I would like to acknowledge the extraordinary work of the staff of all Queensland Health facilities. The director of Eventide, Mary Slattery, and her staff have worked brilliantly to provide a quick response to pay issues of Eventide staff. I urge any employee who continues to experience mistakes in their pay to talk to Mary who can arrange immediate cash payments until the issues are rectified. A lot of federal and state funding has gone into Eventide to help with its new focus on transitional care beds, which are helping people get out of hospital sooner and helping them with their rehabilitation before they return home. There is a plan to provide even more rehabilitation beds at Eventide, as flagged in the 2010-11 budget. It is part of the Bligh government’s future focused plans to reform health care in Queensland and meet the needs of our growing and ageing population.

The Bligh government’s record $9.99 billion Health budget for 2010-11 is delivering more front-line services sooner. The members opposite still have no plans for meeting the ongoing health needs of Queenslanders. They know how to harp and complain, and while I think these pay issues should never have occurred, I know that this government has the best plan to fix it. Government does not come without problems, but there needs to be a team with the intestinal fortitude to face the facts and get on with fixing things. The disjointed, disloyal, disharmonious mob opposite does not have the skills to see a problem and fix it. They are good at blaming each other and splitting into opposing groups, but as we have seen, this does not result in any decent plans for Queensland. Again, I thank the dedicated Queensland Health staff. I ask them to hang in there while we fix these problems. I support the amended motion.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP)
(6.05 pm): This motion by the Leader of the Opposition is firstly about getting this system technically right so that the human face of our health system can be paid and the unbelievable stress that they have been put under can be overcome; and, secondly, to get to the root cause of this situation. How did this happen? These contracts were let back in 2004-05. People made overseas visits, decisions were made and 10-year contracts were signed. I heard Minister Schwarten say that he did not have any advice as to how bad it was. I remind this House of when the Courier-Mail said that a simple Google search of Dr Patel would have shown a full history. A simple Google search of ‘SAP failures’ and ‘USA’ or ‘SAP failures’ in other parts of the world will show some of the problems that occurred in the pay systems, good points, bad points and the complexity of mixing the system with other overarching systems.

We have to get to the bottom of the pain and suffering caused unnecessarily to the good people of Queensland Health by incompetence, negligence, lack of experience, lack of knowledge and definitely a lack of interest. Surely the health minister would have sat with his director-general and said, ‘What can go wrong with this? Are we running a system in parallel with this or are we not?’ He knows that they have up to 70,000 employees on one of the most complex payrolls in this state. Surely they sat down and he asked again and again, ‘Is there a parallel system? We will not go live, will we, until everything has been done and everyone has their entitlements, their long service leave, and they have been paid for their shifts and their overtime?’ Surely any decent, reasonable, responsible health minister would have done that with the senior executives in the health department. Surely the same would have happened with the executives in the Department of Public Works who are also responsible.

This is an indictment on a government that is tired, that has had its day, lost interest, has no competence and no leadership. The ministers are just saying, ‘I’m advised.’ We have lost the technique of ministers who actually care and know a little bit about their department and ask the questions so that there are no surprises. There could not have been any issue bigger than this issue that would have required digging and investigation by the minister with his senior executives.

I want to talk about some of the cases of hardship that have occurred as a result of this situation, bearing in mind that we are in the 12th week of this debacle. Consider a nurse who has a husband with leukaemia and three grown-up kids to look after. She is doing night shift and trying to manage with the stress of having $600 not in her pay one week and every other pay wrong. She is trying to get off night shift and go and find out from the payroll staff what is wrong. Consider casual workers who have done 10 shifts and got $19 or $20; student nurses who have done 15 or 16 shifts and were underpaid by $1,600. It goes on and on. I know of a nurse who had a bank account closed because the money was not there to pay the house payments. Fortunately the bank was told about it and they reopened the account.

We had a case in Toowoomba of someone who went into the bank to check their account and became so frustrated that the money was not there that they kicked the door of the bank and ended up before the courts. Those are only some of the stories. People who do not have a loan with the health department and have given no authority for moneys to be taken out of their account have had moneys taken from their accounts. Staff are facing enormous stress about taxation, superannuation, long service leave, holiday pay and so on. All of those are good reasons to, firstly, fix the problem with pressure from us and, secondly, get to the cause of it so it never ever happens again--not for the railway workers, police, teachers or anybody else. There has been enough pain suffered.

Of course the government does not want to have a proper independent judicial inquiry that goes right back. Sure, let us have a look at all the technical issues to see why the technicalities have not worked and why the pay has not been correct, but we have to get back to how this started. That is what it is all about. The government should not be hiding behind it because the human faces of Queensland Health--the dedicated, hardworking and caring nurses, doctors, wards people, cooks and everybody else--are the ones who are suffering incredibly because of the incompetence, neglect and lack of responsibility of this government.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (6.09 pm): I also wish to speak in support of the Deputy Premier’s amendment to the motion. At the outset, I want to acknowledge that this is a very serious issue. The Premier and Deputy Premier have already apologised to Queensland Health staff affected by the failures of the new Queensland Health payroll system and I join with them in apologising to those staff. Those failures have affected a number of Queensland Health staff living in the Everton electorate and my office has assisted them in having incorrect payments rectified. I also want to thank Queensland Health staff for their patience during this difficult time. I think the clinical staff who treat Queenslanders every day and the administrative staff who have bent over backwards to pay those clinical staff deserve a medal.

The government has made no secret that there remains a lot to do to fix the problems, but we are making progress in the stabilisation of Queensland Health’s payroll system. Yesterday the Deputy Premier reported to parliament that the number of Queensland Health staff who were not automatically paid as of Friday, 4 June was 318 out of a payroll of 75,000. So we are making progress, but clearly we cannot stop until the payroll system is fixed. The payroll stabilisation team is aiming to reduce the backlog of adjustments to pays by 30 June 2010. To do this, Queensland Health has hired an additional 200 staff to assist with the processing, taking the total payroll staff to approximately 830.

Currently there are two independent reviews of the payroll system underway. The first, by international accountants and consultants KPMG, was commissioned by the government as soon as it was clear the problems were not going to be fixed overnight. The second is a review by the Auditor-General, something which, as the Deputy Premier has already said, the member for Clayfield sought and then complained about as soon as it happened. Now the opposition wants a third investigation, a royal commission headed by a retired judge. I have been trying to seek some explanation for why the opposition wants a third simultaneous investigation. Of course, it is seeking to exploit rank political opportunism by throwing rocks without offering one single solution for the problems that exist in the payroll system. However, maybe there is another reason.

We are all aware that the Leader of the Opposition’s days are numbered. I wonder if the shrill calls for a royal commission are connected to this. First, we had leadership aspirant No. 1, the member for Clayfield, calling for an investigation by the Auditor-General. Now we have the member for Caloundra calling for a royal commission headed by a retired judge. We have all heard the rumours this week that the member for Caloundra is the latest opposition frontbencher to be approached to challenge the opposition leader. Maybe this is his first salvo in jumping ahead of the member for Clayfield. He says to the member for Clayfield, ‘I’ll raise you; I’ll double your Auditor-General with my retired judge.’ Obviously to seek the leadership of the LNP you need to demand an investigation by higher and higher authorities. I can hardly wait to hear what the next speaker, the third leadership aspirant, the member for Southern Downs, has to offer. Maybe he will raise the member for Caloundra and demand an investigation by the FBI. Then we could have four investigations underway. We could have KPMG, the Auditor-General, the member for Caloundra’s retired judge and the member for Southern Downs’s FBI. Now we have the member for Noosa also expressing an interest in the leadership of the LNP, so it may be that he will have another plan for us as well.

Let us not forget that this is an opposition with a terrible track record when it comes to staffing of Queensland Health. This is the same opposition that went to the last election wanting to staff mental health wards with volunteer labour. This is the same opposition that went to the last election wanting to ‘front end’ 12,000 public service jobs to fund their promises. Who would have been in the firing line? We can bet that the first to be ‘front ended’ would have been the administrative staff who process the Queensland Health payroll. How do we know this? Because this is the same opposition that wanted to cut administrative positions to fund more doctors and nurses. While the government is acting by bringing on more staff to clear the backlog of incorrect payments, the opposition would have staged a massive pay day for lawyers and would have sacked the very people who are needed to pay Queensland Health employees. The opposition fails to understand that if you cut administrative staff who support doctors and nurses, you not only leave doctors and nurses doing more paperwork rather than treating patients but you also guarantee that their situation would be worse than it is now as there would never be anyone to pay them.

The Deputy Premier has repeatedly taken responsibility for the payroll problems and for fixing them. I believe he is doing a good job of rectifying the system, with the assistance of the two independent reviews already underway. I see no benefit in commissioning a third review, other than to put more money in the pockets of lawyers. I support the amendment to the motion.

Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (6.14 pm): I have never seen a greater display from a government in absolute denial. What we have out there in the community are families. We have loyal workers who have supported this government over a long period. They have supported our hospital systems and those in need. In Queensland the nurses, the doctors and the allied health professionals have been left high and dry by a government that is in denial. In the last few minutes from honourable members opposite we have seen supercilious, smarmy spin from people seeking to sheet away the problems and sheet away the blame to someone else. We have heard grossly insincere apologies, which is what we hear week after week after week from members of parliament who are virtually smiling when they deliver them, because they think that this is a big political gain. This is not a political gain, because there are people, families and lives greatly and grossly affected by this.

I bet few members opposite have actually stared in the face of somebody who was suffered and been affected, week after week, payroll after payroll, by this Labor government’s incompetence. Those people keep being promised that the problem will be fixed, but that fix never comes. They are told that things will be fixed by the next pay cycle, but that fix never comes. This is not only about people who have not been paid; it is also about people who have been overpaid; it is about people who have been underpaid; it is about thousands of people who are waiting for corrections to their entitlements and who are concerned that they are going to be penalised by the tax department. Those people are concerned that their superannuation entitlements are not being paid on time.

We have a government that sinks deeper and deeper into the mire of mismanagement that is its own creation. This Labor Party is an absolute master of mismanagement in this state. This government is in denial. The term ‘ministerial responsibility’ no longer passes the lips of government ministers. The term ‘ministerial responsibility’ is not even in their thoughts or psyche, because as long as they are paid and can sit back in their ministerial leather chairs, that is all that matters to them. They can mouth a few smarmy platitudes and apologies, and that will do. However, it will not fix the problem for those people who have been hurt and those families that are worried week after week after week.

What has been offered to health districts throughout Queensland? A risk assessment and a risk management matrix that allow them to deal with the problem. Look at that, honourable members. That is just page 1. If you are not a rocket scientist before you start, you certainly will be afterwards. At page 2 it gets even worse. There is more of the matrix of assessment as to the case of urgency that might be before you. If that has not got you completely and absolutely confused, you go to the next stage to try to work out this mess. Is it any wonder that we have experts in the field and employees within the department who say that the Workbrain system, the integration system, can never be fixed because it is so fundamentally flawed. This government knew about it. This minister knew about it 12 months ago. He had the briefing note sitting in his tray and he said that he would not even read it or he had not even read it. Is that any surprise for a minister who establishes a particular veil of believable deniability to put a level between himself and a briefing? He would not even sign his briefing notes, he would not even sign his letters, so he could pass responsibility off to someone. Who are the victims of this minister’s incompetence, denial, failure and lack of attention? They are the health workers who have been loyal to Queensland Health for so long!

What is the Minister for Industrial Relations doing about this? Absolutely nothing. Can honourable members imagine what would happen if a private enterprise went four, five, six, seven, eight or possibly even 10 or 20 payrolls, as we are being told, without paying their staff, with continuous problems with the payroll, without paying entitlements and without addressing superannuation? Would this minister’s department let them slip idly through the system and not prosecute them? No way. There is one rule for Labor and one rule for private enterprise.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (6.20 pm): Tonight’s motion is yet another example in a very long list of examples that demonstrate why the Liberal National Party are unfit to govern this state, why they have no understanding of public governance and why they have even less credibility to form an alternative government in this state. As Queensland’s first law officer and the minister responsible for the Commissions of Inquiry Act 1950, I feel compelled to correct the wild and unsubstantiated allegations and assertions that have been flung about by the LNP here tonight.

Commissions of inquiry have a very important role to play in ensuring that the public has confidence in the integrity of our governance and administrative systems and institutions. In Queensland, Labor governments view this role so importantly that for almost two decades we have established, sustained and supported a standing commission of inquiry--the Crime and Misconduct Commission--contrary to the position taken consistently in this parliament by members of the Liberal National Party. The CMC is ready and able to investigate any misconduct or failings in our governance systems in this state. It is not, however, a political football to be tossed about at any issue that the opposition seek to take political mileage from. And we know they have form when it comes to setting up commissions of inquiry for political purposes.

Royal commissions have served jurisdictions across Australia well, most notably in circumstances where an issue exists that warrants such special investigation where no existing authority has the authority to investigate and where no authority exists with the capacity to make rulings. But is this the case in Queensland? Quite simply the answer is no. The threshold tests--those issues that I have raised that would even warrant discussion of the creation of a commission of inquiry--have not even been touched upon by those members opposite. What is the most damning criticism of them is that the shadow Attorney-General--the man who purports to be responsible for the Commissions of Inquiry Act--did not mention the words ‘commission of inquiry’ once in his address to the parliament today. This is all lost on those members opposite. They are a lazy, policy-free zone who masquerade as an opposition and an alternative government in this state.

The payroll situation confronting health workers in Queensland is a very serious issue and one that the government has devoted very significant resources, dedication and commitment to resolving. As well as the immediate issues which the government is working hard to address, there are several other mechanisms in place to look at the systemic issues that may have contributed to this situation. What did we hear about the Auditor-General tonight? There was no support from members opposite. He is an officer of the parliament who reports to this body, this parliament, on issues that fall within his purview. But we heard no support for that process from those members opposite, as they do not support independent officers of this parliament, nor the CMC.

As I have said before, the CMC has the capacity to take action if there are any allegations of official misconduct or corruption. The opposition’s motion tonight is typical of the policy contradictions and confusion which reign supreme on the opposition benches particularly at budget time. What do we hear at every budget? What will we hear in the future? ‘Government funding must be cut.’ Yet what do we hear now? We hear a call for millions of dollars to be spent on an unnecessary inquiry which they seek to establish for partisan political purposes, and it would cost tens of millions of dollars.
What did the Australian Law Reform Commission say about royal commissions? They said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Royal Commissions usually prove to be very expensive. Precise figures are surprisingly difficult to pin down, but we estimate that, in today’s dollars, the Royal Commission into the Building and Construction Industry cost taxpayers over $70M, the one into the collapse of insurer HIH cost over $47M, and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody cost over $50M.
XML.Hansard-Body: We know what their Liberal National Party colleagues in Canberra did with the Cole royal commission into the building industry. They spent $70 million on a partisan political attack on the trade union movement. They will do nothing less if they set up a political inquiry here. We have seen form from them. What about their disgraceful bill last year--the disgracefully titled Commissions of Inquiry (Corruption, Cronyism and Unethical Behaviour) Amendment Bill--that they put before this parliament? It was a bill that sought to direct me to create a commission of inquiry and, if I did not, they would go to the Bar Association of Queensland to set up a commission of inquiry. The Bar Association would have to nominate someone. Did they ever put on the record how they consulted with the Bar Association? Never, not once. Those members opposite seek to use commissions of inquiry for partisan political purposes.

This is nothing more than a rank political attempt to promote themselves in the community. There is no substance to their argument. They are a policy-free zone. The motion should be voted down and the amendment should be supported by all honourable members.

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Workers’ Compensation & Rehabilitation & Or Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 1947, on motion of Mr Dick--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPRINGBORG (Southern Downs--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (7.30 pm), continuing: By way of reinforcement, these comments are based on this bill as presented by this government, on face value. Under the proposed common law amendments, caps on general damages and loss of income are also established at fair levels. In the case of general damages, these are $300,000 and loss of income three times average Queensland earnings. As I was indicating before the break, it is very difficult to try to understand and do a direct comparison about what may have happened if the government had directed an appropriate management of the runaway common law claims with regard to the WorkCover scheme in Queensland. If the government had directed proper competition to those particular claims to get towards the more meritorious claims and try to sort the wheat from the chaff, it may be that none of these amendments before the parliament would have been necessary.

It is very important to understand that I do not support a restriction in access to common law for workers in general. This bill does not seek to achieve that, nor does the philosophy which I bring into this place. What I do advocate is that there has to be a far more robust, interventionist and deliberate process in managing those common law claims to make sure that the solvency of the fund is properly protected and that it is the most meritorious cases which are being rewarded in the courts in Queensland. Certainly, there has been little evidence that that has been the case.

The Queensland workers compensation scheme allows certain large employers to self-insure. They provide an interesting contrast to those who rely on WorkCover for their protection. Evidence points to a far more active approach for the self-insured in establishing the merits of a common law claim, including through the courts. Effective practices of workplace injury rehabilitation and reintegration are essential. This is how workers are recovered and assisted back into the workplace.
