Experience suggests that large self-insured employers have better and more successful programs of rehabilitation and return to work. This is advanced by self-insured employers as one of the main, if not the main, advantage of the self-insured scheme. Enough anecdotal evidence exists at least to look more fulsomely at the success of their program vis-a-vis those that are directed under WorkCover. Social, economic and personal costs of poor workplace injury rehabilitation and return-to-work programs are significant. The pursuit of better outcomes must be our goal.

Ministerial responsibility is a principle missing from this government’s management of our compulsory WorkCover scheme. Selective choice of board members to manage the scheme associates with it full ministerial responsibility, a term absent from this government’s operating manual. In 1999 this government said in its review of WorkCover--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Queensland government is fully committed to job creation and recognises that any increased cost for employers can essentially lead to job losses.
XML.Hansard-Body: That statement was made in relation to potential premium increases for the Queensland WorkCover scheme. Has Labor repudiated this belief in the ensuing 11 years? If increased premiums cause job losses in 1999, increased premiums cause job losses in 2010. Average WorkCover premiums are to increase from $1.15 to $1.30. The minister must give an indication in his summing-up of whether he believes that job losses are still a significant and substantive threat that comes from the increase in WorkCover premiums, particularly as the Labor government of the day indicated in its report on WorkCover in 1999 that premium increases were likely to lead to job losses. This government must also have done some modelling and must have some advice which would indicate the impact that these premium increases may have on jobs and the viability of businesses in Queensland.

In 1999 this Labor government supported the reduction in solvency requirements from 30 to 20 per cent. Labor said at the time that such a reduction would be sufficient to meet catastrophes and other unpredictable events which may arise. Well, how wrong Labor was! And that is no surprise to anyone because this party consistently scores straight Es for economic management.

When parliament last passed substantive changes to WorkCover, the then minister refused to release his actuary’s advice. He told the House that a reduction in premiums was affordable. He assured us that the scheme’s underlying solvency would not be compromised. Clearly, that advice was wrong. Maybe its interpretation to the parliament was incorrect. Maybe the then minister misled the House. Maybe the advice did not exist at all. Today we are faced with a similar situation, slightly in reverse. We have a minister telling us that if we do not legislate his changes on spec the scheme will collapse. He says that if we do not put up premiums and if we do not restrict access to common law payouts we will be ruined, but he says that we cannot see the actuary’s advice to confirm his claims.
Mr Rickuss: ‘Trust me. I’m from the Labor Party.’

Mr SPRINGBORG: As the honourable member for Lockyer said, ‘Trust me. I’m from the Labor Party.’ A few years ago, the minister’s colleague told the House that we could afford to cut premiums. I repeat: his colleague told this House that we could afford to cut premiums. He said that the fund was overflowing with surplus but that we could not see the actuary’s advice to confirm his claims.

Those of us who sat in this House at that time, about three years ago--when the then minister was being pursued by the then shadow minister for industrial relations, the member for Clayfield--would remember that the member for Clayfield asked the honourable minister whether he could confirm the actuary’s advice that these reductions in premiums were sustainable, that they would not affect the solvency of the scheme and that they would not affect the underlying profit and balance sheet of the scheme? The minister said that it would not affect the underlying position of the scheme. He went on to reinforce that point over and over again and he confirmed in this place that the actuary’s advice was that it was quite appropriate and fiscally responsible to cut premiums, despite the protestations and the concerns being advanced by the opposition through the shadow minister at that time. Isn’t it interesting that some few years down the track we are here today with a government that now says that we have to increase premiums, we have to put restrictions on common law payouts and we have to make a range of other changes with regard to costs and contributory negligence because the scheme is in difficulty? ‘Trust me. I’m the minister. I have actuary’s advice.’

We are very concerned, based on what we were told a couple of years ago. The opposition approaches this debate with an abundance of suspicion--an abundance of suspicion born out of lessons learned the hard way; an abundance of suspicion knowing that we have previously been misled by this government. There will be no blank cheque from the LNP for these reforms. There will be no praise from the LNP for legislation that fails to address the giveaway culture within WorkCover Queensland in the common law division which could have been addressed, in our opinion, in isolation and may have fixed a lot of these issues.

The WorkCover shambles is of the Labor government’s own making. The fault lies with this government and its own dereliction of duty and oversight. There is no adulation from the LNP for legislation that cleans up the mess Labor made of its own affairs. There will be no blank cheque for legislation when the minister hides the supporting financial justification from not only the parliament but also those most affected by the laws--the employers and the workers of Queensland and their advocates.

Mr RICKUSS (Lockyer--LNP)
(7.40 pm): I rise to make a brief contribution to the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. As the member for Southern Downs has quite rightly indicated, in October 2007--only 2 years ago--this legislation was before the House. I will read a quote that follows on from what the member for Southern Downs said in his contribution to this debate. It reads--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The package of benefits for injured workers has been actuarially costed at $24.4 million and is a flow on from the decision to reduce the average premium rate to $1.15 per $100 of wages paid. That saves employers $34 million. So there is $34 million on the employers’ side ... Employers who have paid their premium in full by 16 September ...

WorkCover is a well managed scheme and its actuarial advice is that the benefit package is affordable within the current pricing structure of the scheme. A blow-out in common law payments was a significant factor in the deficit of the old Workers Compensation Board. In 1995 the Goss government introduced the irrevocable election to either proceed to common law or take a lump sum. It was this reform that reined in common law claims and payouts.
XML.Hansard-Body: Earlier in the day’s proceedings the member for Clayfield, Tim Nicholls, made a contribution to that debate. He stated that Jim Kennedy, who was pilloried in 1996 for his reforms which the Borbidge government brought in, was brought back to review the whole thing. He said that we had not seen the report by Kennedy to the minister. He asked whether the most recent Kennedy report to the minister actually took into account lower rates of return. The returns they were getting from the investment markets at that time were 14 per cent. That is why the fund was in credit in 2007.

We seem to be coming back every two years trying to clean up this mess. It is an ongoing mess. Surely the board appointments must be such that those people can manage this on a year-to-year basis. It is needs to be managed year to year. We do not have to change--
Mr Finn interjected.

Mr RICKUSS: It has not been; that is right. I take the interjection from the member for Yeerongpilly. That seems to be the problem. The management on a day-to-day basis seems to be lacking, because we are here propping it up again. This was done only 2 years ago.
Mr Springborg: It is 180 degrees in 2 years.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Member for Southern Downs, you have completed your speech.

Mr RICKUSS: I will take the interjection from the member for Southern Downs. Some 2 years ago we stood in the House having this same debate and said that we could afford to cut the premiums. We are in the House today saying that we have to put the premiums up.

Jim Kennedy wrote a report and it was not shown to us. His report was not shown to us. The Deloitte report has not been shown to us. Workers compensation legislation is presented to us carte blanche--accept it as it is, take it for what it is. How can we accept this?

I paid workers compensation premiums for 30 years. I felt like it was an impost but I knew I had to pay it. I wanted my workers to be covered. That is appropriate. No-one denies workers’ legitimate claims for work injuries. As has been highlighted by the shadow minister, what has actually happened is that claims that were not legitimate have been trumped up and paid. This really needs to be looked at.

What cost savings will WorkCover incur due to costs being awarded against the plaintiff? I notice in this legislation that costs can be awarded against plaintiffs. Has the minister got a costing for that? I call on the minister to give us an answer to that. What will actually be saved by that measure? This act was poorly drafted by Goss in 1995 and fixed up by us later on. It has been hashed about ever since. It goes on and on.

The excess for any claim is going to increase by more than $400. Will this legislation have to be revisited next year? Will it have to be tidied up next year? What is Deloitte’s advice on what is going to happen next year and the year after? That is what we really need to know. Where is it going year after year?

Mr JOHNSON (Gregory--LNP)
(7.46 pm): I wish to make a short contribution to the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill this evening. We witnessed today this government hiding when confronted with the critical issue of the nonpayment of employees and the disgraceful debacle that is raging out of control in Queensland Health. One can only imagine what the outcry would be if it were the conservatives who were sitting on the Treasury benches while this fiasco raged on.

Twice in less than two decades we have witnessed a workers compensation scheme with a question mark over it. I hope that the Attorney-General can verify whether there is a question mark over it. As a member of the Borbidge government in 1996 I saw firsthand the deceit about the management of strategies by the Goss government exposed. The then minister, Santo Santoro, had to find over $300 million to fill a black hole hidden by that government.

I ask: what is hidden here? We have to bear in mind that the truth always comes to the fore. This government preaches daily about its desire to increase job opportunities and to retain jobs but the real target should be employers. The government has to create an environment to encourage employers to employ, not discourage them from employing because of the moral policies of a government that has no conscience when it comes to telling the truth about what the real package is.

We certainly do not need a re-run of the Goss government days. When this government finally changes, the truth will be told. Again, this government is precious when it comes to the spotlight being shone in its eyes. It has to find someone to blame. Yes, it is the global financial crisis, as the shadow Attorney-General alluded to this evening. We had a crisis in Queensland long before the global financial crisis. It was poor financial management.

The platform of workplace practice is sacred to the Queensland economy and it is absolutely paramount that it is protected by an affordable, responsible and workable workers compensation scheme. Premiums can be, in most cases, increased but the fallout will be a further impost on employers. Whilst something has to give, it could be jobs. This vicious circle is a form of mismanagement and the fallout becomes that of the employees. Ambitious claims through fraudulent claims of corruption and dishonesty have not helped this very sacred right of the Queensland worker, but dishonesty can cause hurt to the decent and proper applicant and employer ultimately.

Workplace safety measures are something that need a refocus, and I urge the Attorney to put into policy reward for good workplace practices because that will save many people a lot of money over a long period of time. The mining industry must be congratulated for its commitment to safe workplace environments. In an industry that is dangerous if not managed properly, unions, management and allied support have certainly demonstrated their quality management in the mining industry in this great state and have demonstrated that it is one of the safest work environments in a highly technical area where heavy machinery is used on a regular basis in terms of underground mining and above-ground mining. I have to congratulate the mining industry in Queensland for an environment that is comparable to nowhere else in the world in terms of safety. Other workplaces in Queensland should adopt this example that is overseen by responsible management of industrial relations with a parallel for employers and employees.

One must question the scrutiny by Commerce Queensland and the Queensland Law Society when they did not get the answers they wanted and became suspicious. If full and proper consultation is done at the time of compiling legislation, these responsible bodies would give their blessing. The claims mounted by some claimants is criminal, as alluded to by the shadow Attorney this evening, and the protection of employers in these cases is void if they cannot defend their position. As the shadow Attorney stated, speculative claims serve no purpose. Again, the bill contains amendments that allow provision to award costs against a person whose common law claim is thrown out. These speculative claims with a nature of wrong intent do push up premiums and unfairly punish the legitimate claimant and the honest and decent employers. This is something that must be further canvassed in getting justice for the legitimate claims. We want our workers to be in the workplace because it is a productive cause for Queensland. We need to make sure that a proper rehabilitation program is afforded to genuine injured workers. The non-genuine will identify themselves in time, as always happens. They skite about it and always get caught out.

A premium increase from $1.15 to $1.30 is a significant increase in these difficult times of job security. There are many people out there at this very moment looking at their bottom line and how they can trim some fat to ensure that their business operations are viable. I would have thought that if this process was managed as well as the government says it is there would be no need to increase premiums in these fragile economic times where many employers are at the very moment still coming to terms with the hidden government policies that have caused their businesses extra burden through, for example, higher fuel prices that they did not budget for and which in many cases pushed them over the edge. Those policies of deceit are certainly not advantageous to the ongoing productivity and viability of Queensland employers and ultimately, more importantly, Queensland employees.

This legislation should be treated with the same contempt that this government has treated the people of Queensland in recent times if the Attorney cannot clarify some of the real facts that may be hidden in this agenda. I will be waiting to hear the Attorney’s response to some of these issues before I set my mind free in relation to this legislation.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (7.53 pm): Before I turn to the speech I have prepared I want to make a few comments about some of the information that has been related to the House so far. Firstly, let us be quite clear: the WorkCover scheme in Queensland is well managed. It is a well-managed scheme. It is the only scheme of any state in the country that operates at over 100 per cent solvency--the only of any state. It has the lowest employer premiums of any state in the country and it manages some 96,000 claims every year. What we hear from the opposition is that this is not management. How has it managed to maintain 100 per cent plus solvency? How has it managed to do that? It has done that through good management. The problem we have with members of the opposition is that they come in here over one year after the last election when they should have learned their lesson and still deny that the global financial crisis exists. That is what they said before the last election and they still come in here and deny that that occurred. It is a fairly weak argument to say that a scheme is poorly managed. They do not have the facts on that and their argument is completely wrong on that.

What we see is a board that manages an insurance scheme for injured workers in this state--a board that sets premiums for an insurance scheme and a board that manages a volatile mix of risk which means it has to be flexible, which means it has to evolve, which means it has to model its operations on the workforce of today and not deny global financial crises and not set a scheme that just goes on and on with no change. It has to be nimble at times and it has to reflect the needs of the workforce. It sets a premium. It works out what an appropriate premium is in the workplace but it also reports annually to government. In its annual report it reports on what amendments need to be made to address the needs of injured workers and the compensation scheme and insurance scheme that covers them while they are at work to suit today’s workforce. It is quite a normal and a good practice of management to annually review a scheme through the annual reporting process.

In the amendments before us today we see three clear sets of decisions have been made as part of this review, and I will address them as I go on. The health and safety of workers is a priority of the Bligh Labor government. Ensuring that workers receive a fair and reasonable level of protection under Queensland’s workers compensation scheme is part of that priority, as is ensuring business has a competitive base in comparison with interstate rivals. That is why when the government moved to make changes to the country’s fairest and least expensive workers compensation scheme to ensure its continued viability in the face of world economic recession it consulted widely, and it consulted widely with key stakeholders including employers, workers, workers’ representatives, unions and the legal profession. I thank those people who were involved in that stakeholder process.

It is fair to say that there was feedback across the spectrum about how government should resolve this issue and that direct stakeholder involvement meant that we came up with a proposed set of outcomes that have been very well road tested with the stakeholders and have reached an agreement in what can be a fairly volatile set of circumstances. There can be very strong views from all sides of stakeholder groups in the industrial relations arena. There can be a fairly broad scope in terms of what people’s views are, and there were people who said that we should have addressed the issues brought about by the global financial crisis solely through premiums. There were people who had that view, and that would have seen massive premiums over the $2 mark. We had people who said we should stop injured workers from having access to common law if they have an injury that is under 15 per cent of a whole person injury. That would have virtually knocked out just about every common law claim or the vast majority of common law claims.

What I was very pleased about in the consultation process was that those extremes were not very common and that people worked in a very proactive and consultative way to come up with an outcome which works out as a set of amendments that address the needs that face the workforce while also addressing the needs of spiralling common law claims and addressing the financial viability of the scheme into the future, with all parties realising that something had to be done if Queensland employers and workers were to continue to enjoy the best and fairest workers compensation scheme. For employers the WorkCover Queensland board has advised that with these changes the average premium rate will increase to $1.30 per $100 of wages paid, up from $1.15. Whilst this is a 13 per cent increase in the average premium rate, Queensland employers will still have the lowest average premium rate of any state in the country.

For example, Victoria and Western Australia have announced their average premium rates for the same period--2010-11. Victoria, the state with the second lowest average premium rate, has announced an average rate of $1.34 per $100 of wages, which is just over three per cent more than the Queensland rate. Western Australia has announced an average premium rate of $1.49--almost $1.50; it is actually $1.497--which is 15.2 per cent higher than the Queensland rate. If the members of the opposition want to talk about the management of the scheme, perhaps they could talk to their mates in Western Australia.

For workers, the bill harmonises the workers compensation common law arrangements with the Civil Liability Act 2003, which will see general damages assessed in accordance with a set scale. To determine general damages, an injury scale value will be used to assess a worker’s dominant injury, having regard to the scale set up in the CLA. The effect of the injury scale value is that it compresses claims at the lower end of the scale and benefits the more seriously injured. WorkCover’s actuary, PricewaterhouseCoopers, has projected that the harmonising with the CLA should result in common law claim frequency reducing by nine per cent.

As was mentioned previously, although it was clear that action needed to be taken to ensure the solvency of the scheme, the government was not prepared to consider significant changes without careful consultation with scheme stakeholders. A discussion paper was released on 23 February 2010, with public comment invited by 24 March 2010. The discussion paper outlined a number of proposals to ensure the continued future strong financial health of the scheme. A stakeholder reference group of employers, unions and the legal profession was established to consider the submissions and provide advice to the minister.

I should say that the member for Lockyer incorrectly claimed that there was no access to the Deloitte report. The Deloitte report was released publicly and given to all stakeholders in that stakeholder reference group. It was the basis of a number of submissions that were prepared by stakeholders. It was a readily available, publicly released--
Mr Springborg interjected.

Mr FINN: A report from Deloitte was available to everybody who sought it. The reference group, which was chaired by the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations, met on four occasions. Sixty written submissions were received in response to the discussion paper. They were received from employers, self-insurers, unions, workers, lawyers and health professionals. None of the submissions that were received suggested a change to the fundamental nature of the Queensland scheme, that is, a short-tail scheme with access to common law. Today we introduce amendments that maintain a short-tail scheme, maintain access to common law and continue the lowest premiums of any state in Australia.

Three concerns were consistently raised by stakeholders, and the minister outlined those in his second reading speech. These were concern about the need for a much stronger focus on rehabilitation and return-to-work outcomes, concern that WorkCover accepts claims too easily and settles common law claims for sums that are too high, and concern regarding the transparency of the scheme.

Earlier in my comments I said that there were three sets of decisions. The first set of decisions was those that we are introducing in this amending legislation that go to the immediate solvency and financial viability of the scheme and the way in which the scheme operates. The second set of decisions will be made towards the end of this year. That will come about after a review is conducted by Robin Stewart-Crompton, who is the former chief executive of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and most recently the chair of the national review into model occupational health and safety laws. He has been appointed to conduct the structural review of institutional and working arrangements in Queensland’s workers compensation scheme. Mr Stewart-Crompton commenced scoping the review on 1 June and, as part of this exercise, he is meeting with key stakeholders in the compensation scheme. So this second set of decisions, if you like, will be based on the structural operations of the scheme and how they best need to be addressed.

The review that Mr Stewart-Crompton will undertake will advise the minister on, firstly, appropriate strategies and institutional arrangements to ensure the roles and the functions of Q-Comp, WorkCover and the Department of Justice and Attorney-General in Queensland workers compensation are clear and well understood by stakeholders and the broad community; secondly, arrangements that can be put into place to enhance transparency and ensure that information is readily available to stakeholders and the broader community on the workers compensation scheme performance; thirdly, strategies to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the workers compensation claims management and common law settlement process; fourthly, the appropriateness of the current level of legal costs and management of the legal profession in workers compensation matters; and, fifthly, what actions can be taken by scheme stakeholders to improve rehabilitation and return to work. This is the structural review that will pick up on the matters raised by stakeholders in their written submissions and will lead to the government addressing the structural needs of the scheme in the short term.

As I said earlier, any scheme, no matter how successful, needs monitoring and finetuning from time to time. I am pleased that the minister is assessing whether the amendments that are passed tonight or any of these concerns that were raised in the stakeholders group have any basis by ordering the structural review of the working arrangements.

Also, as the minister addressed in his second reading speech, an overall effectiveness review of WorkCover’s current and future financial position will be undertaken into two years time and completed by 31 December 2012. That review will assess the success of the amendments that we make to the scheme tonight to ensure the financial viability of the scheme into the future. By 2012 we will know the full impacts of the amendments that have been outlined. That will give some comfort to representatives of employers and unions, as the full impact of the amendments that are being debated today will be known then. I say to the opposition members that I completely reject any suggestion that the scheme should not be regularly reviewed and changed as needed.

The short story of this bill is that a scheme that operates successfully in Queensland compensating injured workers comes to the government with an annual report that says that it has taken a hit from the global financial crisis and that it needs to have some amendment. An extensive consultation process, which gathers all of the feedback that we can get from stakeholders, comes up with some recommendations that are about ensuring the financial viability of the scheme into the future. We come up with a set of amendments that maintains the lowest premiums in the country and ensures that there is no restriction on common law access for injured workers. This is good Labor Party amending legislation. It is good economic management legislation. It is legislation that builds on a well-managed insurance scheme and ensures its viability into the future. I commend the bill.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (8.06 pm): I rise to speak in support of the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. Throughout my career of 27 years in the union movement, workers compensation was something that I had been involved in and I never considered for one minute giving up my role in policy formation and implementation. When it comes to providing benefits for workers injured in the workplace and providing entitlements to affected families, the union movement and Labor governments in Queensland have a proud history. In 1916, it was a TJ Ryan led Labor government that introduced Queensland’s first compulsory workers compensation scheme, which was based on no fault and access to common law rights and entitlements. It is interesting to note that, at the time, my understanding is that the opposition voted against such a bill being introduced into this House. Yet if you listened to the member for Southern Downs you would think that they had been for this legislation since 1916.

But the members opposite have a legacy in workers compensation. We do not have to go back too far to know exactly what they intended to do with workers compensation entitlements. I remember being elected assistant general secretary of the QCU in 1995. One of the first things that hit my desk was the then Borbidge government’s draft changes to the workers compensation act. They were not about mucking around with common law; they were about knocking it out completely. At that time they went to an election promising to maintain common law. However, when they got into power, I give credit to the member for Gladstone because she held them to that promise they made during the election campaign and stopped them knocking out common law. I am sure she will remember that, because the then government had negotiations with the member for Gladstone. That is their legacy--not about trying to fix it up but about knocking common law out completely--and they were only stopped at that time because they did not have the majority. Yet they come in here crying about what we are doing here based upon their legacy.

But that was not the only thing they tried to do. They changed the definition of worker, restricting the number of workers who had access to common law. They restricted the definition of injury where employment had to be the major significant factor. That absolutely smashed the number of workers who had entitlements to workers compensation. Unless a person was able to prove that work was the major contributing factor, it was such a hard test that not many workers went through. I see the member for Kawana smiling over there.
Mr Bleijie: I was just thinking go to the future. Let’s talk about the future.

Ms GRACE: He is a legal person and maybe he understands exactly what it means. I take the interjection from the member for Kawana about looking to the future. We were given a history lesson by the member for Southern Downs, and I think it is about time that we gave a history lesson and gave the facts when it comes to the opposition’s intentions in relation to workers compensation. Not only did it change the definition of injury, it then reduced the income that workers get from 39 to 26 weeks. It introduced self-insurance to employers of 500 or more employees but without any sort of occupational health and safety management system whatsoever. The member for Southern Downs comes into this House and goes on about occupational health and safety. Those opposite allowed employers to self-insure without any record of their occupational health and safety systems. That is what those opposite introduced in 1996. It was a disgrace. We changed it.

What the opposition then did was insidious. It tried to knock out journey claims altogether. Once again, because it did not have the majority, that was knocked out as well. What was put in was that they had to access journey claims from the most convenient, direct and shortest route. Its intention was to do two of the most hideous things to workers under workers compensation: knock out journey claims and knock out common law. That is the history lesson that we have in this House. That is what those opposite should be talking about, not giving us a history lesson on TJ Ryan.

Let us talk about the future. I am pleased that this bill continues these principles of a no-fault statutory scheme together with maintaining the rights of injured workers to pursue common law claims and entitlements. We are the only state in Australia that still maintains common law rights. I am proud to have been part of ensuring that this has been maintained over the many years that changes have been made to the WorkCover legislation. If one looks at the history there have been many changes. I see some of the staff from the department on the fringes of the House. We have had many meetings in the past years over changes to workers compensation. However, I want to focus on the future of the Queensland workers compensation scheme and its sustainability in good times and, of course, in bad. When I say that, I acknowledge that the global financial crisis represents the very worst of times and hopefully we are putting that behind us at last. But the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 sets up the Queensland scheme for a strong future because it addresses issues associated not only with the economic woes of Wall Street and beyond but also increases in common law claims and the cost of those claims that require laws to be updated and improved from time to time. We know that we have had many instances where we have been in this House because of this situation occurring from time to time. The bill before us does just that and ensures the scheme remains sustainable well into the future. It offers protection for workers and their families, but it also offers a fair and balanced approach to compensation issues that, along with the global financial crisis, could threaten WorkCover Queensland’s bottom line to some extent if action had not been taken. It was not in the exaggerated dire strait as the member for Southern Downs pointed out. The Deloitte review found WorkCover was experiencing a rise in common law claims and payouts and that premiums were not keeping pace with this growth. These factors resulted in a loss of $381 million before tax in 2007-08, followed by a loss of $894 million in 2008-09. These are not small figures. However, sound board management over the last decade had built up a healthy reserve and that was used to absorb these losses. Obviously the situation could not be allowed to continue. I must stress that the scheme remained fully funded as at 30 June 2009 with a positive funding ratio of 127 per cent, the highest in the country; not the exaggerated position as outlined by the member for Southern Downs.

The Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill harmonises damages arrangements with the Civil Liability Act 2003. This will see a capping of payout amounts and changes to common law damages, particularly liability and contributory negligence. General damages, pain and suffering will be capped at approximately $300,000 and damages for economic loss will be capped at three times Queensland ordinary time earnings or, currently, $176,607. This will be the maximum annual earnings a court will be able to take into account when calculating loss of future earnings.

Although I accept that this is not the ideal situation, and I accept that no-one really likes caps, I believe that, in view of the need to improve the workers compensation WorkCover fund, these amendments present a fair and reasonable outcome. WorkCover’s actuary, PricewaterhouseCoopers, says that these measures should reduce the frequency of common law claims and reduce the size of settlements paid, particularly for minor or less severe injuries or lower end of the scale injuries, and benefit more seriously injured workers, which is really what we are all about. Injured workers continue to receive fair benefits through the unchanged statutory scheme. I also note quantum and liability restrictions will apply if a worker pursues a common law claim, with a court able to award costs against a worker where a claim is dismissed. My understanding is that this is actually correcting an anomaly which exists under the current bill.

Importantly, the bill before us addresses the issue which has arisen since the decision in the Queensland Court of Appeal in Bourk v Power Serve Pty Ltd & Anor. This decision effectively meant that if a worker is injured at work and there is a casual connection between the injury and work the employer has breached its duty under the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1995. Common law claims increased after this decision based on the perception that strict liability attaches to an employer if a work injury has occurred regardless of fault, which was not the government’s policy intent. The amendments address this. Workers need to show that an employer breached a duty to take precautions against a risk of harm that was foreseeable, not insignificant, and in circumstances in which a reasonable person would have taken the precautions.

Another sustainable change that should ensure the future financial strength of the fund is the fact that the bill also increases employer excesses from 65 per cent of Queensland ordinary time earnings to 100 per cent or one week of compensation. I believe that this is a win-win situation. I think that employers will take notice when they actually have to put their hand in their pocket for the first week of workers compensation, thus hopefully changing the culture to improve worker health outcomes because it is an incentive to employers to improve injury rates and cut their costs.

A financially sound WorkCover Queensland is vital for all Queenslanders and our economy. Therefore, in conclusion, I wish to make three important points regarding this bill. Firstly, the bill maintains access to common law damages for all injured workers, a uniquely Queensland entitlement, whilst maintaining a no-fault, generous statutory scheme. Secondly, the bill balances good benefits for injured workers with affordable premiums for employers, which are currently the lowest premiums in Australia and which could not be sustained for the viability of the fund. We had to increase the premiums. Everyone was saying they were far too low. I must confess that when we brought them down to that level when I was QCU general secretary I said we had gone too far. I said that we would be here trying to amend it. It saddens me that my words actually came true.
Mr Springborg: Who said that? You?

Ms GRACE: I said that and I think the member for Southern Downs may have said the same. Thirdly, I welcome the proposal to further review the scheme in two years time to be completed by 31 December 2012 by which time the effects of the GFC should have diminished significantly and the impacts of implementation of amendments in line with the Civil Liability Act will be known. I really do welcome a review in two years time.

I commend the minister and staff, together with all members of the stakeholder reference group, particularly union and employer organisations, who gave so generously of their time and commitment to find a solution and for participating in an open and cooperative approach to ensuring that this state maintains a strong, viable and fair workers compensation scheme, a WorkCover scheme in Queensland that leads Australia. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (8.18 pm): I too rise to support the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. This legislation protects our strong and generous workplace compensation schemes from the effects of the global financial crisis. Last decade saw some very generous reductions in WorkCover premiums for employers, based on strong returns on WorkCover asset investments. The global financial crisis saw income from investments reduce while claims from workers increased. This is the time when employees are less able to find suitable alternative employment after injury and the likelihood of mitigating their loss is minimised, but Queensland is not alone. Significant losses of more than $1 billion were felt in the states of Victoria and South Australia. In Queensland, we are fortunate that we have had a very strong policy of fully funding liabilities. As at 30 June 2009 we fully funded this to the extent of 127 per cent of liabilities going forward. Compare that to South Australia with 56.7 per cent of funding, New South Wales with 89 per cent of funding and Victoria with 97 per cent of funding.

In 2009 the WorkCover board responsibly sought independent advice on the effects of the global financial crisis on the scheme. With the handing over of that report to the Attorney-General, the Attorney-General released a discussion paper and established a stakeholder reference group to consult with the stakeholders on this issue. There was never going to be an outcome on the issue where everybody was happy, but what was needed was an outcome that stakeholders could live with going forward, and this bill delivers that.

This bill protects the fundamental principle of our WorkCover scheme, a system that protects workers’ common law rights to seek compensation and to have finality of their claims. The best interests of employers and employees is to finalise claims quickly and let both parties move on with their lives. Long-tail schemes such as those in operation in other states might appear more attractive to some employers but end up being more costly and more cumbersome for employees.

There are a number of aspects to the reform contained in this bill. The first is an increase in premiums for employers. When we discuss insurance premiums, we must remember that this is an insurance scheme. This is not a government tax or a government charge. This is insurance for liabilities that employers have incurred due to workers being injured at work. This meets the employers’ costs. Taxpayers and workers should not be subsidising the compensation that workers are entitled to from employers through the WorkCover scheme. Queensland still has the lowest premiums in the country, which are three per cent below our nearest competitor state of Victoria. This maintains a competitive business environment for Queensland. This $1.30 rate is still lower than the rate that existed in Queensland in 2006 and is significantly lower than the $1.85 rate that stood when Santo Santoro took an axe to workers compensation in 1997.

The bill also introduces a cap on economic loss, but this cap applies to people earning more than $176,000 per annum. This will affect a small number of people. Those who need the compensation most will still receive it. The bill provides for a cap on general damages. That cap provides a clear statutory table for general damages, providing guidance and certainty, and a clear way to resolve claims without the need for expensive legal advice and litigation. This encourages claims to be settled early, meaning that money can be spent on paying workers’ claims rather than paying lawyers to fight them. The cap on general damages means that small claims that often have legal fees making up a higher percentage of that claim are discouraged and may be negatively affected, but large claims for general damages are often better off under a scheme of this nature.

Importantly, this reform process includes a review in two years time of the strength of the reforms. There are some items that I think really need to be given great consideration--issues like voluntary services and their compensation in this scheme--but if the scheme has the ability to return benefits to workers, we should do that. If this bill delivers the strength that it plans to, there should be a position where the common law scheme is fully funded and workers can return to the benefits they get at the moment. Workers should not be forgoing their entitlements to subsidise employer premiums.

I finish by reiterating the point that this is an insurance scheme to meet the costs that should be borne by employers; this is not a taxpayer funded program to fund compensation entitlements. This is an insurance scheme and workers, through either taxes or loss of rights, should not be subsidising those claims. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (8.23 pm): Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset may I congratulate you on your elevation to the panel of temporary speakers. This evening I rise to draw the attention of the House to a perfect example of how the Labor government has mismanaged the state’s finances. What better way to celebrate that than by debating this bill in budget week? In fact, in the first paragraph of his second reading speech, the honourable Attorney-General said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill before the House implements important reforms to further strengthen the performance of the Queensland government’s workers compensation scheme.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It is not a matter of reforming the government’s workers compensation scheme. It is another example of whatever this government touches it cannot get it right. Further, in his second reading speech the Attorney-General stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: While WorkCover did not escape this crisis, its continued stable performance contrasted with that of other Australian workers compensation schemes that did not fare as well through the global financial crisis.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The Attorney-General then went on to compare Queensland with other states. The only comparison that should take place is between Queensland which lost its AAA credit rating in the GFC and all the other states which did not lose theirs. That is the comparison that the Attorney-General needs to make. This government never accepts responsibility for anything it does. No doubt the global financial crisis is behind the Premier’s worst approval ratings in Queensland history of 69 per cent.
XML.Hansard-Body: My contribution to the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 follows on from that of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Attorney-General. The course before the House is set to amend the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 2003, the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1995 and other relevant subordinate legislation to ensure a viable WorkCover scheme is in place for Queensland workers. The near collapse of the WorkCover scheme in Queensland is as a direct result of the changes implemented by Labor governments in this state.

In 1996 the Borbidge coalition government introduced the test to tighten injury claim provisions under the WorkCover legislation. Those provisions ensured that a rigid framework was applied to all WorkCover claims and that the scheme was a viable one to protect Queensland workers in the event that a workplace injury was sustained. Since the election of the Beattie government in 1998, the WorkCover scheme in Queensland has been weakened to a point where it has now run at a deficit of $1.3 billion over the past two years.

The viability of WorkCover Queensland and its demise over the past two years is intrinsically linked with mismanagement by successive Labor governments in this state. I refer to an article titled ‘Businesses call for WorkCover scrutiny’, which was published in the Courier-Mail on 4 April and is available on the Courier-Mail website. I table a copy for those opposite.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Copy of a Courier-Mail article, dated 4 April 2010, titled ‘Businesses call for WorkCover scrutiny’ [ 2394 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: In relation to the WorkCover board, the article quotes the President of the Queensland Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr David Goodwin, as stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think management needs to be investigated and they need to have a look at its internal protocols.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The article also states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Mr Goodwin said the WorkCover board, along with union bosses Bill Ludwig and Ron Monaghan and Labor Holdings’ Ian Brusasco, had to be held accountable.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The same article states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Trilby Misso chief executive Graeme McFadyen said the public had been ‘hoodwinked’ and the picture being painted by the Government was a facade. He said sharemarket losses claimed by WorkCover of about $800 million last financial year would have recovered since the economy turned around and would be nowhere near that level now.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The article quotes Mr McFadyen as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think the background of the economic crisis is very convenient for them to introduce changes.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a scathing indictment of the WorkCover board and this government’s management of the scheme that is meant to protect Queensland workers.
XML.Hansard-Body: One can understand why business in general is by no means a friend of this government. Since 1998 consecutive Labor governments have mismanaged WorkCover almost into insolvency. Now, to recover from the mess it has created, the Attorney-General introduces this legislation in an attempt to regenerate the scheme and increase the premiums. Who will pay for this? Businesses that employ working Queenslanders.

I have a great deal of empathy for Mr Terry White, deputy chairman of the WorkCover board. He serves on the board with the six Labor appointees and under the chairmanship of Mr Ian Brusasco, who, as I said, is also on the board of Labor Holdings. I am baffled that the Attorney-General maintains that WorkCover’s dire financial position is as a result of the GFC. In his second reading speech, the honourable the Attorney-General championed Labor’s record of ‘protecting workers from injury in the workplace and for providing compensation for those who find themselves in an unfortunate situation’.
Mr Ryan: That’s right.

Mr BLEIJIE: They are the words of the Attorney--and I note the honourable member for Morayfield is in agreement. Well, of course he is because it is his Attorney-General. But I point out to the honourable gentleman that the Attorney-General failed to mention the fact that policy implemented by Labor governments since 1998 has failed to maintain a viable WorkCover scheme. This legislation is required to rescue the current WorkCover scheme. Two million Queensland workers rely on the WorkCover scheme for injury compensation cover, and these workers deserve a scheme that is viable and well managed. Clearly this government has demonstrated its inability to do so, and this legislative rescue package is a last-ditch effort to save face before the workers of this state are again let down by this government.

We need a WorkCover scheme in this state that balances the protection of Queensland workers should a workplace injury occur with the premium costs associated and paid for by business. The cap that this bill includes is finally a protective measure that will ensure the viability of the WorkCover scheme is maintained into the future. The $300,000 cap on claims ensures that the scheme is viable and that claims are at an appropriate level that recompenses workers if they are unable to work as a result of a workplace injury.

I note that the bill also introduces contributory negligence factors. That of course should be supported because, as the honourable shadow Attorney-General highlighted in his representations to the parliament, it is necessary in that if someone is continually advised of safe practices and they neglect to follow those safe practices then they are indeed contributors to negligence.
I say to the member for Yeerongpilly that we do not deny that the global financial crisis existed. He said that the LNP continually denies that the GFC existed. But what we do say--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! The House will come to order. The member for Kawana has the call.

Mr BLEIJIE: I note the objections raised. I remember at the time the comments made by the shadow Attorney-General in relation to a recession. His statement at the time was proved to be quite right. So statements made by us on this side of the House at that time in relation to the recession were in fact correct.

We do not deny that the GFC existed, but we do say that had the LNP been in power we would have retained our AAA credit rating. I yearn for the day of an LNP state government so that we are not continually dragged into this place to legislate against Labor Party stuff-ups--continual stuff-ups by the Labor Party. I yearn for the day that the LNP is in government, when we can come into this chamber looking to the future and not hear about review after review after review and continually review legislation because the Labor Party--it is a fact--cannot get it right the first time around. In summary, I wish to reiterate the points and support the statements made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Attorney-General in relation to this bill before the House.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (8.34 pm): I rise to speak to the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and place on the record my continuing concern and support for injured workers. We need to understand--and I am sure that we all do--that when men and women are injured at work, and their families are affected thereafter, they are in their greatest need of support at a time when they are least able to defend themselves.

There have been a number of comments about the history of workers compensation and a number of interjections by people who were not here at the time. From my perspective, some of the comments that have been made do not reflect the reality. We had a minister hell-bent on making quite significant changes to workers compensation. We also had a shadow minister who was either unwilling or unable to provide amendments in a timely fashion and to defend those amendments so that those of us in the chamber could properly understand the position that the Labor opposition felt it was in at the time.
I thank the member for Brisbane Central for her comments on the retention of common law. I remain of the view that if you make a promise at an election you keep that promise.
Ms Grace: And you hold them to it.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: Yes, thank you. In relation to travel claims, a lot of comment was made in relation to football or other sports injuries which occurred on the weekend but were claimed on the Monday as a work injury. That was a background to the claims being from the person’s fence--the beginning of public property. I felt that at least there was some opportunity to be able to prove or disprove the reliability of that claim. It was the same with the definition of a worker. There have been people who thought they were workers under the workers compensation schedule but when they were injured found out that they were not included. That was people like young deckies who got paid a percentage of the catch and when they were injured on the boat, sometimes quite seriously, they found out after the fact that they were not actually workers under the workers compensation scheme.
Ms Grace: Seventeen-year-olds who were independent contractors.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: That is right. So it was important to get some clarity. Was it all right? Not at all. Is this all right? I do not believe so either, because it will have an impact on workers at a time when they are at their most vulnerable.

I will be interested in the Attorney-General’s clarification of a number of issues. One aspect that is being blamed for this financial shortfall is the global financial crisis. I have heard both sides of the chamber debating this. I wonder about the investments, particularly those in sensitive portfolios, if those investments are of a speculative nature. I wonder whether people in this state expect our governments to be speculative or to leave those investments in vulnerable areas. That is perhaps a moot point.

I am concerned about the capping of common law claims. I will be interested in the minister’s comments in relation to this matter. I am particularly concerned about two aspects. One is with regard to people who are significantly injured--people who were providers for their families who are seriously injured in a workplace. How significant will be the capping on their ability to provide not only for their family but also for themselves if they become high-care people, if they become paraplegics or quadriplegics? It is easy to dismiss that comment or question by saying that it does not happen very often, but when it does happen it is a cataclysmic event and one that has to be addressed.

I would be interested in the minister’s comments in relation to the application of costs. I am very concerned as to whether this will be a significant disincentive for injured workers to rightly pursue a claim. So often we have people in our offices who have been injured--sometimes visibly, sometimes less visibly--and they are in a vulnerable position physically, emotionally and financially. If they are put in a position where to pursue claims they are at risk of having damages awarded against them, how big of a disincentive will that be? Will it mean that workers who should be receiving financial support will be so intimidated by that risk that they will not pursue their rights?

I would have to say that I do not fully understand how moving the common law damages in line with the Civil Liability Act will impact on people in terms of quantum, but perhaps the minister will clarify that in his summing-up. In the situation of contributory negligence, I think most reasonable Queenslanders believe that if a worker contributes to an incident then that contribution should be recognised in their eligibility for payment. I think if somebody has been drinking on a site or taking drugs on a site, irrespective of the zero tolerance requirements, then reasonable Queenslanders will say that, yes, they have to be held accountable for that. If equipment has been supplied to them but they have refused to use it--refused, not been unable to--then that has to be taken into account.

I would like another clarification. Again, I commend the member for Brisbane Central because I did go and have a chat with her yesterday in relation to this bill. I spoke about the capping of damages for pain and suffering at approximately $300,000 and damages for economic loss of future earnings being capped at three times the Queensland ordinary earnings. I wonder how many people that will catch and how many will be disadvantaged by that proposal. I note that there will be a review of this piece of legislation in two years. A lot of people can be negatively impacted in two years but it is a short time frame and I welcome that time frame.

I note that the minister said in his second reading speech that injured workers who elect to pursue a common law claim will be subject to quantum and liability restrictions. He also said that, in addition, a court will be able to award costs against a worker where the claim is not successful. I have already placed on the record my concern about that because I do believe it will be intimidatory. I think some workers will consider not pursuing their rights rather than pursuing them at the risk of awards being granted against them.

I have one more clarification. The minister said that the amendment to the Workplace Health and Safety Act ‘will preclude retrospectively and prospectively only those claims where negligence under common law cannot be proved’. In a subsequent paragraph, he went on to say, ‘If the amendment only applied to injuries that occurred after the introduction of the bill into parliament, it will not address the growth in claims.’ That appears to be a retrospective application and I would seek the minister’s clarification.

The minister and others here have talked about the premium rate to employers being the lowest in Australia. I commend the minister for that. I commend governments in the past which have made changes to achieve that. I think it is easy for us to stand in this chamber and debate and discuss theories and theoretical situations. The fact is that workers compensation and rehabilitation affects people who are injured at work.

When I opposed some of the stuff with Santo Santoro, I had the media chasing me wanting to know why. I have had a number of people in my family affected by workers compensation quite profoundly. They are vulnerable at the time they need help the most. We need to the best of our ability to maintain that assistance and that safety net, not only for the injured worker but for the injured worker’s family.

Mr KNUTH (Dalrymple--LNP) (8.43 pm): The proposed changes in the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill are just another bandaid solution to an overloaded system and ignore the real issue, which is access to common law and the aggressive marketing by law firms to encourage speculative claims. The government has blamed the global financial crisis for every catastrophe arising from this government’s poor policy. Successive Labor governments have systematically dismantled the WorkCover scheme and, as a result, the number of common law claims has increased by 100 per cent in the past three years.

This government was informed by key industry groups that the fundamental problem is access to common law and that to reduce the number of claims it needs to reduce the access to common law whole person impairment from zero per cent to 10 per cent or 15 per cent. While the ‘quantum and liability’ restrictions placed on common law claims put more onus on claimants to prove employers at fault, it is still just another example of this government’s whole approach of dealing with the process, not the problem.

The problem is claimant access to common law. This was the finding of the independent report. This was the basis of the recommendation by the WorkCover board. This is the recommendation that consistently appeared in the public response to the discussion paper. This is the advice that the government has repeatedly ignored. Once again, we see a government that is more interested in short-term popularity rather than long-term sustainability. These changes will not address the very real threat of insolvency and will definitely not produce a WorkCover scheme that benefits all Queenslanders.

These changes do nothing to address the aggressive no-win, no-fee marketing of law firms. If this government were serious about reducing the number of claims, which is a determining factor in the solvency of the WorkCover scheme, it would enforce the restrictions introduced by the Labor government in 2002 by the Personal Injuries Proceedings Act. This government is not interested in adhering to its own party policy.

In my constituency, there are many small business owners who are hesitant to employ people because the cover is not employer friendly. The measure of capping the general damages at $300,000 is not the real issue. The minister really needs to address the aggressive marketing of law firms and reduce the high number of claims of access to common law.

Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (8.46 pm): I am aghast at the remarks on the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill by the honourable member for Dalrymple in terms of the ability for workers to access common law claims and his equally remarkable tirade against lawyers. In my career as a lawyer, I acted for many railway workers, fettlers and so on, with very, very bad back injuries who alleviated the misery they were suffering through obtaining justice through the courts through common law claims. The honourable member, as I understand, has a background in railway matters and I would suggest to him, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that he might like to acquaint himself with some of the tragedies that have occurred in that industry over the years and some of the benefits that have arisen as a result of people’s right to seek justice before the courts via, I might add, lawyers who are prepared to take on cases, many of which are extremely risky and many of which are lost at the lawyer’s expense.

I will just make a few comments in relation to this legislation, not because it is unimportant--it is very, very important--but because I think the arguments have been well advanced by the Attorney and by speakers from the government in this debate so far. I congratulate the Attorney sincerely for what he has been able to achieve here. It is quite a remarkable achievement, bearing in mind the rather drastic situation in which the WorkCover fund found itself earlier this year for the reasons that have been given. The first reason was the global financial crisis, but the expansion of common law claims that was occurring was also a reason. Whatever the reason, it was in a fairly dire strait and drastic action had to be taken.

Extremes of predictable advice were given to the Attorney from points of interest in the spectrum from people and organisations that are involved in the workers compensation field. The Attorney was able to get together all of the players and come up with this solution that we see in this legislation today, which I believe is extremely reasonable and just. Of course, a review will take place over the ensuing year or so and we will see what happens as a result of that.

My interest in this subject matter goes back a long time and in fact was the reason I became active in the Labor Party. I felt that moves within my party in the early 1990s to restrict the rights of workers to seek justice before the courts was wrong. I felt it was important to fight against that and to fight against it within the Labor Party. I am here today because of those actions at that time. It would be very remiss of me not to stand up for those workers and this subject matter in this debate tonight.

I think what has been proposed here is eminently fair and just. I again congratulate the Attorney for that. There are good, bad and indifferent lawyers as there are managers of common law claim files or CTP claim files. There is that myriad of human nature that comes into play. It would be a very game person to say that everyone on one side of the argument is pure. I do not say that.

I looked at the figures in the WorkCover report for 2009. It shows that settlements out of court rose from $294.8 million to $352.5 million between 2008 and 2009. That shows a very considerable increase in settlements of that nature. It does support what I have been told anecdotally that WorkCover was extremely accommodating in terms of settlement negotiations.

It was different 10 years ago or 12 years ago when I was practising. It was very difficult to ever get a settlement out of WorkCover other than at the door of the court. In those days I felt it was better to have a system which encouraged settlement to reduce legal cost and delay rather than ever imagining that settlements could be reached overly generously. The honourable member for Southern Downs gave an alleged example of an instance where a lawyer asked for $100,000 and his advice to his client was that he would get $100,000 and the opening offer from WorkCover was $200,000. I find that quite incredible and very unlikely to be correct even though the honourable member might believe it to be so. It would have been historic in legal history if that were the case.

Nevertheless, there does seem to have been an overenthusiasm to settle as a result of the authorities in the courts of recent times. What we are now seeing under this legislation is that the law that will apply is the law that applied up until recent years--that is, where contributory negligence has its place. We also see sensible caps on damages in line with the Civil Liability Act. All told, this legislation is, in my view, eminently sensible and just. I commend the Attorney for his efforts.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP)
(8.52 pm): I wish to make a short contribution in support of the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the Premier, the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Parliamentary Secretary for Industrial Relations for their determination and patient work throughout the preparation of this bill and their preparation of the government’s response to WorkCover’s report to government.

There were many options open to government as to how to address the financial difficulties of WorkCover which were caused by the global financial crisis. Some in the community wanted workers compensation premiums to be massively increased, with a detrimental impact on jobs. Others wanted the rights of injured workers slashed, preventing them from taking legal action against negligent employers. However, despite these calls, the Premier, the Minister for Industrial Relations and the Parliamentary Secretary for Industrial Relations I believe have delivered a balanced solution which sees a modest increase to workers compensation premiums, which will still remain the lowest in the nation, and some appropriate changes to the workers compensation law as set out in this bill.

I was disappointed, if not surprised, by the comments of the member for Southern Downs which essentially summarised the position of the opposition on this bill. He made a number of outrageous claims that injured workers were getting unjustified payments from WorkCover due to the negligence, laziness or incompetence of WorkCover officials. We have come to expect the member for Southern Downs to make unfounded smears in support of his arguments. In this case, it is just another attempt to cloak the conservative side of politics’ opposition to fair redress for injured workers. Nothing has changed in conservative politics since the days of Santo Santoro back in 2006 when he used temporary financial difficulties in WorkCover to argue for cutting the rights of injured workers.

The member for Southern Downs also proved that he remains the great denier. Prior to the 2009 election campaign he denied the world was experiencing a financial catastrophe. He is still in denial. He puts up all sorts of reasons for the financial difficulties that WorkCover has found itself in other than the primary reason being the global financial crisis.
Mr Springborg interjected.
Mr WATT: He continues to bleat. He continues to deny the global financial crisis. Again he uses this as a desperate argument to undermine the rights of injured workers.
Mr Finn: You disagreed with Obama.
Mr WATT: As the member for Yeerongpilly points out, he has the hide to disagree with the President of the United States on this issue. That is a very bold move for a three-time election loser.

This bill is a balanced, reasonable approach to correct the financial difficulties experienced by WorkCover while retaining the fundamental rights of injured workers to seek legal redress. I commend the bill to the House.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (8.55 pm): There can be no-one else to blame for the current problems in the Queensland workers compensation scheme, known as Q-Comp, other than the incumbent Labor government. It exists as a party to support workers. Today, in this 2010 bill, to some extent changes are being implemented that mirror those that opposition speaker after speaker raised in the debate on the predecessor to this bill in 2003. At that time, the organisation was divided into two entities.

Historically, the problem with workers compensation faced by the Borbidge government 12 years ago was a failed scheme that was unable to survive let alone assist injured workers without an emergency government bailout. This was after eight years of Labor. This was a fund that had run for decades for the benefit of employed Queensland workers. If members need reminding, Premier Borbidge commissioned Jim Kennedy to review the scheme and give recommendations to enable the workers compensation scheme to go on.

For a Labor administration to drive this entity charged with providing a correctly funded scheme to assist those at work into the ground and at the transition of government to hand over a near dead carcass is not just hypocritical but financially incompetent and, more so, immoral. By 2003 Labor had done it again and Q-Comp had hit the wall again.

It gets worse. The malaise of this organisation runs parallel to the government’s stewardship of the scheme. In 2003 the then Labor Premier, on behalf of Labor, reached out and locked in all employees who were not organised enough to escape from its clutches. Those who escaped--major retailers, miners, large private companies and the BCC--have had a much different passage to Q-Comp people since 2003.

What the examples from private industry have demonstrated is that when comparisons are made between those in Q-Comp, costs, outcomes, management and patient care are very different. In fact, there are clear examples and compelling evidence that amply demonstrate that for an equivalent injury, an equivalent situation and equivalent management the private system gets people back to work faster, rehabilitated and at a significant lower cost to the funds, employers and employees themselves. Sadly, there is a stark contrast between Q-Comp and private workers compensation in the areas of early return to work, rehabilitation, ease of payment, speed of claims processing and defence of defensible claims where appropriate and settlements from them. There is a strong approach to issues of contributory negligence and careful prudential management of funds allocated to claims present, past and future.

There appears to have been an assumption within Q-Comp or the WorkCover board of a higher knowledge of how best to do it and complacency about how difficult problems should be approached by excluding themselves from legitimate competition and the perception that if it all gets too hard the government will bail out Q-Comp again. Q-Comp became lazy and compliant. These are the reasons for comments about laziness. On the ground, this leads to overt hostility from some medical and allied health providers to workers compensation cases because the treatment of those providers by the WorkCover authority is appalling.

I am uncertain whether this pliancy of WorkCover was due to the weakness of the board, the massive bloated bureaucracy or the demands of unions. However, when we end up with a system that is unsustainable and within seven years has the same problems which require a rewrite, we have to examine what the problems are. The weak claims of the government that the GFC has affected the fortunes of the statutory fund of workers compensation are hollow indeed because, firstly, the government has chosen not to allow access to full financial data, as is the norm, because this is not secret data; secondly, the investment of workers compensation appears at surface value to have lost significant value 18 months prior to the GFC; and, thirdly, it is accepted knowledge that settlements to the injured are running at 80 per cent over that of reasonable tort estimates.

The current estimate of potential unfunded liabilities is said to be $8 billion. Therefore, in the absence of a significant increase in income and significant changes in settlements and disbursements, the scheme will be insolvent. The mere fact that things have been allowed to get so bad is an indictment on both the government and the workers compensation board and its senior management. For an organisation entrusted with securing the compensation rights of over two million Queensland workers, this is disgraceful and it brings great shame on all of those players.

The problem had got so bad that the scheme was on the verge of collapse this year, with losses of $1.3 billion in the last two years. Every change since 1988 has weakened the scheme to the point where the changes as proposed today are to be given royal assent. It is no secret that many of these changes that I highlight are those that are LNP policy positions, and it is well known. No wonder Labor today is adopting them, because they are sensible and sound for employees and employers.

Firstly, it is capping general damage awards to $300,000 and restricting maximum disbursements at three times average wages, and this is combined with an injury value scale. Secondly, there is the introduction of contributory negligence. Thirdly, there is the capacity to reclaim costs against both vexatious claims and failed cases--that is, unsuccessful claims. Fourthly, Q-Comp is to undertake actuarial modelling and briefing.

Sadly, however, it is more what Q-Comp has failed to change that is most disconcerting. Firstly, it did not take immediate action to reduce the number of common law claims; secondly, it did not address internal issues of financial competence, with a far greater potential for rebates for no claims, limited claims, well-managed claims and those claims that are easily settled; thirdly, it did not have an increased focus and funds for rehabilitation and return-to-work initiatives. In fact, for those who are unaware, WorkCover is currently cancelling contracts with rehabilitation providers who have had a good history of successful return to work. In fact, 30 per cent of the money allocated for this is allegedly being cut out of the funds.

So, really, is this bill only addressing the problems that Labor alone created in the last 13 years? Labor is not sensibly confronting those issues that workers compensation globally is facing into the future. Labor’s idea of best practice is to repeatedly state that the average premium for workers compensation will be the lowest in the nation. This does not mean that this is the best scheme; nor does this average mean anything at all, since many high-cost areas are basket cases for Q-Comp, employees and employers. Equally, jettisoning rehabilitation providers, as has been done, means losing all of the corporate knowledge, particularly on the most successful way to return these people to work.

Q-Comp really has a great impact on the people in my electorate of Gaven because it is highly involved in the construction industry. It has a large pool of small business owners and both employers and employees. They are involved in tourism, construction and property business and there are times when employees need access and need maintenance from the system. The problem is that no-one really has the kind of discretionary income in the absence of a regular wage to sustain them when they are injured in the course of their work.
