XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 13 to 16, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 17--

Mr SPRINGBORG (10.23 pm): This provision deals with written final offers if claims are not settled at compulsory conference. I have a couple of questions for the Attorney-General. Again, if he does not have the information at his fingertips I will be happy to place it on notice. How many claims are settled before compulsory conference and how many have been settled where there was no medical assessment done prior to an offer being made by WorkCover?

Mr DICK: I see a pattern forming. The member will be using this process to trawl for information and not, of course, speak to the substance of reform, the need for reform, the importance of change. In his inconsistent and incoherent contribution to the second reading debate the member wanted it every which way but, of course, presented no consistent position on behalf of the opposition. I am happy to provide those figures at a subsequent time subject to my examination of them.

Mr SPRINGBORG: Frankly, I am just giving the Attorney-General the liberty of being able to seek that information, because I know that in briefings with the Attorney-General’s own staff from time to time this information needs to be sought, even when examining the Attorney-General during the estimates process. But if the Attorney-General wants to engage in a philosophical debate about why and how the WorkCover scheme in Queensland ended up in the malaise that it has, I am more than happy to engage him in the time that is available to us.

We even had a concession from the Attorney-General earlier in his summary that a number of issues are associated with the malaise of WorkCover in Queensland. The Attorney-General continues to raise the old hoary chestnut of the global financial crisis, notwithstanding the fact that WorkCover’s own report for the 2005-06 year shows clearly a significant $900 million turnaround. That is not including the injection of a $400 million return on earnings that year. The issue is far more than just the global financial crisis, as that did not exist at that stage.

Again, one of the fundamental issues--and even the Attorney-General conceded this--was the mismanagement or the lack of prudence when it came to dealing with common law claims in Queensland. That was brought to the Attorney-General’s attention during the inquiry that he initiated. It was also pointed out during the public consultation phase. So there is no doubt that the lack of fundamental management of the common law scheme of WorkCover has compromised and placed the viability of the entire scheme as we know it at risk.

If the scheme had been managed properly from the start through a combination of more prudent investment, making sure that the fund had an appropriate solvency ratio of 30 per cent--not 20 per cent--and making sure that common sense was used and the premium rates were not reduced from a high of $1.55 per $100 to $1.15 per $100 and the common law claims were managed properly, then maybe there would be no need to impose the restrictions that are being placed on common law in this parliament tonight. So the Attorney-General should not come into this place and say that there are not some alternatives when there are very, very clear alternatives.

It has also been extremely clear that, despite the Attorney-General’s protestations and assertions in this House tonight, we do not have access to the full actuarial advice that we need to be able to guide us in the final decision-making process. If the Attorney-General believes that the interest groups that were consulted throughout this process were comforted by the cut-down version of the actuary’s advice then he needs to think again. In my discussion with those groups, including the Law Society, they felt that there was a long way to go in terms of the advice that was given to them, the background information and the actuarial data that they required to be able to make a proper assessment of the likely success of the legislative reforms that are recommended to be passed in this place. So the Attorney-General should not come into this place suggesting that he has been fulsome. He should not come into this place suggesting that the government has been open on this issue when it has been anything but open with the information that is required not only by the opposition but also by the various interest groups that entered into good faith negotiations and which were denied information that they should have received in a more fulsome way.

Mr DICK: It is always an error to give the Deputy Leader of the Opposition a platform. I apologise to all honourable members for raising that, because we got the wall of sound for five minutes. Why speak for one minute when you can speak for five minutes? But it was good; I am glad that I put out the invitation to him because we had the extraordinary suggestion by the party that supposedly represents business in this place that a prudent way to deal with the workers compensation scheme was not to reduce the premium for business from $1.55 to $1.15. So I will be very comfortable in telling every business in Queensland that that remains the opposition’s policy: high premiums--higher than the premiums in other states. At $1.55 that would put it at one of the highest levels in the country. I am very happy to put to industry and to business that the opposition is a high-taxing, high-premium party. I am very happy to do that. The member opposite has displayed his true colours. We know what his views are on business. Those opposite are no longer the party of business; they are the party of political expedience, as the Country Party has always been.

Mr SPRINGBORG: For somebody who actually stands in this place and proffers a belief against verballing, that is the greatest verbal that I have ever heard in this House. For a person who is supposed to believe in the law and be able to engage in debate on merit, a person who stands in this place and says that somebody does not have a right to speak yet is in a profession that charges by the word, to dare say that we were advocating an unfettered reduction in premiums or an increase in premiums is absolutely, completely wrong.

In my speech I referred to a debate that was held in this place 2 years ago when the honourable member for Clayfield properly asked the then minister for industrial relations whether it was actuarially sound to reduce premiums at that particular time, whether it was going to compromise the bottom line of the WorkCover scheme in Queensland. The then minister went on to say that, yes, it was actuarially sound, that it was safe to reduce premiums in Queensland, that it would in no way compromise the soundness of the workers compensation scheme in Queensland. We now know that that was not the case. Of course we laughed, and we would like to know that premiums are able to be reduced. No-one would argue against that.

What we are saying is that there was improper actuarial advice, or the improper interpretation of that advice, in the parliament 2 years ago and no-one can actually argue against that. If that was the proper advice which was offered by the then minister then we would not have to be running back into this place some 2 years later to put up premiums again. We would not have to be running back into this place 2 years later to jack up premiums. Clearly the government got it wrong at that particular stage.

We will always advocate the reduction of the burden of government regulation and cost on business, but in order to be able to make all of those decisions one needs to be furnished properly with the facts. Clearly at that time, 2 years ago, there was not a proper furnishing of the facts, and I think the events since that time can verify that absolutely.
Mr DICK: The honourable member dissembles. My comments stand.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 18 to 20, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DICK (10.33 pm): I move the following amendment--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 2 Clause 21 (Insertion of new ch 5, pts 8 and 9)

XML.Hansard-Body: The bill as it stands proposes that damages for loss of superannuation entitlements if awarded be limited to the nine per cent superannuation guarantee charge. The current provisions in the bill are copied from section 56 of the Civil Liability Act 2003. The Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 2003 does not currently limit the manner in which a court can award damages for loss of future employer superannuation contributions. Some categories of employees receive more generous employer superannuation contributions in excess of the nine per cent superannuation guarantee. The government does not intend to penalise those workers receiving a higher contribution given that such contributions can form a significant proportion of damages. The amendment that I have introduced will maintain the court’s discretion to decide damages for loss of future superannuation contributions for workers. This amendment maintains the status quo in this area.

Mr SPRINGBORG: I have a couple of questions to put to the minister in relation to clause 21. This is quite an extensive clause covering a whole range of issues to do with the matter of common law access, putting caps on general damages, putting caps on payment for loss of income et cetera, et cetera. One of the issues in relation to this is the introduction of the principle of contributory negligence. Is the minister able to provide a costing analysis undertaken by WorkCover that would show the expected cost saving to the scheme through the introduction of these provisions? If it has not been undertaken, why has it not been undertaken given that there may be an effect or otherwise of this particular provision in bringing down the payment?

The minister indicated earlier on that he and the government rely upon the advice of WorkCover and its board. On the surface that sounds quite appropriate. If one has faith and confidence in the board then that certainly should be the case. The minister has been indicating tonight that he has absolute confidence in the board, its operations, its management of the fund, its guidance on the administration of the fund, its investment recommendations and the way it is dealing with a whole range of things. Is it a fact that the WorkCover board has provided advice to the government that there should be a reduction of 70 per cent in common law claims otherwise it is likely that there are going to be premium increases over the next four years which will see the premiums paid by employers in Queensland being amongst the highest, if not the highest, in all of Australia? Has a request been made by the WorkCover board that there should be moves to reduce common law claims by 70 per cent and, in the event of that not happening, has it expressed concern that premiums would increase to the highest level in Australia over the next four years?

Mr DICK: In relation to contributory negligence, there is actuarial advice, I understand, that it should decrease the cost by about nine per cent. That is the advice we have, but this is imperfect because it relates to change of human behaviour. Changing how people engage with the common law system, whether they sue or not because they need to consider the consequences of proving negligence and the issue of being exposed to costs, will change behaviour. Modelling human behaviour is imperfect, as we all know.

In relation to future premiums, again the honourable member displays his ignorance of how the premium is set. The premium is set by the board on recommendation to the government and the minister of the day can veto the proposal or recommendation. It is done on an annual basis. We need to bring stability to the increasing number of common law claims. The board will have to consider over time what the premium will be on a year-to-year basis. It has a better crystal ball than me if it knows what the impact of these legislative reforms will be over the next 12 months when they set the premium for the next financial year, and similarly for the next financial year after that. It is a matter for the board independent of government.

I know there has been criticism over time of the board. I know that the members opposite have criticised the union representatives on the board in this House and outside. They have contributed significantly to the workers compensation scheme and it is appropriate that representatives of injured workers be on that board. I stand fully behind unions being represented on the workers compensation board and I, for one, will not criticise them as others have in this House and in other places. The premium will be subject to review over time but the critical issue is to ensure that the scheme remains solvent and the board will make appropriate recommendations going forward.

Mr SPRINGBORG: I do understand that the government reserves the prerogative through the recommendation of the minister to accept or reject the offerings of the board by way of its experience, by way of its recommendations. Unless I missed something, I am not sure that the minister completely or in part answered my question. Did the minister or the government receive advice from the WorkCover board that common law claims or payments needed to be reduced by 70 per cent otherwise over the next four years there was a risk that premiums for employers would have to increase by a significant amount, taking them to amongst the highest, if not the highest, in Australia? Did the minister or the government receive advice from the board that common law claims needed to be reduced by 70 per cent or we could see the scenario of Queensland employers facing the highest WorkCover premiums in Australia?

Mr DICK: I am sorry; I missed the question. The answer was so obvious that I mistook it. It is no state secret--it has been out there from the day we received the report--that the board recommended a threshold for common law claims of 10 per cent or 15 per cent of whole person impairment. If you take out those injured workers below 15 per cent whole person impairment, it is 70 per cent of people who bring common law claims. That is what the board recommended and that is what we have known all along, since it was recommended to government last year. As I hope all honourable members would acknowledge today, if you take out every one who is under a 15 per cent whole person impairment you take out 70 per cent of claimants for common law claims, which is a very significant cut, a very significant wall, a very significant threshold to put to people who are injured in the workplace. We know others seek to abolish common law claims altogether, which has happened in other states and led to the financial instability in those schemes in other states. We think that the balance is right. Short-tail scheme, open access to common law, and that is what we are trying to maintain in Queensland.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I wanted to again raise the concern of many in the community with the capping of the common law claims. I heard what the minister just said, although it is very difficult because the minister speaks very quickly and if there is other noise in the background it is very difficult to follow what he is saying. I am assuming that he has agreed that the changes to the legislation that he has brought in will result in a significant reduction in common law claims. Can I say that the board’s recommendation of whole person impairment of 10 per cent to 50 per cent is a significant impairment?
Mr Dick: Ten per cent or 15 per cent.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I thought he said to 10 per cent to 50 per cent. I was thinking that that was a huge impairment, if that was what was being brought in. Again I am sorry, I could not hear. However, I did want to put on the record that I am concerned about the capping of claims. I do hope that the Attorney can give an undertaking that, in the review in two years’ time, if the impact on workers is more significant than anticipated, the government--and I note that it would be after the next election, so whoever was in government--would genuinely review that situation. If it impacts on workers much more significantly, even for workers whose impairment whilst slight has a significant impact on their ability to earn, these measures should be unravelled and unravelled quickly.

Mr DICK: Just to clarify for the member for Gladstone, the recommendation of the board was that we put a threshold in for common law claims, either a 10 per cent whole person impairment or a 15 per cent whole person impairment, to knock out most of the people effectively who would bring common law claims, thereby bringing down the costs of common law claims significantly. That was the recommendation the board made and, following the very detailed examination of that, the stakeholder process and having received public comments we decided not to go down that path.

What the member says is right, and others have already made representations to government that we need to look at the impact on common law claims and, if they not only plateau but start to diminish, others have suggested we might need to permit the common law scheme to expand again. I think we need to be careful. We do need to see how these reforms take effect, but there are mechanisms, of course, that can be used. Reviewing injury scale values is one, and another is looking at the caps we have put on down the track to see whether there is some capacity to expand the eligibility and the damages that might be awarded. However, the key thing is to ensure financial stability, which is what we will do. Once we put a threshold in, of course, it is very difficult to ever go back. That is one of the challenges for any government that either abolishes common law or introduces a very significant threshold. That is the really significant issue that has been a great challenge to the government, to get the balance right of continuing to have open access to common law to protect the Queensland system and, at the same time, ensuring the burden on employers is kept reasonable and as limited as possible through appropriate and relevant premiums.

Mr SPRINGBORG: Further to my earlier question, the Attorney-General has indicated through mathematical concession that the board did indicate that there needed to be a 70 per cent reduction in the amount of common law payouts in Queensland. The other part of my question, which the Attorney-General did not properly answer, is this: was the Attorney-General made aware through this process that unless the reforms addressed this common law growth and reduced the numbers by 70 per cent we would be facing the highest premiums for employers in Queensland of all the Australian state and territory jurisdictions? Did he receive the advice that, if that does not work, if his reforms do not actually reduce it by 70 per cent, in four years Queensland will have amongst the highest premiums of any state or territory jurisdiction in Australia?

Mr DICK: It is no state secret that the WorkCover board has a very firm position about what has to happen. It is very firm in its view that there needs to be a threshold to common law claims. Again I affirm on the parliamentary record that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, speaking for the opposition, has today confirmed that they do not support a threshold to common law claims. I can assure the member that every trade unionist, every worker and every member of the Australian Labor Party will hold him to that commitment. We will hold him to that commitment. Before the dinner break, during an exchange following an interjection, I challenged the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and he was very quick to come back after the dinner break to put on record that he does not support thresholds. We will hold the Liberal National Party to that commitment. I hope he is not trying to back out of it now by his interjections. No, I did not think so. He is going to stick to that. I hope that represents the ongoing position of the Liberal National Party.

The board has very strong views about what should happen. We are confident that premiums can be kept at reasonable levels. Frankly, four years time will be after the review of institutional working arrangements that we are going to do immediately, and it will be after the effectiveness review that we will do in two years time. There will be effectively two premium years that we will negotiate, that we will need to get through those years that the board will set premiums for. We will assess the financial situation then.

As I said, I do not direct the board. I do not tell it what the premium will be. It will set its own premium. We are confident that these changes will be effective, but ultimately we are looking to changing human behaviour. If human behaviour does not change and common law claims are not stabilised within WorkCover, we will have to consider the matters afresh.
Amendment agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 22 to 28, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 29--

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (10.49 pm): Clauses 29 right through to clause 32, I believe, deal with costs. I do not really want to speak to each of the clauses and hold the House up, so my comments cover those clauses. I am very concerned about the awarding of costs in that I have not heard the minister say--and I cannot see it in the bill--that these amendments deal with vexatious or mischievous claims. It appears to go across that. In fact, the explanatory notes in relation to this bracket of clauses about costs, and again with the minister’s forbearance, states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Clause 32 inserts new sections 318A to 318E regarding the awarding of costs in particular circumstances. A court may make an order for costs other than the prescribed order if the party ordered to pay costs shows the other order is appropriate in the circumstances, or if an award of damages is affected by factors that were not reasonably foreseeable by a party at a time of making or failing to accept a written final offer. A failure to accept a written final offer or later offer includes a refusal to accept the offer. The clause also prescribes conditions for costs orders for interlocutory applications and orders where an entity was not a party at the compulsory conference.
XML.Hansard-Body: Your eyes glaze over. I am thinking of people who are injured who do not feel that the offer is high enough. It will not compensate them for their loss of perhaps physical activity, and it may be a whole person impairment that is quite low. They seek advice from solicitors--and I know the member for Toowoomba North was defending solicitors earlier. My experience is that some solicitors are excellent and some solicitors really do need solicitors to defend them. If you are an injured worker, you do not know that. It might be the first time you have talked to a solicitor about anything. If they get a solicitor that is reasonable then they should get good advice.

I am concerned that there does not appear to be any consideration of the nature of the claim. Is it vexatious, is it mischievous or is it a genuine claim that the worker thought they had good foundations for, perhaps were poorly advised and then at the end of the court case have costs awarded against them? They have not only lost time at work, they have not only lost some physical ability or intellectual or emotional ability, but then they get this bill. It would be the straw that breaks the camel’s back. I want to know how subjective the assessment of awarding of costs is and whether the vexatious or mischievous nature of a claim will be an overriding factor.

Mr DICK: I thank the member for Gladstone for the question. Obviously the standard operation of the law in Queensland will be imported now into common law claims for work related injuries--that is, costs follow the event. So, if the plaintiff succeeds, their costs will be paid by the other side. If the plaintiff fails and cannot prove negligence then they will be subject potentially to a costs order made by the court. So the way that the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation Act and the Workplace Health and Safety Act had been interpreted was that it was effectively a strict liability rule. If you were injured in the workplace, you basically could succeed in your common law claim, regardless of having to prove negligence or otherwise. So what we are doing now is bringing workplace injuries in line with other injuries sustained, for example, in a motor vehicle accident or in some other, as I said earlier, public place or in a large retail shop. For example, if you slip over and the floor was slippery or there was something on the floor that had not been cleaned up and the occupier of the premises was liable for not doing what they should have done and owed you a duty of care, people will be brought into line with those causes of action. So you have to prove negligence by the employer. That is the long and the short of it.

The aim is to try to ensure that people think carefully before they sue, before they bring proceedings. Now it is open slather effectively and people do not have to consider that, which is why the number of common law claims has gone up and the claims costs have increased because people are bringing these claims however they are injured in the workplace. It is, I suppose, a dampening. It is designed to change litigation culture, to change the behaviour of lawyers but also to make people think about bringing proceedings.

The member talked about vexatious claims. Ultimately it is for the plaintiff to prove that the employer was negligent. An individual will have to take advice on that from a solicitor. Solicitors have a duty to provide frank advice to clients. They cannot mislead clients. They cannot induce them to bring proceedings. They have to discharge their obligation as an officer of the court. They have a fiduciary duty to their client to be open and frank and fair and honest. So every legal practitioner in Queensland has that duty. They will have to be frank with their client about whether they can succeed or not. So people will still be protected. They will still get compensation because they will be compensated through the statutory scheme.

If they want to bring a common law claim, they will have to think about it. It is up to the individual really. If the injured worker is bringing a vexatious claim where there is a very tenuous link or there is no link to liability, then they will need to be very careful about bringing those proceedings because if they are unsuccessful, because it was a bit of a try on frankly then they may be exposed to costs. Ultimately, there are decision points to be made about whether you sue, whether you bring proceedings--those sorts of things. That is the broad picture. Again, it is designed to change litigation behaviour to try to plateau the increasing number of common law claims, if that is of any assistance to the honourable member.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 30 to 43, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 44--

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (10.56 pm): This again is an issue that the minister responded to in the second reading debate but I could not hear what he said and I could not follow what he said. The clause refers to no civil cause of action based on contravention of the act, the act being the Workplace Health and Safety Act. In the minister’s second reading speech, he says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill amends the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1995 to remove any private civil right of action arising under the act--that is, a worker will not be able to rely on a breach of the Workplace Health and Safety Act 1995 to support their claim of common law negligence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I see that as a significant change. The minister goes on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This amendment will preclude retrospectively and prospectively only those claims where negligence under common law cannot be proved. The approach is justified on the basis that common law claims under the Workers’ Compensation and Rehabilitation Act 2003 are generally lodged between one and three years after the injury. If the amendment only applied to injuries that occurred after the introduction of the bill into parliament, it will not address the growth in claims.
XML.Hansard-Body: So it is a retrospective clause. I would like to better understand what sorts of people will be affected by that retrospectivity, what sorts of numbers will be affected and why, from my understanding--and it could be flawed--the minister is saying that if there is a breach of workplace health and safety an injured worker cannot use that as a defence.

Mr DICK: I apologise to the honourable member for speaking too quickly or not loudly enough during the second reading debate if that has made it difficult for her. So I apologise for that. I will continue with where I left off before the member’s last question. The decision of the Court of Appeal in Bourk v Power Serve dealt with the interpretation of the Workplace Health and Safety Act. The Court of Appeal basically attached strict liability to an employer for any injury that occurred in a workplace. So where the relevant section of the Workplace Health and Safety Act was breached and there was an injury, then the court held the employer liable for the negligence. That is how it was determined. That is how the court interpreted the law, that part of that act.

So the purpose of the amendment, if I can put it on the record, is to address a perception that strict liability attaches to an employer if a work injury has occurred regardless of fault. So you do not have to prove fault; you just have to prove that there was a breach of workplace health and safety in the workplace and you were injured. You do not have to prove anyone was at fault.

The decision in the Bourk case affirmed that, if a worker is injured at work and there is a causal connection between the injury and work, the employer has breached the duty under the Workplace Health and Safety Act and the injured worker could recover. What we are doing with this amendment is removing that right of action under the Workplace Health and Safety Act, but it does not affect any other cause of action the worker may have in relation to his or her injury, such as a breach of duty of care in negligence or in contract. So he or she can still sue for negligence but it is removing that right.

If you are suing to recover damages for a breach of the Workplace Health and Safety Act--if you are basically bringing a Bourk action, bringing an action under the Workplace Health and Safety Act--we are saying you are no longer permitted to do that. We are winding the law back to what it was before the Bourk decision was made. That is a significant decision, as I said. That is a retrospective decision, but it is designed to bring financial stability to the scheme because the cost of the Bourk actions is significant. I am advised it is in the tens of millions of dollars.

I said in my second reading speech that we do not think there are a large number of claims currently on foot. If your trial is running before a court in Queensland where you have pleaded Bourk, that can continue, but if you commenced proceedings or you have not commenced proceedings you will no longer be able to rely on it. We will be allowing people to amend their pleadings. We will not be challenging them. We will not be seeking a cost order if they need to bring an application to do that because they might not plead Bourk; they might plead general negligence in the workplace.

We have done this basically to take the significant cost burden for Bourk actions out of the workers compensation scheme for common law claims. It is a significant thing to do, but it is designed to save the scheme money. People can still sue for negligence; they just will not be able to rely on the strict liability that attaches to a breach of the Workplace Health and Safety Act. I hope that assists you and has not confused you more.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 45 and 46, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (11.03 pm): I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Kilburn, on your election as a Temporary Speaker. I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill, as amended, be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill, as amended, be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (11.04 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (11.04 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Loaves and Fishes Food Friendship Kitchen
XML.Hansard-Body: Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (11.04 pm): Once in a while something truly remarkable occurs and, because it is happening at such a humble level, it often gets missed. In the Gaven electorate, a mixed group of volunteers led by Louise Jennings is feeding hundreds of those who, through no fault of their own, are largely unable to feed themselves, house themselves or build sustainable lives.

Six years ago, Michael Ware and Toni Demmey started this twice-weekly lunchtime meal service. Louise, a neighbour, who is a mother of seven children and on a pension, asked to help. Since that time, thousands have been fed week on week and nightly from Coomera to Coolangatta, have had bread or food delivered to their homes, have had meals prepared for free or have been given food parcels, money or food vouchers to local suppliers. Louise has helped largely through the local St Vincent de Paul Society, although she was not a member of it. She has voluntarily delivered so much to so many for nothing, other than a need to assist and a love of her fellow men and women.

Local bakeries, food suppliers, service station operators, fruit shops and butchers have helped. Each year, they contribute hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of stock that might otherwise be disposed of. This group has spawned a neighbourhood barbecue group run by the parishioners of the local St Margaret’s Anglican Church. There is a list of volunteers distributing food, food parcels from a food bank and funds to enable the survival of some very needy people. Representatives of Blair Athol, the Department of Communities and Health routinely attend these meals because there are a high number of people who are drug affected and who have mental illnesses. No preaching or brainwashing occurs.

Louise has widened the group meal to take in the needs of the young people in the local Nerang skate park. These Nerang and surrounding district locals have followed the teaching of Christ. Loaves and Fishes has made many whose lives have been challenged a little more tolerable and very happy, and there can be no greater gift to offer. Their actions have triggered actions from others. Another group of volunteers have spent three years, as I said, providing this barbecue at Bischoff Pioneer Park in Nerang. Rain, hail or shine, every Tuesday this group provides a meal with a second course to the very needy of our local Nerang community. All sorts of people come and go at that barbecue, from the genuinely needy to those seeking a friend to talk to.

With our electorate office assistance, they have applied for a Woolworths food rescue grant that will hopefully facilitate the recycling of fresh food that major food stores otherwise dispose of. This food is not past its use-by date. This may make the process sustainable. In a sometimes Godless world, we do not always notice how many are not just talking the talk but walking it too.

It is a great credit to our community that the efforts of volunteers are able to do so much for so many, and they want to do more. The Meals on Wheels group, the Red Cross, the CWA, the senior citizens group together with the Loaves and Fishes group are merely just anonymous people serving anonymous citizens. Without any fanfare, the Nerang Neighbourhood Centre has delivered the same sort of service. Every day of every year all these groups live by a motto--

Ms NELSON-CARR (Mundingburra--ALP) (11.07 pm): A couple of weeks ago, I spoke in this place about the perils of gambling and the toll this pastime can take on people who spend more and more time and money gambling than they would like to or that they can afford. Unfortunately, my message was lost with my aside about small men on horses. In fact, the aside became an instant attention piece for my local paper--and none too complimentary, I might add. I wish to raise my concerns again in the hope that my views reach some level of interest in the great outside.

Gambling can be an occasional fun exercise but unfortunately, like any addiction, the costs can be massive. It is not just the hip pocket that struggles either, because the problem can strain relationships, interfere with home and work responsibilities, as well as take families down the road to financial catastrophe. People often do things they would not normally do when they are in the grip of this horrible addiction, like steal, deprive family and regularly hurt loved ones. Thankfully, help is available in many forms, but the key is in admitting the problem and then sticking to it with treatment and support. It is like alcoholism: facing it and doing something about it with support. Maintaining that recovery takes commitment, but the key for any addiction is to stay away from the activity. You have to avoid tempting environments and find activities to replace the addictive behaviour.

Fortunately for some killer addictions in this country we have legislative protections, smoking being an excellent example. We have the best outcomes in the world as a result. But while we have solutions and support for smokers and drinkers and, to a lesser extent, gamblers, what hopelessly addicted gamblers face in their own homes is much more frightening. Alcoholics and smokers have a circuit breaker. They have to make a conscious decision to leave the house, drive, cycle or walk to a bottle shop or corner store to get their supplies and they are not bombarded with TV encouragements to smoke and drink. It is not so for gamblers. The temptation for gamblers is in their faces in their own homes.

As a society, I ask: how can we sit by and accept that on free-to-air TV gambling is an accepted norm? Viewers are deluged with the betting odds, the picks, the favourites and the ease with which it can be done--right there in your lounge room. It is on all their most watched favourite sports events and it is every few minutes.

I believe that while ever there is an event on free-to-air TV, advertising to gamble should be banned. Just asking people to gamble responsibly is really not responsible. Alcoholics cannot drink responsibly. Drug addicts cannot inject responsibly and nor do we urge people to do so, either. Gambling advertising, on the other hand, is fed with the lie that keeps the addiction alive and well. It is guaranteed to bring pain, hardship, family breakdown and suffering into the home. We must act responsibly and stop the abuse. Ban gambling on free-to-air TV.

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (11.10 pm): On several occasions I have brought the views of my electorate to this House about the government’s water reform agenda. Water supply and security have been a high priority for successive Redland councils. In the Redlands, the foresight of former councils ensured the Redlands has always had sufficient water to provide for its community.

Former Redland shire mayor Don Seccombe said that the state government taking control of dams, weirs, bulk water pipes and wastewater treatments plants in South-East Queensland while councils control the domestic distribution system and water retail businesses was ‘not good for the Redlands’. He further stated that the ‘Redlands has planned ahead and paid for its water security over the years and now we are being penalised.’ The former mayor’s comments were echoed loudly by many in the community and the unrest about the state government’s takeover continues today.

1 July brings with it further changes in the delivery of water services for the Redlands. On 1 July, as a result of the state government’s failed water reform program, a new entity that is jointly owned by the Redland, Logan and Gold Coast city councils, Allconnex Water, will take over the local delivery of water, recycled water, trade waste and wastewater services from Redland Water.

A new problem has developed with the state government’s solution, and that is the potential of remaining Redland Water assets to be significantly undervalued in the transfer to Allconnex Water. The water assets have been independently valued in excess of $700 million, but Allconnex has written them down to just over $400 million. This shortfall of more than $300 million will mean the Redlands will be ripped off again by the state government’s water management policy. This major write-down of assets means that Redlanders will have a much lower level of equity in the new business which, in the short term, would likely result in reduced annual revenue for the council which will ultimately drive rates up.

Again, the residents of my electorate of Cleveland, and the broader Redlands, appear to have been ripped off by this state Labor government when it comes to water management. The latest is that there may still be further negotiations about the value of the Redland Water assets and thus the equity of the Redlands in Allconnex and the resultant level of rate rises in the Redlands.

Today I am calling on the government to take into account in its final deliberations the forward thinking of Redlands councils’ thinking and planning that built the necessary water infrastructure to provide a more-than-adequate water supply for this growing community in the first place. It is now up to the government to finally show some fairness towards the Redlands vis-a-vis the community’s water or it will put a nail in the coffin of cost-effective water delivery to the residents of the Redlands.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (11.13 pm): Yesterday I tabled a petition bringing the local council works on the destruction of vegetation on the dunes along Rickman Parade, Woorim, to the attention of the parliament. I wrote to the council requesting that it immediately cease all works and that a full investigation be conducted to see whether due process was followed. The planned works are extensive and expensive and are not normal maintenance. Such major works demand public consultation but none was undertaken.

Principle 2.9.9B of the State Coastal Management Plan states that ‘all levels of government participate in coastal planning in an open and cooperative way’. Nothing about the council’s decision was open and cooperative if one considers that at the 17 March 2010 meeting of the council’s Woorim Erosion Reference Group, WERG--specifically formed by council; one of the terms of reference for the group is to ‘assist with consideration and input into the protection of the Woorim Beach environment’--the proposed major works were not even mentioned by the local councillor who was there. This is an extraordinary omission since I discovered last week that the plan had been developing for some time. His press release the next day said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There is now an understanding that everybody needs to work together to achieve our common goal of protecting Woorim Beach from the forces of Mother nature.
XML.Hansard-Body: What hollow words. There is an agreement between the council and the federal government’s Envirofund Woorim Beach Dune Stabilisation Project 2007 which includes the in-kind contribution by the council to construct and repair fencing along the Woorim foreshore on both the eastern and western sides of the dunes, but only in consultation with the Envirofund. Approximately 700 metres has now been removed along Rickman Parade by the council without any consultation with the Woorim Envirofund Natural Heritage Trust committee.

Mayor Allan Sutherland, to his credit, visited the site. Unfortunately, he was told by a senior officer that WERG was not consulted because the work was being done only on the western side of the dune. He was misled. The plan lacks any formal detail and is useless in the hands of amateur supervisors who do not understand the important role of dunal vegetation. Even the department of resource management was concerned about the lack of detail in the proposal and asked the council for a list of actual trees to be removed and how, suggesting removal by hand instead of heavy equipment.

Unfortunately, these dunes are on the council’s road reserve so the state government does not have to tick it off. The council’s excuses to remove vegetation are pathetic. They contradict previous advice in 2008 to residents warning them to be vigilant and take note of anyone damaging vegetation because it is illegal. At a time when budgetary constraints are paramount, this work, if any is genuinely required, could be undertaken by a properly funded, environmentally sound landcare group.

The council has done some excellent work at Woorim with state government funds but removing this vegetation is not good. It is underhanded and smacks of favouritism for those few who will benefit from hundreds of thousands of ratepayers’ dollars to get better water views. Those responsible should feel ashamed.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP) (11.16 pm): As a mother of three young adults, I am very interested in the issues that matter to our young people, their hopes and aspirations and how they see Queensland now and in the future. I really enjoy engaging with young people in my local area, whether it is through their schools, their workplaces or community groups. Outside my electorate I have had the pleasure of participating in the Peace Parliament and attending YMCA Youth Parliaments, the next being held in this chamber in September.

Tonight, however, I would like to speak about the Indigenous Youth Forum and Indigenous Youth Parliament that I had the great opportunity to be part of last week here in the precinct. As I learned, the Indigenous Youth Leadership Program aims to improve the leadership skills of young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Through the program, young people learn about Queensland parliament’s democratic processes, develop their leadership skills and develop networks with peers and potential mentors.

The forum is designed for Indigenous youth aged 18 to 25 years. This year there were 65 applicants from which 40 youth members were selected. The program supports and encourages the development of future Indigenous leaders, and these young people get inspiration and motivation through the sharing of stories and experiences. Most importantly, these young leaders are encouraged to apply the leadership skills learned from the program in their respective communities.

Forty youth members and four youth mentors from urban, regional and rural Queensland gathered to discuss matters with particular relevance to the Indigenous community but also discussed issues that face the broader community. It was terrific to see a gathering of articulate and confident young people who are poised to become our leaders of tomorrow. The majority of participants were employed full time, part time or were undertaking study. One youth member was a young mother who had her baby with her.

I very much enjoyed the first day, when I shared with the group my own journey to this place. There was particular attention paid by those interested in seeking political office in the preselection process and election campaigning. Day 2 was the Youth Parliament, where I had the pleasure of taking on Deputy Speaker duties when the youth members debated the Indigenous Healthy Lifestyles Bill 2010. It was a lively debate, won by the opposition. I look forward to reading the Hansard when it becomes available.

There were many outstanding speeches, but I would like to mention one contribution that, although brief, was extremely powerful. It was delivered by the Youth Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade in the adjournment debate. The speech was in relation to the age of retirement for Indigenous men which is presently 67 years. The youth minister highlighted that the life expectancy differential between non-Indigenous and Indigenous Australians was 17 years. His speech focused on the current reality that until the Close the Gap campaign is successful most Indigenous males may never get to enjoy the benefits of retirement.

I believe that overwhelmingly our young people, irrespective of their background, are solid community members who want to make a positive contribution. From where I stand, I believe that our state is in good hands for the future.

Mr CHOI (Capalaba--ALP) (11.19 pm): This evening I rise to render my support to school chaplains and commend the work they perform in our schools. Recently our state celebrated Chaplaincy Week, which was a great opportunity to recognise the important role our school chaplains play in the life of our schools and our wider communities. Across Queensland more than 500 chaplains support students and their families in more than 600 schools. School chaplains help students to handle issues they are confronted with and better ways to deal with challenges they face. This could range from a student’s loneliness in a new school or a new city through to substance abuse by the student or a member of their family and may even include at times very serious issues such as abuse, depression and self-harm. Scripture Union Queensland is officially endorsed by Education Queensland as an accredited employing authority for school chaplains. Each chaplain provides a personal point of contact with care and support for students, teachers and their families within the schools.

During Chaplaincy Week each year communities are invited to help raise funds to support the work of each chaplain, or ‘chappy’ as they are known in schools. Breakfasts, dinners, sporting events and other projects are all dedicated to raise funds and the profile of chappies and the work they do. I want to take the opportunity to acknowledge the hard work of some of the chappies in my electorate: Joy Livingstone at Capalaba State College, Terry Keen at Alexandra Hills State School, Lyn Keen at Hilliard State School, Amy Dolling at Birkdale South State School and Anna-Claire Hoey and her colleague Peta Lloyd at Alexandra Hills State High School.

The recent Redlands chaplaincy dinner was another opportunity to highlight the important work that our chappies do. It was a pleasure to have the company of Tim Mander, the CEO of Scripture Union, and Ken Mihill, our area organiser from SU, who together with the SU event team put on a fantastic evening with over 150 guests attending, including Olympic swimmer Duncan Armstrong as our emcee and Phil Smith as guest speaker. Phil spoke of the importance of setting an example for our young people by being dedicated to a purpose and that all of our actions have consequences, positively or negatively. In each of our schools which have chappies on board students can find a safe place to talk about problems they are facing and can sit down and find ways of easing the pain in their lives and help to pick up the pieces and work on new attitudes and learn new skills to deal with challenges. One outback student is quoted as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think it would be naive for ... communities to believe that there is no need for someone like chappies. Stuff happens behind closed doors that most people don’t know about, big and small. Without the help I was given, I know I would be dead.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: With those comments, I commend the work of chappies in our schools.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Cleveland-Redland Bay Road, Road Surface Noise
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DOWLING (Redlands--LNP) (11.22 pm): Tonight I rise on behalf of the many residents of a small estate whose lives have been turned upside down at the hands of Main Roads, and I am pleased to see the minister in the chamber and I hope that he will intervene and help them. One family that have reached the end of their tether, their humour and their patience with Main Roads are the Brewsters, and I table for the information of members of the House a letter from Scott and Joy Brewster.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 7 June 2010, from Joy and Scott Brewster regarding resurfacing of the Cleveland-Redland Bay Road [ 2396 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Can members imagine the surprise of residents when a road surfacing job along Cleveland-Redland Bay Road at Victoria Point would result in a worse surface when the work was finished and a noisier surface when the work was finished? When all calls for help have gone unanswered or--worse than that--they are given completely wrong information, they are devastated. Scott and Joy are devastated by the way that they have been treated so far by the department.

I believe the department is actually conning the community by delivering on only half the project. The road in question had an asphalt surface which has been replaced by Main Roads, which has allowed a replacement with a spray tar and chip seal finish. So what does that mean? It means that you save a few thousand dollars upfront, but at what cost? You end up with a rough corrugated road surface where the life of the asset is reduced significantly. Then there is the added cost of time by engineers and others responding to complaints. There is the emotional cost to the community because of the noise dB rating going through the roof. Families have lost the use of their backyards. It means that Scott and Joy can no longer sleep in their own master bedroom. It means that Scott and Joy and families adjoining this road are sleep deprived. This couple believe that they have been lied to by representatives of this government, which I find unacceptable and I am sure all members do as well.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): The honourable member will withdraw that word.

Mr DOWLING: I withdraw the comment. I call on the minister to heed the wishes of petitioners whose petition was tabled this morning and intervene in this instance. This Bligh Labor government has a history of overpromising and underdelivering, and here we have another prime example. Redland City Council tried this half-baked chip seal practice many years ago and found it to be unacceptable. It is short-sighted. It is a penny-pinching strategy that fails. Road construction is a simple process--you spray the tar down, you whack some gravel on it and then after it is bedded down you then do the cap in asphalt cement. In this case, that part has not happened. By not applying the final topcoat--the AC layer--the road life is reduced, and this road is already showing signs of failure. You save a dollar today, you skimp today, and you pay dearly for it tomorrow--yet another demonstration of this government’s mismanagement, a false economy, a lack of adhering to standards, and residents of Redlands are going to suffer with this until the road is fixed. The residents of Queensland will continue to suffer because of this type of systemic failure by the Bligh Labor government. The Brewsters and other families need your help, Minister, and I add my congratulations on your elevation, Mr Deputy Speaker Kilburn.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (11.25 pm): Last Friday morning I hosted a breakfast to kick off the week-long celebrations of the Hayes Inlet Festival. The Hayes Inlet Festival is designed to shine a spotlight on our beautiful Hayes Inlet waterways and to educate the community on the unique ecosystems. These waterways are the filter that keeps the waters of the bay pristine and many of the fish that are caught in the bay have their breeding grounds in those waterways. The week will be packed with activities including a family fun day, information events about the wading birds that migrate from the Northern Hemisphere, boat rides through the inlet and walks into the wetlands where koalas can still be spotted and the odd cheeky kangaroo can be sighted taking a short cut across the mudflats at low tide.

Some 80 businesspeople, the members for Kallangur and Petrie, representatives from community groups and schools sat down to a delicious breakfast at the Redcliffe Leagues Club with guest speakers Channel 7 weatherman John Schluter and Miles Yeates, regional manager of Queensland Parks and Wildlife Service. Miles’s presentation impressed the gathering and reflected the cutting-edge role Parks and Wildlife has in implementing sustainable practices in our natural environments, including a spectacular PowerPoint demonstration showing why dugong are susceptible to propeller strike. John Schluter was excited by the festival and keen to promote it and the importance of the Hayes Inlet waterways in the future.

The Hayes Inlet Festival reflects the Bligh government’s Toward Q2 goals to protect the environment and manage it sustainably. I have been working with a committee of locals in conjunction with cross-departmental representatives towards a 10-year plan for the Hayes Inlet, Saltwater Creek and Pine River waterways to Kurwongbah. The Bligh government is committed to protecting our vital waterways and is acting not only here in Hayes Inlet or in the south-east but right across the state, including increased protections for the Great Barrier Reef and wild rivers, the koala strategy, new national parks, increased protections for Moreton Bay, the Green Army and many measures to protect Queensland’s biodiversity. Only this Bligh Labor government has the vision to protect Queensland’s natural heritage and the courage to turn that vision into reality to deliver the policy and action that will ensure not only pristine Hayes Inlet waterways and a clean, sustainable Moreton Bay but all of our vital natural environments across the state.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Burnett and Bundaberg Dental Patients, Compensation
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (11.27 pm): Tonight I renew my calls for this government to apologise and compensate the 268 Burnett and Bundaberg dental patients who were operated on by Queensland Health medical staff using unclean and non-sterile dental equipment. Some 268 Burnett and Bundaberg dental patients in mid-November 2009 were told by Queensland Health that they had been exposed to HIV and other blood-borne diseases because of a failure to properly sterilise dental equipment. Some 268 patients and their families suffered over Christmas, some fearing to kiss their children or cuddle their partners for more than three months while waiting for medical test results, and deserve to be compensated. Innocent women and children have been harmed and damaged by this government, and this health minister thinks that he can ignore these people’s legitimate claims for compensation. Each victim deserves an immediate payment of $5,000. They should not be forced to spend their own money on lawyers to achieve justice and fair compensation.

Bradley O’Kane is a dangerous man. In 2005, he randomly stabbed a 42-year-old woman at Robina while allowed out of the mental unit to go shopping. He is currently held at The Park mental facility. He has a history of attacking staff and has repeatedly threatened to strangle them and slash their throats. We have all heard the assurances from the health minister about the locks that will not work. We have all heard that they were meant to be fixed by April. We have all heard, too, that the health minister is familiar with system failures and avoiding responsibility. But despite the ham-fisted promises, the locks still do not work. Just recently, a staff member was locked in a room with O’Kane because the locks failed again. That is a potentially lethal situation, because this health minister will not fix the problem. Incredibly, the failing lock was removed and replaced with a lock from the room of another dangerous patient. This then left another violent patient with a lock that did not function.

The risks at The Park are real. Staff are regularly attacked. I have been informed that one nurse was bashed so badly that she had to use a straw to eat. Another was stabbed. There was no warning and no reason. This person went to work one day and got stabbed. One day a nurse will go to work and not go home to his or her family. Someone will be killed if action is not taken immediately. We cannot wait for a minister who has proven by his actions that he does not care and he will not get his act together.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Marsden State School, Horsing Around Program
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (11.30 pm): During Education Week, I witnessed the mysterious power of a beautiful horse to calm the spirit of young students aged 10 to 12 with varying degrees of behavioural issues, learning difficulties, lack of confidence and interpersonal skills and problem-solving ability. The night before, inspired Marsden State School teacher Jill Strachan went forward to receive the South Coast region award for Excellence in Inclusive Education. Their program, Horsing Around, has been designed to facilitate social and emotional learning. Six to eight students were selected, some from the special education unit, to take part in an eight-week course of two hours per week where they would learn to identify the horse and calmly approach and read the mood of the horse. They would go on to learn to catch and greet the horse, calmly place a soft bridle on and lead the horse, work in a team to construct an obstacle course to lead the horse through, learn grooming and, finally, to ride the horse, which is quite an accomplishment for young students who come with their fears and apprehensions.

My visit to the equestrian centre at Waterford West coincided with week 5 for this group of children and here I was to witness students who had already progressed significantly in this incredible transformation conducted by Equine Learning for Futures Inc. It was simply amazing. I watched in awe as one by one the students donned a helmet, quietly and calmly entered the enclosure, picked up the harness and confidently approached Lady. They held out the back of their hand to greet her and then quite proficiently placed the harness on her. Principal Kevin Leathwaite stood beside me, outlining the dramatic transformations that had taken place over these five short weeks, where once there was a child who may have been uncooperative in class, often distracted and lacking in concentration--and some children have anger issues--to now be quietly leading Lady around the enclosure. They then dropped the harness and moved close to the horse to gently but firmly push on her chest to force her to step back.

I have for many years known of the power of animals to effect a calming influence on human beings and to change lives, such as when at-risk young people are given the opportunity to spend time on a cattle station or at a horse stud. To see this powerful demonstration was a real privilege. The next exercise was equally remarkable. In the principal’s words, to see these children working in a team to construct an obstacle course would never have happened prior to this program. They communicated with each other, had smiles on their faces, placed items appropriately and led Lady through her paces. Then later on we saw them grooming, cleaning her hoofs and exhibiting a real sense of respect and care for her.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 11.33 pm.
